And have three Jade Maidens of Great Cinnabar attend as guardians,
Lest they fail in reverence and incur the scrutiny of inspecting officers.

The Primordial Yellow Thearch’s true talisman summons the Four Directions’ Direct Talisman Officers to guard the Celestial Writs of Numinous Treasure,
With no central regular officer.
When the Daoist ingests it, numinous *qi* stabilizes the spleen,
Generating twelve petals of yellow essence’s precious blossom.
Spirits are commanded as servants,
Enabling communion with the numinous to attain transcendence.

The above *Comprehensive Numinous Text* derives from the *Yellow Thearch’s True Writ Chapter*,
To pacify the Five *Qi* Heavens of the central direction.
The Yellow Thearch receives this text as the celestial *qi* opens at the center,
Its revolutions responding to the turning wheel.
When this text first appears, the Celestial Gate halts its wheel,
And day and night cease to alternate.
The Primordial One gathers the original text,
Returning it to the *qi* of the Upper Primordium.
Thus, the Central Marchmount lacks this text.
It is recorded in the old scriptures only to preserve it from extinction.
The Four Thearchs jointly oversee its guardianship in the Upper Palace,
With no regular officer to guard it.
Daoists whose destiny belongs to the Central Marchmount
May inscribe yellow talismans on white silk and wear them on the body.
They must also inscribe yellow talismans on white silk,
Place them within the node below the Vermilion Thearch’s on the spirit staff.
The reason Daoists alone may wear this text
Is solely because the Yellow Thearch presides as host,
Aligning with the celestial *qi*.
Though it lacks a guardian officer,
Lest they fail in reverence and incur the scrutiny of inspecting officers.

The Primordial White Thearch’s true talisman summons the Direct Talisman Officer Quzheng to guard the Celestial Writs of Numinous Treasure.
When the Daoist ingests it, numinous *qi* stabilizes the lungs,
Generating seven petals of white essence’s precious blossom.
Spirits are commanded as servants,
Enabling communion with the numinous to attain transcendence.

The above *Radiant Primordial Numinous Text* derives from the *White Thearch’s True Writ Chapter*,
To pacify the Seven *Qi* Heavens of the western direction.
The White Thearch receives this text to guard the Western Marchmount,
Sealing one passage to the Nine Armpits Cavern Mouth of the Metal Cave,
Which opens once every forty thousand kalpas.
Daoists whose destiny belongs to the Western Marchmount
Should inscribe white talismans on *qi*-colored silk and wear them on the body.
They must also inscribe white talismans on *qi*-colored silk,
Place them within the node below the Yellow Thearch’s on the spirit staff,
And have seven Jade Maidens of Great Simplicity attend as guardians,
Lest they fail in reverence and incur the scrutiny of inspecting officers.

The Primordial *Qi* Thearch’s true talisman summons the Direct Talisman Officer Yin Feng to guard the Celestial Writs of Numinous Treasure.
When the Daoist ingests it, numinous *qi* stabilizes the kidneys,
Generating five petals of *qi* essence’s precious blossom.
Spirits are commanded as servants,
Enabling communion with the numinous to attain transcendence.

The above *Luminous Pervasion Text* derives from the *Black Thearch’s True Writ Chapter*,
To pacify the Five *Qi* Heavens of the northern direction.
The Dark Thearch receives this text to guard the Northern Marchmount,
Sealing one passage to the Dark Yin Cavern Chamber,
Which opens once every forty thousand kalpas.
Daoists whose destiny belongs to the Northern Marchmount
Should inscribe *qi* talismans on azure silk and wear them on the body.
They must also inscribe black talismans on azure silk,
Place them within the node below the White Thearch’s on the spirit staff,
And have five Jade Maidens of Great Mystery attend as guardians,
Lest they fail in reverence and incur the scrutiny of inspecting officers.

The Five Thearchs’ true talismans:
Their upper essence in heaven becomes the Five Stars,
Their middle essence in the human body becomes the Five Viscera,
Their lower essence on earth becomes the Five Marchmounts.
Thus, the fishes of the Three Primordia each have their respective affiliations.
Without the Five Writs in heaven, the Three Luminaries remain dim;
Without the Five Writs in humans, there is no means to establish form;
Without the Five Writs on earth, the Five Marchmounts lose their numinosity.
The Five Thearchs’ true talismans,
Born together with the Primordial One,
Are now concealed in the Purple Tenuity Palace of the Mysterious Capital.
Five hundred million divine officers attend the Five Thearchs,
And all heavens pay homage thrice monthly.
The true writs are guarded by fire, water, yin-yang officials,
And their disclosure is strictly forbidden.
The Primordial Heavenly Worthy seals them within the spirit staff,
Which must always accompany the body.
This is to conceal and repay the celestial perfected,
Never to be parted from the form even for a moment.

The Primordial spirit staff is made from seven-node bamboo of the Celestial Yang of Mount Ling,
With the five talismans placed in sequence at the center,
Leaving one node empty above and one below,
To correspond to the celestial and terrestrial configurations.
One should select sun-facing bamboo from Mount Ling,
Seven feet in length with seven nodes,
To fashion the spirit staff,
Ensuring the upper and lower sections are straight and unobstructed—sweet bamboo is best.
Inscribe the Black Thearch’s talisman within the second node from the bottom,
The White Thearch’s talisman in the third node,
The Yellow Thearch’s talisman in the fourth node,
The Vermilion Thearch’s talisman in the fifth node,
And the Azure Thearch’s talisman in the sixth node.
Leave the top node empty to connect with heaven,
And the bottom node empty to stand upon earth.
Seal the top node with wax and impress it with the Primordial One’s seal,
Seal the bottom node with wax and impress it with the Five Thearchs’ seal.
Wrap the talismans in crimson silk,
Ensuring the length and width are sufficient to encase the staff.

Carry it with you always—whether lying down, resting, sitting, or rising. When traveling, you may remove the staff from its wrapping to conceal your comings and goings, but always store it in a clean place when setting it aside. Point the staff toward heaven, and the celestial spirits will render homage; point it toward earth, and the terrestrial deities will receive you. Point it toward the northeast, and the myriad ghosts will be bound in form.

When riding the staff in motion or preparing to employ it, strike the teeth thirty-six times in succession. Visualize the five lictors of the Five Thearchs, each clad in the color of their respective direction, their five-colored radiance flowing and illuminating the staff. The jade maidens of the Five Thearchs, one for each, stand together to guard the staff on either side. Whisper the incantation:

"Mountain of the Great Yang,
Primordial essence of the Highest Origin.
Opening heaven, unfurling earth,
Sweet bamboo channels the numinous.
Lictors of the straight talismans, marshaling divine soldiers,
Five hues flow and gleam—vermilion fire, golden bells.
Assisting the perfected on high,
Emerging from darkness, entering the unseen.
Summon the heavens, and the heavens bow;
Command the earth, and the earth welcomes.
Point at ghosts, and ghosts perish;
Demons and malevolent spirits are bound in form.
Numinous talismans, divine staff,
Might to govern the hundred directions.
With me they attain completion,
With me they attain life.
After ten thousand kalpas,
They shall take my place in form.
Their splendor dissolves the Five Bonds,
Their spirits ascend to the Highest Clarity.
By talisman and decree,
None dare disobey."

Conclude by drawing in the qi of the five directions, reversing the flow twenty-five times, then cease.

Practice this Way for nine years with utmost diligence and reverence, and the divine perfected will manifest in form. The staff will then bear you aloft, soaring through the void. Should you seek liberation through the corpse, the staff will assume your form, and in an instant, you shall become a perfected one.

On the first and fifteenth days of the lunar month, your natal day, and the eight solar terms, burn incense to either side and prostrate before the staff. Thus will the numinous spirits descend in response, and the Way will be accomplished.

*From the* **Upper Scripture of the Jade Instructions of the Cavernous Mystery**, *Section on the Tablet of Strategies.*

Inscribe in cinnabar the *Three Heavens Supreme Venerable Summons to Subdue Dragons, Tigers, Leopards, and Mountain Spirits* upon a gold tablet. Record also the year, month, and the master’s surname and personal name on another tablet. Enclose both tablets within a pouch, then inscribe in cinnabar the sequential text upon a third tablet, placing it on the outside of the pouch. Seal the three tablets together in the form of a divine tally, all made of *yin* wood, each one foot and four inches in length and two inches and four *fen* in width. Fashion a pouch from crimson silk, twelve feet in length, to wrap the sealed tablets, binding both ends. Imprint upon it the seal of the Primordial Five Elders of the Middle Origin. Encase the tally in a cypress box lined with crimson silk, and store it in a separate chamber. Burn incense on either side, offering reverent devotion. Once received, wear it upon the body, and all divine spirits under heaven will announce their names at the celestial gate. Twelve Jade Lads and twelve Jade Maidens of the Five Emperors shall be assigned to you, accompanying your ingress and egress, with the Five Emperors as your guards. The administrators of the Three Realms shall receive you, and in life and death, you shall no longer face the three evil destinies. Bypassing Mount Tai, you shall ascend directly to the Nine Heavens, where clothing and sustenance arise spontaneously. Your rank shall equal that of the Supreme Ultimate, and you shall attain immortality as a matter of course.

When a Daoist adept who has received this teaching wears this text and performs the divine incantations, pointing the tally toward heaven will summon celestial spirits to descend; pointing it toward earth will cause earthly deities to prostrate in homage, with the Three Realms girding their sashes in attendance. Pointing it at spirits will make them bow in reverence; pointing it at ghosts will cause them to perish and dissipate. Pointing it at water will make the water spirits clear the way. Even when the great kalpa turns and the four floods converge in cataclysm, the tally may be used to summon dragons to bear you aloft. Through long cultivation and accumulated resonance, divine spirits will gather in response. Wherever you issue the summons, they shall arrive at once, manifesting myriad wonders as you will. In your comings and goings, your rank shall be commensurate with the Supreme Ultimate, ever preceded by flying dragons and followed by the celestial hook, with phoenixes crying and simurghs singing. Twelve radiant blossoms of light shall appear, and banners of the Three-Seven Colored Numinous Command shall be raised. After nine years of concentrated practice, the celestial regalia shall assemble of its own accord.

The *Eight Mighty Divine Incantations of the Numinous Treasure* state:

Primordial Supreme Perfected,
Five Spirits Most Exalted.
Radiant as the Great Flower,
Illuminating the Eight Gates.
The Five Elders issue their decree,
No hidden realm remains unopened.
Above, they govern the Nine Heavens;
At center, they command Mount Feng;
Below, they rule the rivers and seas,
The twelve sources of all waters.
The Eight Mighty Divine Incantations,
The Numinous Tally and Jade Texts.
Summon dragons to bear the waters,
Gather qi and amass the clouds.
Bind demons and dispatch ghosts,
Sweep away all demonic hordes.
Ten thousand spirits shall be shattered,
None shall escape the execution.
Sun and moon, the Five Stars,
The Northern Dipper’s Seven Origins.
All heavens, all earths,
All waters, all mountains,
The Jade Perfected’s hosts,
The Great Spirits of the Netherworld.
The Immortal Kings at their feasts,
The Five Emperors with their banners.
Celestial soldiers lead the way,
Golden tigers rush behind.
Fierce beasts of the highest heaven
Guard the four gates.
What is called shall arrive at once,
What is summoned shall appear before you.
The Vermilion Script blazes forth,
Wind and fire unceasing.
Whatever is seized or verified
Is transmitted by golden dragons.
Conclude by knocking the teeth nine times, inhaling toward heaven thrice, drawing in the celestial qi three times, and pointing the tally staff toward the designated place. Hold the breath for nine cycles, then cease.

*From the* **Scripture of the Azure Essence and Purple Writ of the Golden Root of the Cavernous Perfection**, *Section on the Casting of Tallies.*

The Most Exalted Azure Youth Lord said: None among the later sagely hosts of perfected beings fail first to present the golden tally to the Eastern Florescence or cast the jade writ to the Supreme Clarity before they may receive the *Great Cavern Perfection Scripture*, refine themselves through rigorous purification, and ascend as perfected persons. Yet those of shallow learning, lacking the golden tally’s register in the Azure Palace and the jade ledger’s mystic inscription, may neither unroll the divine scriptures nor command the celestial demons to be gathered. The true numina shall never descend, nor shall jade maidens guard their bodies.

Now, in accordance with the statutes of the Supreme August, I have compiled and arranged these ranks to serve as a gateway for later learners. Those of sincere heart should intensify their pure fasts, rouse their resolve with diligence, and fix their thoughts upon the mysterious truth, moving the Jade Emperor to respond. Once the golden tally is presented to the Azure Palace, they may recite the divine scriptures, penetrate the hidden depths, and the Most High shall dispatch the cinnabar chariot of flying wheels to welcome their forms, ascending to the Jade Clarity.

Yet this prohibition is most weighty—it is not transmitted to the untrue. The Most High regularly dispatches the Jade Dawn Primordial August Supreme Perfection Perfected One, leading the Immortal Jade Lords, to the Eastern Florescence Azure Palace on the first day of the first month, the seventh day of the seventh month, and the ninth day of the ninth month—three times yearly—to review and confirm the registers of perfected immortals. Those whose names are inscribed on golden tallies and jade ledgers shall be reported to the Three Origins, and according to the depth of their cultivation, jade youths and jade maidens shall guard their bodies. Should any divulge these secrets, slight the true teachings, or treat the laws with disdain, the jade youths shall report them. Even those with golden tallies shall be struck from the rolls, their names transferred to the offices of ghosts, their bodies subjected to the trials of the wind-blade, their seven dark ancestors burdened with the stones of Mount Meng to fill the River of Eternal Night.

All who pursue this study must, on these appointed days, calm their minds in a secluded chamber, burn pure incense, and meditate in stillness. Scatter incense to left and right, inscribe the golden tally eight times in vermilion, bind it with purple cords, and present it to the Most High Jade Emperor of the Eastern Florescence Azure Palace. Prepare eight jade writs to present to the Three Origins. First, within the oratory, face east, knock the teeth nine times, and perform one cycle of praise and obeisance.

Thereafter, reverently address the Most High Supreme Jade Emperor, the Thirty-Nine Emperors, and the Twenty-Four Perfected Ones:

*"This humble mountain adept, [Name], born in the [Month] of [Year], on the [Day] of the [Month] of [Year], at the [Hour] of the [Day], presents the golden tally, purple register, and jade ledger, submitting this text to the Most High Supreme Jade Emperor, the Thirty-Nine Emperors, and the Twenty-Four Exalted Perfected Ones, to the golden tally’s purple radiance and the jade splendor of the numinous palace."*

Inscribe this in purple script, one foot in length, and attach it to the golden tally before casting it. Address it to the Most High Void August Jade Clarity Perfected One of the Eastern Florescence Azure Palace, [Name], who bows twice in reverence.

Inscribe this on one tally and present it.

The petition reads:

Present one tally.

To the Most High Void August Jade Clarity Supreme Dao Lord of the Twenty-Four Jade Emperors and the Thirty-Nine August Emperors, this humble adept [Name], a petty servant of this declining age, humbly touched by lingering blessings and filled with felicitous destiny, has been permitted to attend the exalted perfected ones. Reverently following the mystic protocol, on the first day of the first month, I submit this golden tally, inscribing my name in the Eastern Palace, beseeching that it be recorded and enrolled, and that true numinosity be bestowed, allowing me to ride the soaring rosy clouds to ascend to the imperial dawn, my person to mount the golden watchtower, and to present myself in audience before the Jade Emperor. Respectfully submitted.

Present three tallies, together comprising: [Name], Mountain Scholar of [such-and-such] Commandery, [such-and-such] County, [such-and-such] Village, [Name], aged one thousand years, styled [Name].

Present one tally:
Born in the [such-and-such] month, [Name]’s destiny is bound to [such-and-such] Mountain, [such-and-such] Emperor, [such-and-such] Village.

Present one tally:
In the year of [such-and-such] under the Great Year, on the first day of the first month of the [such-and-such] year, at [such-and-such] Commandery, [such-and-such] County, [such-and-such] Village, [Name] petitions the [such-and-such] Mountain.

Present one tally:
Use eight golden tallies, bound with purple cords. Face north and read the tally once through.

Conclude, rise, hold the tally, and bow twice.

Petition the Three Primordial Ladies:
This humble mountain adept, [Name], styled [Name], born in the [such-and-such] month of the [such-and-such] year, on the first day of the first month of the [such-and-such] year, presents the golden tally and jade tablet, submitting the immortal register and ledger. The text is addressed to the White Primordial Lady, the Yellow Primordial Lady, and the Purple Primordial Lady of the Three Primordials, the Purple Canopy and Golden Radiance Grotto Chamber Palace.

Inscribe this in white script, one foot in length, and attach it to the jade tally before casting it. Addressed to the Jade Clarity Novice Perfected One of the Three Primordials, [Name] bows twice in reverence.

Present one tablet.

Petition reads.

Present one tablet.

To the Primordial Ladies of the Grand Simplicity:
This adept, [Name], having past karmic affinities and accumulated blessings, has received the divine scriptures. Not daring to unfold and examine them, I now respectfully follow the *Mysterious Pattern of the Azure Florescence*, submitting this jade tablet to inscribe my name in the Azure Palace. Addressed to the Three Primordials, I humbly beseech that my name be recorded, true numina be bestowed, and that I may ascend to the Imperial Dawn to pay homage to the Jade Perfected.

Respectfully submitted.

Present three tablets.

The novice perfected of [such-and-such] Peak, [Name], styled [Name], of [such-and-such] Prefecture, [such-and-such] County, [such-and-such] Village, [Name], whose age is recorded in the Thousand-Character Classic as [such-and-such].

Present one tablet.

Born in the [such-and-such] month, with a life mandate under the governance of [such-and-such] Peak and [such-and-such] Emperor of [such-and-such] Village.

Present one tablet.

In the year of the Grand Year [such-and-such], the first day of the first month, [Name] submits this petition from [such-and-such] Prefecture, [such-and-such] County, [such-and-such] Village, sealed under [such-and-such] Peak.

Present one tablet.

Use eight jade tablets, bound with purple cords. Face west and read the jade tablets once through. Conclude, rise, and reverently present.

Addressed to the Primordial Lady of Grand Simplicity, the Yellow Primordial Lady, and the Purple Primordial Lady:
This adept, [Name], having formerly received the true scriptures, golden tally, and jade tablet through the covenant of a perfected master, with my name recorded in the Three Clarities, humbly beseeches that jade lads and jade maidens be granted, true numina descend upon my person, and that I may ride the purple clouds to ascend to the Imperial Palace.

Conclude, rise, and bow twice.

Petition to the *Azure Palace Chapter of the Eastern Florescence*:
The mountain adept [Name], styled [Name], born in the [such-and-such] month of the [such-and-such] year, on the first day of the first month of the [such-and-such] year, presents the golden tally and azure register of immortal ledgers. The text is addressed to the Highest Perfected of the Jade Clarity Azure Palace, the Venerable Master of the Lofty Dawn, and the Lord of the Eastern Florescence Azure Palace of the Jade Treasure Golden Portal.

Inscribe this in azure script, one foot in length, and attach it to the tally before casting it. Addressed to the Highest Perfected of the Jade Clarity Azure Palace, the novice perfected [Name] bows twice in reverence.

Present one tablet.

Petition reads.

Present one tablet.

To the Highest Perfected of the Great Clarity Jade Treasure Golden Portal, the Venerable Master of the Lofty Dawn, and the Lord Azure Lad of the Eastern Sea: this humble adept, mired in the depths of the vulgar world, has been blessed with an abundance of felicitous destiny, flowing down with fortune to be born into the human realm, to partake in the lineage of primordial qi, and to aspire to leave no trace behind. Dwelling in the forests and hills, sheltered beneath the sacred peaks, I reverently follow the mysterious statutes and present this golden tally, inscribing my name in the Upper Palace, beseeching to be granted enrollment in the highest register. May the perfected divinities of the Jade Clarity descend, allowing me to depart the lower world, ascend to the Golden Portal, and proceed to pay homage before the Jade Emperor.

Respectfully submitted.

Present three tablets.

[Such-and-such] Prefecture, [Such-and-such] County, [Such-and-such] Township, [Such-and-such] Peak, novice perfected [Name], aged [such-and-such]—as in the thousand-character text, under the cyclical signs *bing ding*.

Present one tablet.

Born in the [such-and-such] month, life-destiny governed by the [such-and-such] Peak, [such-and-such] Emperor’s domain.

Present one tablet.

In the year of the Great Year [such-and-such], the first month, first day, under the cyclical sign [such-and-such], at [such-and-such] Prefecture, [such-and-such] County, [such-and-such] Township, sealed at [such-and-such] Peak, presented.

Present one tablet.

Eight golden tallies in total, bound with purple cord.

Facing east, read the tally once through.

Completed, reverently submit.

The Most High Jade Treasure of the Great Clarity, Supreme Minister of the Golden Portals, Venerable Master Gaochen of the Eastern Sea, Azure Lad of the East—[Name] B, by fortunate karmic affinity and ancestral blessings, has been graced as a descendant of the lineage. Through the perfection bestowed by the true master, I have received the supreme scripture. Reverently I present the golden tablets, inscribing my name in the Azure Palace, beseeching to be recorded and entrusted to the Jade Youth. May this be universally proclaimed to all heavens and earths, the Perfected of the Caverns of Clarity, Depth, and Origin, and the host of immortals of the Five Peaks. May all witness this distinction, descend with true numen, and ascend upon flying auroras to the Three Clarities.

Completed, I rise and bow twice.

After presenting the tablets on three sides, I turn again to face east, click my teeth nine times, and recite the incantation:

The primal net extends into the distant,
The celestial perfected dwell in the hidden.
By ancestral blessings received,
Fortune graces even the unborn.
Once bound to the true master,
I was admonished and granted the precious scripture.
Dare I announce to the Three Origins,
And present my petition to the Jade Clarity.
Inscribed in gold at Eastern Florescence,
My name is recorded in the register.
Ever to be an imperial servant,
I pray for the descent of true numen,
Bestowed with jade lads and jade maidens to guard my form,
That I may ride the flying clouds,
Ascend to the Golden Portals,
And bow before the Jade Court.

Completed, I raise my head and swallow the fluid nine times, then cease.

All rites concluded, I bury the tablets at the peak to which I belong.
The *Jade Emperor’s Tablet* is placed to the north,
The *Three Origins’ Tablet* to the west,
The *Azure Palace Tablet* to the east,
Buried three feet deep, firmly packed above.

Completed, I face north, prostrate upon the earth, and click my teeth nine times.
Again I recite the incantation:

My name is presented to the Jade Register,
Inscribed in the script of the Upper Clarity.
Golden tablets and jade writs,
Bound into volumes at the imperial court.
Lofty and distant, the Three Origins dwell in the hidden.
Before the descent of the true officials,
I reverently seal the numinous peak,
Recording and presenting to the Three Clarities.
Listed in Eastern Florescence,
My jade name is inscribed.
May I ascend by the mysterious lift,
Ride the flying auroras in emerald chariots,
Reach the Three Origins,
And soar to the imperial dawn.

Completed, I rise and bow twice.

The method of presenting tablets to seek immortality, as received by the Celestial King of Primordial Beginning from the Most High, requires three presentations of tablets and writs. Within nine years, the Jade Emperor shall bestow cinnabar essence, jade mushrooms, golden seals, and phoenix script. The Perfected of the Great Ultimate shall descend to your chamber, and the Three Origins shall dispatch thirty-six jade lads and jade maidens. The Supreme Minister Azure Lad shall proclaim to the Five Peaks, bestowing the canopy of flying auroras and an immortal’s parasol, to welcome your form and ascend to the palace of the Golden Portals.

The Perfected Lord of Numinous Treasure, [Name], born in the [such-and-such] year, aged [such-and-such] as in the thousand-year cycle, in the [such-and-such] month—wishing for divine transcendence, to become an immortal, and attain eternal life without death. May the Three Origins be preserved as one, the Water Emperors of the Nine Palaces, the Twelve River Sources, the Jiang, the seas, the Huai, the marshes, and the great spirits of the vast and cold. I beseech the erasure of my sinful name, to be heard in the Nine Heavens, and to journey to the Water Palace by golden dragon courier.

On the [such-and-such] day of the [such-and-such] month in the [such-and-such] year, [Name] presents this document in the [such-and-such] kingdom.

Inscribe this in vermilion upon the register-tablet, wrap the tablet in blue paper, bind it with blue silk, and let a golden dragon bear the tablet to be cast into the abyss of the Three Rivers. Initially, use nine golden clasps to fasten the tablets before sinking them. For subsequent castings, this is not required. Perform the rite three times in total.

When casting the tablet, choose a clear and cold abyss. Face north, click the teeth three times, read the document to its end, and recite the incantation:

Primordial Beginning and the Five Elders,
Supreme Lords of the Highest,
Perfected of the Ten Directions,
Divine immortals of Great Florescence.
The vermilion script proclaims the decree,
No hidden realm remains uninformed.
Ascending to govern the Nine Heavens,
I humbly present this document below.
Sun, moon, and the Five Stars,
The Northern Dipper and the Seven Origins.
Announce to the Five Peaks,
The numinous mountains of the four directions.
Proclaim to the rivers and seas,
The Twelve Water Sources,
The Water Emperors of the Nine Palaces,
And the great spirits of the true numen.
Today I make this supreme announcement,
Declaring all my wishes.
I present the jade tablet,
Beseeching the erasure of my sinful name,
My thousand ancestors and ten thousand forebears,
The nine clans and all kin.
Sinful names that have stained me,
May all be erased and their roots severed.
Record my name in the Water Palace,
Announced before the Supreme Emperor.
May my seven generations of ancestors,
Depart from the Eight Difficulties,
Ascend to the Nine Heavens,
And be clothed and fed by nature.
My sins released and dispersed,
May all spirits hear.
I pledge with golden clasps,
To ally with the water officials.
As I have declared,
Let the golden dragon courier transmit.

From the *Supreme Mystery Jade Formulae of the Upper Scripture*.

The Perfected Lord of Numinous Treasure, [Name], born in the [such-and-such] year, aged [such-and-such] as in the thousand-year cycle, in the [such-and-such] month—life-destiny governed by the Red Emperor, name registered at Huo Mountain. Wishing for divine transcendence, to become an immortal, to attain eternal life and transcend the world, to soar and ascend to the Upper Clarity. O Perfected of the Five Peaks, most divine and numinous, I beseech the erasure of my sinful register, to pledge allegiance in the Nine Heavens. I journey to the numinous mountains by golden dragon courier.

On the [such-and-such] day of the [such-and-such] month in the [such-and-such] year, [Name] presents this document at the [such-and-such] Peak.

Inscribe this in vermilion upon a silver tablet, wrap it in blue paper, bind it with blue silk. Use nine golden clasps and one golden dragon, and bury it at the peak of one’s life-destiny. Face east, click the teeth nine times, read the tablet to its end, and recite the incantation:

The mysterious and luminous opens,
The Primordial Beginning oversees the true.
The Five Elders of the Supreme Emperor,
The vermilion script of the red writ.
The origin of heaven and earth,
Governor of the Three Origins.
Commanding qi and summoning assemblies,
Hastening the ascent of immortals.
The supreme talisman proclaims to the Ten Heavens.
Sun, moon, and constellations,
The Five Peaks and numinous mountains.
Above the earth and below the heavens,
The great spirits of the hidden and numinous.
Overseers of life and keepers of records,
The Three Gates of the Southern Summit.
Open and receive the jade tablet,
Inscribe my name in the cinnabar register.
Erase the records of sin,
To supplement the imperial servants.
My thousand ancestors and ten thousand forebears,
The nine clans and all kin,
May all be liberated,
From the Five Paths and Eight Difficulties,
Depart from the Three Evils,
Their souls ascend to the Nine Heavens.
Life and death transcended,
Eternally preserved through ten thousand kalpas.
Today I make this supreme announcement,
May all spirits hear.
I pledge with golden clasps,
To ally with the true officials.
As I have declared,
Let the golden dragon courier transmit.

From the *Primordial Beginning Numinous Treasure Scripture for Announcing to the Five Peaks and Numinous Mountains to Erase Sins and Seek Immortality*.

The Perfected Lord of the Red Emperor of Numinous Treasure, [Name], born in the [such-and-such] year, aged [such-and-such] as in the thousand-year cycle, in the [such-and-such] month—life-destiny registered in the Nine Heavens, governed by the Southern Dipper. Wishing for divine transcendence, to become an immortal, to attain eternal life and transcend the world, to soar and ascend to the Upper Clarity, the Central August of the Nine Earths. O Yellow Spirits of Wu and Ji, the Five Emperors of the Earth Palace, I beseech the erasure of my sinful register, to be inscribed in the Great Mystery. I journey to the Central Palace, present the tablet to record my name, pledging with golden clasps as my token, transmitted by golden dragon courier.

On the [such-and-such] day of the new moon in the [such-and-such] month of the [such-and-such] year, [Name] of [such-and-such] village presents this petition.

The silver tablet is inscribed in cinnabar, wrapped in blue paper, and bound with blue silk. Nine golden clasps and one golden dragon token are buried at the central palace of the petitioner’s residence, all performed according to the above method. Facing the [Celestial] King in the central courtyard, one knocks the teeth twelve times, recites the tablet in full, and intones the incantation:

Heaven unfolds, Earth extends,
Nine qi divide the numinous.
The Three Origins unite in harmony,
The ten directions shine in clarity.
The Five Venerable Lords of the Dao,
Open the true register of life.
Cinnabar script in crimson characters,
Primal essence of the Highest Origin.
Proclaimed throughout the world,
The august spirits of the nine lands.
Today I make this supplication,
The myriad immortals confirm my birth.
I vow to become immortal,
I beseech to inscribe my jade name.
Great Sovereign of the Earth Palace,
Erase my sins and punishments.
Present this tablet to the Upper Palace,
Record it in the registers of Splendid Azure.
Swiftly attain flight and ascension,
In harmony with Heaven and Earth.
Nine generations of kin,
Their decayed bones renewed in glory.
Their souls ascend to the Southern Palace,
Transformed in the immortal courts.
Auspicious day, this decree is issued,
The ten thousand kinds heed its command.
With golden clasps I pledge my sincerity,
As this petition is transmitted by golden dragon courier.

*From The Highest Origin Numinous Treasure Supreme Method for Petitioning the Earth Sovereign of the Nine Lands to Erase Sins, Declare One’s Name, and Seek Immortality*
Thus concludes Scroll Forty-One of *The Supreme Essentials*
Scroll Forty-Two of *The Supreme Essentials* begins

**Chapter on Serving the Master**

When approaching the master with a request or to inquire about the Dao, one must first bow once to the *Scripture Master* and once to the *Register Master*. After this, bow twice more. Then, address the *Initiation Master* and state one’s purpose.

When visiting the master, one should fast and purify oneself from the previous night, don proper ritual attire, and await dawn with reverence, filled with both urgency and joy. One’s conduct must be upright, bowing deeply with measured movements, demeanor composed as though standing before the divine. Each step toward the master should be taken with hands clasped and feet together, mind fixed upon the Perfected Ones above.

Approach the master with wholehearted reverence, hands respectfully gathered, gaze steady, and thoughts clearly focused. Maintain a centered mind, intent upon the mysterious and void, performing rites with solemnity and measured movements.

In bowing and yielding to the master, honor the non-action of the Dao, rejoicing in the void, where joy and felicity converge. Before approaching, wash hands and feet, wear clean and plain garments, and anoint the body with fragrance so that one’s *qi* harmonizes with the divine radiance.

After exchanging greetings with the master, enter the purification hall, burn incense, make vows, and pay homage to the Three Treasures. Adjust one’s ritual attire, arrange oneself properly, and listen with focused attention, responding both inwardly and outwardly with care.

Joy and reverence should fill one’s heart, countenance upright, gaze direct, awe and caution ever-present, as though treading upon thin ice. When seated beside the master, maintain composure without fault, observed by all.

After completing the rites, reflect upon one’s past transgressions in this life and resolve to reform. Once this reflection is complete, still the mind and abide in clarity, holding the divine *qi* within, never straying from it.

After all contemplations, rise to sweep and purify the inner and outer spaces, offering service and devotion in reverent observance. When prostrating before the master to present a request, rise to perform the rites, then return to one’s seat to state one’s purpose.

Speak with a calm and gentle voice, exhaling and inhaling softly, never raising it harshly to harm one’s true *qi*. Choose words carefully, speaking in accordance with the Dao’s intent, never carelessly or with personal bias.

Proceed directly and without deviation, never wandering or wavering in resolve. Seek the true Dao with sincerity, never harboring divided loyalties. Keep heart and speech pure, focused upon the true and real, never consuming alcohol to cloud the divine *qi*.

Uphold the precepts with discipline, unwavering even unto death, never indulging in stray thoughts or worldly distractions. Let one’s *qi* and form be in harmony, never gathering those of disparate kinds.

When resting or sleeping in the master’s presence, remain clothed, thoughts fixed upon the true, never exposing the body. Keep one’s headdress and attire always tidy, never bareheaded, lest one show disrespect to the honored.

Rejoice in the master’s presence as though before a great sage, never giving way to anger or resentment. Cultivate loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and righteousness, never acting with jealousy or harboring unrighteousness.

Conceal the unworthy and proclaim the good, ever promoting the Four Classes, never slandering or suppressing the worthy. Strive to enlighten and liberate all beings, never obstructing or stifling the stubborn.

Awaken the ignorant and guide them into the Dao’s gate, never obscuring the truth or deceiving the true for personal gain. Reflect upon the universal vision of the Dao’s gate, never entertaining wayward thoughts or straying onto crooked paths.

Hold the master’s household in mind, that all may attain flight and ascension, one’s own body serving and ascending to the great sages. If the master is grieved, disciples must share in that sorrow, showing no joy in their comings and goings.

If the master falls ill, disciples must attend closely, observing their breath as though caring for their own parents. If the master faces misfortune, disciples must gather fellow students to establish purification rites and prayers, accumulating merit.

When parting from the master for months or years, disciples must don ritual attire, hold the tablet, bow three times, and kneel to inquire after them. After this, bow twice more, completing five bows. The same is observed upon reunion.

Remember this well—never neglect these observances, lest one be deemed irreverent. When disciples travel or lodge away, they must bow twice and kneel upon parting and returning.

Those who share the same surname, lineage, or ancestral rites in mourning garments may not serve as master and disciple. This is because on the day of initiation, the three generations of grandparents, five generations of ancestors, and seven generations of parents come to witness their descendants’ reception of the Dao. Should one violate their oath, the nine generations will bear the sin, bringing calamity upon the recipient of the Dao’s body—thus, they may not serve as disciples.

In all actions, whether entering or departing, one must first consult and inform the master, never acting arbitrarily or self-indulgently. When walking with the master, never step upon their shadow. When seated with the master, never accept another’s kneeling bows, for there is no second honor in a seat.

When sharing a room with the master, if they rise, move, or depart, disciples must rise and step down, never remaining seated in their presence. Upon first approaching the master to receive the Dao’s teachings, one must wear ritual attire, hold the tablet, and humbly seek instruction, never carelessly or presumptuously speaking.

When presenting the master’s writings, place them upon the table, burn incense, bow twice, then open and read them, reciting each phrase aloud. Afterward, bow twice more and return the writings to the master. The same is observed when responding to the master’s letters.

Disciples must never violate the master’s name or taboo. If asked about the master’s name, and pressed thrice, one must bite the teeth in restraint. Disciples must never touch or disturb the master’s attendants, for officials oversee their conduct.

*From The Scripture of the Golden Register of the Cavernous Mystery, Chapter on Cultivating Study*

The Most High said: In all learning, one must proceed from the lower to the higher, cultivating in proper sequence, never skipping or omitting, lest one violate the celestial statutes and ordinances.

The scriptures comprise three ranks, and the Dao possesses three Perfected Ones. The Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns, the Celestial Script of Great Characters, the Registers of the Nine Heavens, and the Way of the Yellow and White—these allow one to rein the reins of the Dark Empyrean and traverse the Five Marchmounts, thus constituting the first rank of the lower grade.

The Cavernous Mystery of the Numinous Treasure likewise originates with the Primordial Beginning. Its traces are profound and abstruse, its wondrous essence sharing a common source. With fragrant orchids of purification and fasting, the Five Invocations illumine the Mystery. It delivers the seven generations of ancestors and severs the roots of transgression, also causing Perfected Ones to descend and ascend in flight to the Upper Clarity. The marvels of the middle grade do not preclude earthly immortality.

The Daoist Scriptures of the Upper Clarity and the Hidden Writings of the Great Elixir—comprising three hundred treasured names and nine thousand jade instructions—are the foremost titles of the Upper Perfected Ones and the inner chapters of the Jade Emperor. Those who attain them are recorded on the Jade Tablets, their names inscribed in the Azure Palace, ascending at dawn to the Imperial Hall. These are the instructions of the upper grade.

The Most High said: In human learning, all begin with diligence but grow lax in the end, or falter when success is near, entirely due to having resolve that is not steadfast, or being steadfast yet not firm, thus failing to achieve the expected outcome. Heaven does not deceive humanity—it reveals itself through echoes; Earth does not betray humanity—it responds with shadows.

Where echoes and shadows do not reach, the spirits grow distant. Is this not because the celestial truth fails to manifest—all due to the self?

—Excerpted from *The Most High Cavern-Real Plain Numinous Great Possession Scripture*

Those who attain immortality do so through the learning of the heart, and through sincerity of heart; those who attain the Dao do so through inward seeking, and through inner secrecy—then the Dao draws near. Those who attain the Real do so through cultivating stillness and profound quietude—then they merge with the Real; those who attain the numinous do so through accumulated resonance and response—then the spirit becomes efficacious. Those who can constantly uphold these principles draw ever nearer to the day of transcendence.

Yet if the heart is contentious and the spirit startled, if the body is harmonious but the focus scattered, if movement and stillness dissipate essence, if the ears and eyes are overly keen—then even with ceaseless yearning and pursuit of the Dao, the Dao grows ever more distant. Methods of guiding and pulling, of ingesting qi, of embryonic breathing, of closing the heart and preserving thought—along with the esoteric scriptures of the Numinous Middle Chapters, the hidden tones of the Golden Casket, the inner and outer canons of the Yellow Court, and the guard-records of the Great Clarity—numbering several thousand such practices, all have circulated among the common folk, known and heard by all. Since the middle ages, from the time of the Yellow Emperor onward, those who have ascended and transcended by means of these teachings are as numerous as the mountains, beyond counting. Such individuals have exerted their hearts to the utmost, guarded their essence with devotion, held fast to their integrity, and steadied their aspirations. In practicing these four virtues, I shall break the bonds for you and grant you ascent to immortality.

As for those of unstable resolve who undertake these practices: some may toil for years, even decades, without gaining benefit. Why? Some fail to grasp the principles of ingesting qi and regulating breath; others are led astray by external distractions and fail when success is near; some gain temporary benefit but cease upon encountering illness; others receive instruction from their masters yet cannot discern its meaning; some cannot concentrate their minds, their spirits scattered and confused; others accumulate transgressions and offenses, violating celestial taboos; still others recklessly alter scriptural methods according to their own whims. Such cases are commonplace—these are the frivolous and defiled, those who utter empty words, unworthy of instruction. Thus the Great Dao is not disseminated throughout the world, and true immortals seldom wander among mortals—all due to humanity’s deep failings, not the fault of our fellowship.

—Excerpted from *The Most High Cavern-Real Hidden Writ Scripture*

The Perfected Lord Zhou said: Few are those born naturally attuned to the Way; rare are those who understand the Dao from birth. One must cultivate and practice it, study and refine it.

Laozi said: When superior individuals hear of the Dao, they diligently practice it. How true these words are!

—Excerpted from *The Cavern-Real Chamber-Interior Scripture*

The Three Sovereigns said: Those who wish to cultivate the Dao and share the lifespan of the Three Heavens must spurn extravagance and delight in frugality; scorn glory and honor, and find contentment in lowliness and humility; despise brocade and silk, and instead wear coarse cloth while cherishing the jade within.

Those who are not distressed by poverty and lowliness, nor zealous for power and emolument—this is the essence of extending life.

It is further said: For those who practice the Dao, retreat has its obstructions, and advance has its reasons. Like crows and egrets of different kinds, the clear and the turbid flow apart. No goodness is left unraised, no worthy left unpromoted. Heaven’s love never ceases, the spirits’ reverence never rests—this is the enduring path of Dao cultivation.

It is further said: The vast Three Heavens nurture all things together. Others covet the blossoms, while I take the fruit; others seek the ornament, while I receive the essence. With a tranquil mind and hidden stillness, free from the toil of household affairs—this is the way to prolong life.

It is further said: When the world is rigid, comply by softening the heart. Conceal your wings outwardly, withdraw your scales inwardly. Let glory not burden you, let favor not cling to your person. Hide your radiance and conceal your light, withdraw from the world and guard the Real. Preserve the brightness of your eyes, and turn your thoughts to the Five Spirits—this is the great essential for increasing years.

The Heavenly Elder said: When common people cultivate the Dao, their minds are filled with a thousand distractions. Their eyes see gaudy colors, their thoughts grow chaotic, their hearts troubled. The Five Spirits lose their master, and the Dao Lord does not return. Petty men practice for no more than a day or ten, claiming swift attainment, reciting with their mouths and grasping with their hands. Before gaining even a single text, they believe they can preserve their bodies whole. They see only the swift rush of a trickling stream, not the vast depth of rivers and seas. They perceive the fleeting profit of advancement, not the nourishment of the spirit through embracing the Dao.

The Yellow Emperor said: When one receives the Heavenly Writ of the Three Sovereigns, it is always inscribed with one’s predestined name in the Mysterious Register. Having received the divine script, one must practice its methods. First, one must aid and rescue the emperor, dispel calamities, and ensure the nation’s peace and the people’s security. Only then may one withdraw to seclusion and cultivate in tranquility.

—Excerpted from *The Cavern-Spirit Scripture of Overseeing the Heavens*

Cultivate it in the body, and its virtue becomes real;
Cultivate it in the family, and its virtue overflows;
Cultivate it in the village, and its virtue endures;
Cultivate it in the state, and its virtue abounds;
Cultivate it in the world, and its virtue becomes universal.

Thus, observe the body through the body, the family through the family, the village through the village, the state through the state, the world through the world. How do I know the way of the world? By this.

—Excerpted from *The Scripture of Laozi on Virtue*

When the Dao and virtue are cultivated in the body, the heart becomes penetrating and the will unimpeded. One values the spirit and cherishes qi, disdains material things and scorns fame. Thoughts are free from confusion, blood and qi harmonious. The skin is moist and lustrous, the face radiant. The spirit is focused and steadfast, the body light and strong. Void and full complement each other, the temples are glossy, and one’s appearance remains youthful without end.

When cultivated in the family, fathers are kind and children filial, husbands faithful and wives chaste, elder brothers considerate and younger brothers obedient. The nine clans live in harmonious kinship. Farming and sericulture proceed in season, blessings and abundance accumulate. The six livestock multiply, and undertakings flourish with constant surplus.

When cultivated in the village, actions accord with harmony and moderation. The proper norms and disciplines are observed. Right and wrong are clearly distinguished, crooked and straight follow different principles. Truth and falsehood are naturally discerned, treachery and deceit do not arise. Authority and dignity are esteemed. Superiors are served and inferiors transformed, as in a father-son relationship. Love, respect, trust, and devotion prevail. Superiors and subordinates are joyfully close, the hundred clans harmoniously gathered. Officials have no backlog of duties, their posts are well-managed, and their reputations honored. They remain secure until the end of their lives.

When cultivated in the state, the ruler is enlightened and ministers loyal. The court does not conceal the worthy, scholars do not envy merit. Evil does not obscure the upright, slander does not harm the public. Harmony and compliance prevail, superiors and subordinates bear no grudges. All officials are content, and all affairs proceed naturally. Distant peoples yearn and admire, the world follows the prevailing wind. The state is wealthy and the people prosperous. Though unprovoked, it grows strong. Ancestral temples are revered, the altars of soil and grain endure in peace. Yin and yang harmonize, calamities and disorders do not arise. The myriad things flourish, and within the borders, great tranquility reigns. Neighboring states entrust their fate, and future generations prosper. Dao and virtue abound, becoming as constant as Heaven.

—Excerpted from *The Scripture of Wondrous Reality*

Though the Great Dao has no intent, it may be sought with feeling.
I stand my chariot in the empty void,
Gazing back at the hidden currents of the azure flow.
Beyond the Three Realms, pure and bright,
I wander the desolate Jade Capital.
Without the mysterious impetus of fate,
Who can comprehend the obscure subtleties?
The Milky Way shines clear and still,
As I look up and down in the softness of the void.
The Seven Mysteries scatter the dark night,
Returning to the womb, following the ebb and flow.
If one silently awaits the hidden convergence,
The Yang Nine brings no sorrow or care.
Beholding these comings and goings,
Time and again, one lingers.
By relinquishing the body, the body is preserved—
True immortals meet their true companions.

—Excerpted from *The Cavern-Mysterious Scripture of the Nine Heavens*

The Perfected said: For those who study the Dao, their conduct toward others should first be filial to their parents, loyal to their lord, compassionate to those they employ, kind to their friends, trustworthy and reliable, admonishing evil and praising good. Without partiality or self-interest, free from the bias of "I" and "mine," not violating external teachings—this is the ability to practice the human Dao.

Next, one must abstain from wine and meat, from sensual pleasures, jealousy, killing, extravagance, greed, arrogance, and indulgence.

Next, one must avoid the five pungent vegetables, which harm life and stimulate the palate.

Next, one must still all thoughts and perceptions, so the heart beholds the clear and void.

Next, one must practice grain avoidance, uphold the great precepts, maintain firm resolve and diligent aspiration, engage in guiding and embryonic breathing, exhale and inhale harmoniously, and cultivate merit and virtue.

The pursuit of immortal arts is urgent; uphold the precepts to restrain the heart. With emptiness and equanimity, the correct qi resides within, and immortals and sages naturally come seeking you.

If one does not believe these teachings, why dwell in the mountains and forests?
The great worthies delight in the scriptures and precepts,
Receiving them as treasures for the body.
Those who begin their studies always regret being late,
Those who cultivate themselves lament not starting sooner.
This is the time to uncover the hidden and abstruse,
Yet in a flash, the years have grown old.
Grasping the scrolls, you exhaust your efforts,
Only to face death with bitter remorse.
Thus, in my youth, I abandoned the world to study the Dao.

—Excerpted from *The Cavern-Mysterious Scripture of Settling the Aspiration*

Laozi said: One should hold to the source of superior wisdom, for wisdom does not arise alone. It must respond to conditions, each having its karmic roots from past conduct.

What is heard of destiny and fortune is shared by those on the same path, just as those of the same virtue have roots in virtue. Those who did not study in past lives now again drift apart from it. Thus, success and failure depend on this, and one should not delight solely in the texts of the Dao.

From the *Scripture of Western Ascension*:

The Most High Lord of the Great Dao said: The arts of internal alchemy governing the bedchamber, the benefits of the Yellow Way and Red Qi in union, the essentials of seven-nine morning refinement and seminal absorption, the methods of Six-One Reverted Elixir and yin-yang interplay—though these may confer the name of immortality, the Upper Clarity does not deem them comparable to virtue; though they may achieve transformation, the Most High does not hold them in esteem. These are the defiled immortals and turbid perfected ones, inherently unworthy to pass through the Jade Gate.

Moreover, treading treacherous ice is often seen to end in overturned chariots. Even those who survive intact remain but foul and disordered earthbound immortals.

---

From the *Supreme Cavern-Real Scripture of Wisdom and Dispelling Demons*:

The Pure Numinous Perfected One said: The Way of Yellow and Red, the method of mixed qi—these are but one technique taught by Zhang Daoling to propagate his lineage, not the work of true perfected ones. I have seen many who practiced this and perished without descendants, yet none who cultivated it and attained life. Among millions, all have been examined and found wanting. Among ten million, perhaps one may errantly succeed, achieving a distant semblance of deathlessness. Zhang Daoling transmitted this to teach the world, yet even his own transformations did not rely upon it. Beware the defiled ways of base existence, for they corrupt the upright qi of the True Empyrean. Those who harbor lustful desires, fix their minds on sensual visions, and yet claim to practice the supreme Way only clarify the penalties of the Three Palaces—like bearing jade into fire or interring a dog in a golden coffin. The "Yellow and Red" refers to sensual visions; the "supreme Way" to the Hidden Writ. How few comprehend this!

The Lady of Purple Tenuity said: The Yellow Writ and Red Realm, though secret essentials of long life, are but inferior arts of attaining existence, not to be spoken of by those who feast in the Upper Palace with the Heavenly Perfected. This Way lies merely in nurturing and generating life, not in the supreme Dao. Those who harbor lustful qi while practicing the Hidden Writ only shake the brush of the Three Officials, sound the drums of the Three Officials—even the Mysterious Staff cannot be relied upon, nor can liberation be trusted. In short: purity invites numinous descent; devotion commands spirit aid.

---

The Lady of Right Florescence said: Those who study the Dao must focus single-mindedly on the Dao and infuse the true, free from scattered thoughts. Cast off extravagance, preserve simplicity and purity. Be still as though secretly perceiving, rarefied as though subtly attaining. Tremble as if standing at a deep ravine, quake as if treading upon ice and embers. This is but the gate of attaining the Dao, not yet its inner chamber. What is called difficult is the study of the Dao; what is called easy is also the study of the Dao. In serene mystery and profound savor, preserve harmony with the Heavenly Perfected. Direct the spirit to nest in the numinous, immerse in the study of the Six Repositories. Cherish essence and seal the Gate of Earth, neither seeing nor hearing—this is the ease of the Dao. Those who cannot practice this find it difficult.

---

The Lady of Right Florescence said: From ancient times to the present, life and death have had their ford. Manifest and hidden meet differently; the past is concealed, wisdom extinguished. Those who align with the world in this share in the practice of attaining the Dao. As for those who refine the Jade Elixir once, soar thrice with the Nine Flowers, savor cloud-liquor at dawn, wander with flowing yellow, swallow golden nectar, and chew jade blossoms—they may instantly command the light and ascend to the void, rising to the Great Tenuity. Yet when worldly affairs diverge and karmic tasks remain unfinished, one must tread the path of the Great Yin, conceal life in the dark realm, relinquish the body and abandon form, nurture the embryo in the empty dwelling, refine qi and seal the crucible, receive essence in the mysterious vastness. Thus, one transforms countenance in the halls of the Three Yin, regains youth at the gates of the Nine Refinements. Only then does one know the marvel of divine immortality—death yet not perishing, the principle of going and coming runs deep.

---

The Lord of Life of the Eastern Minister said: For those who practice the Dao, essence is sufficient. With essence but no diligence, nothing can be achieved; with diligence but no focus, nothing can be accomplished. One must dissolve stinginess and scatter defilement. The Lord of Fixed Records said: To distance the inner and betray the heart is to lose the true nature of the Three Hun. Once the true is scattered, the hun seize the opening. Those who practice the Dao must make the inner heart as clear as a mirror, harmonizing the inner and outer like notes in resonance. The numinous responds within, the spirit descends without—this is no empty claim.

---

The Lady of Mysterious Clarity said: Practicing the Dao is like wood upon water: carried by the current, it neither strikes the left bank nor the right, is neither taken by men nor blocked by ghosts and spirits, nor does it rot. I guarantee it will reach the sea. If one practices the Dao without being deluded by defiled desires or deceived by manifold evils, advancing without doubt, I guarantee they will attain the Dao.

---

The Candidate of Fixed Records said: Those who practice the Dao should always wander alone in profound tranquility, nest the spirit in leisurely roaming, drink and peck in contentment, seek nothing from the snares of the world. Joy and sorrow thus depart forever, and the Gate of Early Death will have no way to approach. Each abides in their destined dwelling, each nature possesses its own harmony. How can one tread the crooked paths of things and distort one’s rightful work? Why not follow the utmost traces of Heaven’s banner, seek the inner joy of the true, follow seclusion to gladden the heart, grasp one’s refuge to settle the mind, dwell on Eastern Mountain to conceal one’s tracks, hold the mysterious snare on the wondrous peak, preserve the Sui Pearl to contain illumination, and dispel the Five Difficulties from the heart?

---

The Lord of Life said: Practicing the Dao should keep the Three Passes ever harmonized—this is the way to accumulate essence and strengthen the bones. The Three Passes are: the mouth as the Heavenly Pass, the feet as the Earthly Pass, and the hands as the Human Pass. When the Three Passes are harmonized, the Five Viscera are at peace, and the entire body remains free of illness.

---

The Lady of Purple Prime instructed: Practicing the Dao is like holding fire and entering a dark room—the darkness vanishes, and only light remains. Cultivating the Dao and preserving rectitude, ignorance dissipates, and rectitude endures.

---

The Most High questioned Daoling: How long does a person’s life last?
One replied: A matter of days.

The Most High said: You have not yet grasped the Dao.
One replied: A person’s life lies between eating and drinking.
The Most High said: You may leave; this is not the Dao.
Another replied: It lies between each breath.
The Most High said: Excellent! This may indeed be called the Dao. I once heard these words, and now I tell them to you. If you diligently study the Dao, you may yet transcend this breath. Though my disciples may be thousands of miles away, if their hearts hold fast to my precepts, they will surely attain the Dao. Those who delve deeply into the Jade Classics and treasure scriptures will attain immortality. As for those who stand at my left side, their intentions incline toward perverse conduct—they will never attain the Dao.

To practice the Dao through scripture and action is like tasting honey: the entire mouth is sweet, the six palaces are filled with delight, and a lingering savor remains. Those who can act thus have attained the Dao.

—From the *Zhen Gao*

The Perfected of Pure Numinosity, expounding the *Scripture of Treasured Spirits*, said: To fix the heart upon the true Dao and mystically contemplate the numinous ones in profound stillness is also to reflect upon one’s intent. If external obstacles have not yet been cast aside, and one clings to both the illusory and the real, they cannot reverse the years beneath the western elm nor restore the hair of the Mystic Youth. Yet if one is devoted to the profound with unwavering resolve, even if their teeth are carved with age, their face lined with wrinkles, and white blossoms sprout upon their crown, my Dao can transform them into an infant in but a moment. The question lies only in the strength of their resolve—age is no barrier to learning the Dao. I am such a person.

—From the *Scripture of Daoist Traces*

*Supreme Secret Essentials*, Scroll Forty-Two—End
*Supreme Secret Essentials*, Scroll Forty-Three
**On Daoist Robes and Headgear**
**The Three Sovereigns’ Ritual Attire for Daoist Adepts**

**From the *Scripture of the Three Sovereigns of the Cavernous Divine (Dongshen Sanhuang Jing)*:**
When the body of one who receives the Dao exchanges worldly garments, its adornments and designations become "ritual vestments." Some may wear robes of the three colors—mystic black, azure, and white—as prescribed, storing within them the *qi* of *jiazi*, *jiayin*, and *jiashen* to fortify the body’s form. A mystic black cap and black headscarf, an azure-green unlined robe, and straw sandals of white *mang* grass are called ritual vestments. When one attains the Dao and ascends to heaven, embroidered robes will come of their own accord.

For those who study all Three Caverns, coarse hempen skirts and unlined robes may be worn together, along with wooden clogs and headscarves, all permissible for use.

**Ritual Vestments of the Numinous Treasure Daoist**
*From the *True One Scripture of the Cavernous Mystery’s Natural Essentials (Dongxuan Zhenyi Ziran Jingjue)*:*
The Perfected of the Great Ultimate said: When receiving the Dao and holding the scriptures, one wears ritual robes, headscarves, and hempen garments. The hempen robes should each be three feet and six inches long, with thirty-two seams. If deerhide is used for the headscarf and robe, it is most excellent; leather robes have no fixed number of seams. They are paired with yellow skirts. Straw sandals are worn on the feet, though leather shoes may also be used.

*From the *Hidden Commentaries on the Scripture of the Great Ultimate of the Cavernous Mystery (Dongxuan Taiji Yin Zhu Jing)*:*
The commentary states: When reciting scriptures while seated on a small dais, five feet in height and equal in length and breadth, one wears a deerhide headscarf and drapes a deerhide mantle, with no need for a hempen robe. If no hide is available, a cloth mantle may be used, along with straw sandals.

When the Perfected of the Great Ultimate reads the scriptures, their ritual vestments consist of a mantle woven from nine-light brocade of *li* silk, a headscarf of cinnabar-red *luo* silk adorned with jeweled radiance, and shoes embroidered with lion patterns. When a Daoist recites scriptures and toils diligently in ritual affairs, they wear a deerhide mantle. After attaining the Dao, the Heavenly Emperor bestows upon them a nine-light *li* silk mantle, celestial jeweled tassels, and the flying immortal’s ritual vestments as reward for their virtuous merit.

**From the *Lower Scroll of the Scripture of Questions to the Cavernous Mystery (Dongxuan Qingwen Jing Xia)*:**
Those who study the Dao must always keep their clothing pure and secluded, burn incense, arrange a high seat, display the scriptures, bow in reverence, concentrate the mind to visualize the Perfected, practice breath refinement and nurturing, repent for the transgressions of seven generations of parents as well as past and present heavy wrongs, perform acts of charity, establish merit, maintain long-term fasting and seclusion, and stabilize their original vows. Only when the heart is empty and the intent profound can the Dao be achieved.

One must properly prepare headscarves, hempen robes, unlined skirts, and recitation mantles. The ritual system forbids lending them to others or wearing them in impure places. Such are called "ritual vestments," and three divine youths always attend them. Once, a virtuous man invited a Daoist, but the Daoist could not go and instead sent his mantle and robe. Upon arriving at the man’s home, the man reverently burned incense and paid homage as if the Daoist were present. The divine youths appeared in visible form, saying: "The Daoist sent us." The host did not realize they were divine youths. Any illness in the household was immediately cured, and the family remained free of misfortune. The divine youths told the host: "The sick have recovered; the Daoist need not trouble himself to come. You may return the ritual vestments to him." The host followed their words and returned them to the Daoist.

The host asked: "Yesterday, I suffered greatly from illness and invited you to a feast. Though you were occupied with many affairs, you sent a messenger, yet you never came to visit. Now the sick have recovered, and I return your ritual vestments." The Daoist was astonished. After listening, he replied: "This poor Daoist had to complete a ritual before going, and the virtuous man did not come again. Thus, I did not go—it was not a breach of trust. I had no one to send, nor did I know your household’s illness had been cured. This must have been due to the host’s wholehearted devotion."

The Daoist asked: "What did the messenger look like?"
The host replied: "About fifteen or sixteen years old, with a dignified and handsome appearance, surpassing all others."
The Daoist pondered: "I have no disciples like that. It must have been a divine being." Thus, ritual vestments must always be kept pure and made according to proper methods. Otherwise, ghosts may harm people instead. If they become damaged, one must wear them oneself and not use them for other purposes.

**From the *Scripture of Ascending Mystery (Shengxuan Jing)*:**
There was an immortal named Dou Ziming who wore a yellow hempen robe and a mystic black headscarf. He bowed in reverence, circled the Most High seven times, and chanted praises.

**Ritual Vestments of the Highest Clarity Daoist**
*From the *Bright Regulations of the Four Poles of the Cavernous Perfection (Dongzhen Siji Mingke)*:*
When studying the thirty-nine chapters of the *Highest Clarity Scripture of the Great Cavern* and entering the chamber, one must wear ritual vestments: a headscarf of deerhide (or kudzu cloth), and a mantle of deerhide. If purple and azure are unavailable, purple may be used for the robe and azure for the lining. The mantle should be four feet and nine inches wide to correspond to the number of the four seasons, and five feet and five inches long to align with the *qi* of heaven and earth. The outer and inner layers follow the same method: the outer should have twenty-four seams, the lining fifteen, totaling thirty-nine seams inside and out to correspond to the positions of the thirty-nine Perfected Emperors, thus matching the imperial vestments of the crown and sash.

If one lacks these vestments, the precious scriptures must not be casually recited. A single chant will resound through the Nine Heavens, and the Nine Perfected will attend in their positions—such a response is not to be taken lightly. If one recites the scriptures in a single unlined robe, demonic forces will penetrate the Nine Heavens, myriad spirits will disrupt the sound, the spirit will perish, the *qi* will scatter, and one will die and enter the dark springs, never to attain immortality.

Those who possess these vestments are attended by two jade lads and two jade maidens, who guard and serve the Perfected. They must not be lent to others. If one is clad in the imperial vestments but lacks this resonance, or treats the divine garments with irreverence, five transgressions will leave no hope of immortality, and ten transgressions will result in punishment by the Left Bureau.

For women studying the *Highest Clarity* method of ascending to heaven in broad daylight, receiving the *Numinous Treasure Jade Instructions*, and soaring through the *Great Cavern*, they will all assume the rank of Lady of the Primordial Sovereign. On the day of entering the chamber, they must wear the Lady’s vestments: a hempen robe of purple gauze, two zhang and four chi in length, with sleeves cut short to fit. The robe should have sixteen seams on the sleeves and twenty-two on the body. They must also make a skirt of azure gauze, forty-five chi in length, with eight panels, each four feet and nine inches long. The remaining fabric is used for the waistband, dividing the eight panels into thirty-two seams. This is the "flying azure skirt," the vestment of the Lady.

When one dons these vestments, the myriad spirits will gird their sashes, and the thousand demons will vanish. Twelve jade lads and twelve jade maidens will be assigned to attend and safeguard the ritual vestments.

Without these vestments, one may not chant the precious scriptures of the Supreme Clarity. Should one lightly use ordinary garments to recite the supreme scriptures, celestial demons will invade one’s voice, spirits will scatter, and qi will disperse—thus attaining immortality becomes impossible.

From the *Regulations for Reading Scriptures* in the *Scripture of True Traces*:
The records state: Jade lads and jade maidens who attend the scriptures, along with those who oversee Daoist practitioners of the written Way, report merits and expose transgressions, which are heard by the Primordial Masters of the Mysterious Center in the Supreme Clarity. Grave offenses incur punishment from the Three Officials; minor offenses strip one’s life-record and shorten one’s years. Major sins bring calamity upon the three generations of ancestors; minor sins confine misfortune to the self. Disrespect causes spirits to depart; defilement causes scriptures to withdraw. Those who study immortality—when unfolding sacred texts, they must rise, bow, and burn incense. The celestial spirits oversee and inspect: how could one not be reverent and cautious?

All who have not received transmission may not recklessly speak even a single line or character, for to do so violates the statutes against leaking celestial writings.

From the *Scripture of the Yellow Plain of the Cavern-Realms’ Forty-Four Methods*:
Whenever a Daoist, having received the supreme methods, wishes to recite scriptural texts, upon unfurling the scroll, they must first burn incense, bow in devotion before the scripture, and click their teeth five times. Then they softly recite the incantation:
*"Supreme laws of the Jade Emperor, heard on high by the Three Clarities.
On this auspicious day of fasting, I dare to open the divine scripture.
Ten thousand trials conceal and submit; all endeavors shall succeed.
Jade lads attend and guard; jade blossoms scatter fragrance.
I report above to the Three Primes, granting me long life."*
Only after completing the incantation may one open the scripture and proceed to recite it. Minor offenses strip one’s life-record; minor sins confine misfortune to the self. This is called the method of the Great Emperor for opening scriptures, commanding jade lads and jade maidens to attend and guard, burning incense to invoke and welcome the divine spirits, and reporting above to the Nine Heavens.

From the *Luminous Statutes of the Four Poles of the Cavern-Realms*:
When scholars enter the chamber to recite scriptures, they must be girded with the sashes of the Five Emperors and assume the floating positions of the Four Controllers. They may not face the scriptures while speaking, nor converse with outsiders. To omit or mangle phrases, to delay the arrival of celestial perfected ones, or to allow thoughts to wander—three such transgressions sever merit and cut off affairs, preventing attainment of immortality; ten transgressions subject the body to punishment by the Left Officials. When entering the chamber to recite scriptures, one must ensure that words and phrases flow in sequence, without skipping or omitting the celestial sounds.

Should a single phrase be lost, one must recite a hundred phrases anew to recover it; should two phrases be lost, two hundred must be recited; should five phrases be lost, five hundred must be recited before proceeding. If a single phrase is missed, recite an entire chapter to make amends. Ten to thirty such transgressions nullify merit and sever affairs, preventing attainment of immortality. Fifty to a hundred transgressions subject one’s seven generations of ancestors and oneself to punishment by the Left and Right Officials—enduring the knife mountains, consuming fire, the twenty-four hells, and the torments of the Three Wastes.

When entering the chamber to recite scriptures, one must fix the gaze upon the text and concentrate the mind upon the perfected deities, without allowing stray thoughts or wayward imaginings to disrupt the celestial sounds. Ten to thirty transgressions nullify merit and sever affairs, preventing attainment of immortality.

When reciting scriptures of a thousand phrases or fewer, one may not consume drink while facing the text; from a thousand to five thousand phrases, one may take a single drink; from five thousand to ten thousand, two drinks; and above ten thousand, three drinks. One may not recklessly consume food or drink to the detriment of the qi-infused recitation. Five to ten transgressions nullify merit and sever affairs, preventing attainment of immortality.

When reciting ten thousand phrases, if exhaustion overwhelms, one may pause briefly to recover, but must thereafter complete the passage in full. Even so, one may not leave unfinished phrases overnight, lest the celestial measure be diminished. Five to ten transgressions nullify merit and sever affairs, preventing attainment of immortality.

When entering the chamber to recite scriptures, if male and female disciples study together, they may share the same room, but must occupy separate beds. When reciting facing north, men should be positioned to the east and women to the west, without mingling seats, rising, reclining, or resting together. Three transgressions sever merit and nullify affairs, preventing attainment of immortality; five transgressions subject the body to punishment by the Left Officials.

When reciting the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Perfected Scripture*, the *One Hundred Spirit Treasures of the Cyclical Wind and Primordial Union*, the *Jade Tallies and Feminine One: Five Elders’ Treasure Scripture*, the *Wondrous Scripture of the Great Profundity of Primordial Numinosity*, the *Concealed Writ of the Great Elixir*, or the texts of the Highest Perfected Ones, one must face north, bow in reverence to the four directions, knock the teeth thirty-six times, swallow saliva thirty-six times, and visualize within the five viscera the generation of five-colored qi, which infuses the essence of the Five Stars. Only then may one first recite the *Seven Cycles of the Divine Continent*, followed by the *Inner Names of the Hundred Spirits*, before proceeding to the *Great Cavern Perfected Scripture*. When reciting, mind and gaze must align, without stray thoughts or wayward imaginings to disturb the true deities. One must complete every phrase in full; to pause midway or skip phrases is to be seized by the Left Officials—three transgressions prevent attainment of immortality.

When reciting the *Thirty Scrolls of the Precious Scripture of the Highest Clarity* and its independent oral instructions, one must face north, bow in reverence to the four directions, knock the teeth twenty-four times, swallow saliva twenty-four times, and visualize the threefold essence of the Five Stars, sun, and moon infusing one’s body. Only then may one recite the scripture and perform the rites, ensuring that mind and mouth align without stray thoughts. One must unfurl the scroll and complete every phrase in full, without pausing or omitting any. Three transgressions prevent attainment of immortality; five transgressions subject one’s seven generations of ancestors, parents, and oneself to seizure by the Left and Right Officials.

When reciting the *Scriptures of the Numinous Treasure*, whether the *Cavern Profundity* or *Ascending Profundity*, one must face east, knock the teeth twelve times, swallow saliva twelve times, bow twice, and visualize the qi of purple clouds covering one’s crown and body. Only then may one recite, ensuring that mind and gaze align, without allowing the eyes to wander or the mind to entertain stray thoughts. One must unfurl the scroll and complete every phrase in full, without pausing or omitting the celestial sounds. Three transgressions utterly prevent attainment of immortality; five or more subject one to punishment by the Left Officials.
