Observing the precepts of the body—from the Five Precepts to the one hundred eighty precepts on the Way of ruler and minister, father and child—is called the *Lower Prime Precepts of Jade Purity’s Wisdom*.

**Middle Prime Precepts of Jade Purity**
The Dao student must not expect others’ reverence;
The Dao student must not secretly copy others’ scriptures or precepts.

The Dao student must not adorn or embellish their clothing;
The Dao student must not ascend the high seat to recite scriptures with an unclean body;
When walking together, the Dao student must yield precedence to others;
When studying with others in summer, the Dao student must tend the stove and prepare food;
When studying with others in winter, the Dao student must carry the vessel and provide water;
When eating with others, the Dao student must partake of coarse fare and vegetables;
When eating with others, the Dao student must eat only what is directly before them;
When studying with others, the Dao student must honor those more advanced than themselves;
When dwelling with others, the Dao student must submit to their arrangements;
When studying with others, the Dao student must reflect on teachings and explanations;
When studying with others, the Dao student must inquire of those more advanced;
If others treat the Dao student with malice, the Dao student must accept it without resentment;
The Dao student must not harbor resentment or seek retribution against others;
When speaking with women, the Dao student must not gaze directly at their faces but respond with restrained composure;
When crossing water with others, the Dao student must not stare directly at them;
If the Dao student loses something, they must not suspect fellow students or others;
If the Dao student loses something, they must accept fate and repent of their many transgressions;
When afflicted with many illnesses or misfortunes, the Dao student must reflect humbly and reproach themselves, resolving to amend past errors and cultivate future virtue;
The Dao student must endure what others cannot endure;
The Dao student must relinquish what others cannot relinquish;
The Dao student must wear what others cannot wear;
The Dao student must eat what others cannot eat;
The Dao student must study what others cannot study;
The Dao student must tolerate what others cannot tolerate;
The Dao student must accept what others cannot accept;
The Dao student must sever what others cannot sever;
The Dao student must not allow their spirit to drift or their true thoughts to become obstructed due to lack of scriptural practice;
If the Dao student’s body is unclean, their hun and po souls will depart;
If the Dao student harbors intentions, the celestial perfected will ascend beyond reach, and demonic officials will not submit;
If the Dao student has a household, the Three Poisons will not be extinguished, and the Three Perfected will not reside;
If the Dao student has a body, myriad desires will not depart, and concentrated thought will yield no response;
The Dao student must empty the heart and still the mind, abiding in tranquility to face the true;
The Dao student must peacefully guard the mysterious spring, preventing reckless movement from generating the primordial;
The Dao student must extinguish perceptions and conceal views, then the Perfected Ones will appear.

Observing the precepts of the body—from the fifth to the two hundred sixteen precepts of the supreme, perfectly true Dao—is called the *Middle Prime Precepts of Jade Purity’s Wisdom*.

**Upper Prime Precepts of Jade Purity**
The Dao student must regard plain food as their constant fare;
The Dao student must prioritize delivering others before delivering themselves;
The Dao student must dwell in secluded mountains and forests to concentrate their thoughts;
The Dao student must remain tireless in studying scriptures and practicing the Dao despite poverty;
The Dao student must burn fragrant incense to perfume the heavens and penetrate demonic realms;
The Dao student must, when among the worthy, listen and receive sublime teachings;
The Dao student must earnestly receive the Three Treasures and the cavernous scriptures, diligently making offerings;
The Dao student must establish merit by delivering others, persevering without weariness;
The Dao student must repay the fundamental kindness of teachers and friends throughout the kalpas without fail;
The Dao student must wish for tranquility in the realm, the king’s transformation to be harmonious, and the absence of unrighteousness;
The Dao student must wish for neighboring realms to be governed by the Dao, each maintaining their borders;
The Dao student must pray for the well-being of the people, that they may always be secure and whole;
The Dao student must prioritize all beings, not seeking the Dao solely for themselves;
The Dao student must keep distant from spirits, neither revering nor slighting them;
The Dao student must keep distant from heterodox arts and taboo practices;
The Dao student must keep distant from music, sensuality, singing, and dancing;
The Dao student must keep distant from those who hastily imitate ghostly speech or propagate demonic falsehoods;
The Dao student must honor the root and guard the true;
The Dao student must ensure their words do not betray their heart, nor their heart betray their form;
The Dao student must not doubt or alter the sacred texts or the regulations of the Dharma;
The Dao student must be free from seeking and desire;
The Dao student must maintain purity and guard the true;
The Dao student must harbor no stray thoughts, abiding only in emptiness and stillness;
The Dao student must wish for every household to be peaceful and free from suffering;
The Dao student must contemplate those in the world who are distressed, bound by sin, and afflicted by suffering;
The Dao student must wish for the Son of Heaven to be sagely and expansive in the Dao, with the royal house flourishing daily;
The Dao student must wish for the ministers to assist and protect, perpetually upholding the Dao;
The Dao student must wish for the heavens and earth, sun and moon, wind and rain, and snowfall to be timely;
The Dao student must reflect on the causes and conditions by which parents raised them;
The Dao student must reflect on their seven generations of ancestors who have not ascended to heaven;
The Dao student must reflect on their teacher who has not yet ascended and been delivered;
The Dao student must reflect on their fellow students who have not yet fathomed the profound depths and canonical subtleties of the Dao;
The Dao student must reflect on guiding like-minded companions to teach and lead one another into the true Dao;
The Dao student must not deviate from the texts they recite;
The Dao student must regard others’ parents as their own parents;
The Dao student must regard others’ children as their own children;
The Dao student must regard others’ bodily faults as their own;
The Dao student must regard others’ bodily injuries and pains as their own;
The Dao student must regard others’ humiliations and malice as worse than their own;
The Dao student must reflect on the severance of their karmic roots from past lives;
The Dao student must reflect on the extinction of their womb-root, never to be reborn in the world or share karmic bonds with kin;
The Dao student must reflect on the withering of their tree of life, their spirit merging with the Great Void, their body uniting with the true through countless kalpas;
The Dao student must reflect on the sealing of the three paths, the eternal cessation of hell;
The Dao student must reflect on taking the middle meal to nourish the spirit, abandoning rich and greasy foods;
The Dao student must be cautious in upholding the great Dharma, constantly preserving the primordial cinnabar child of the Three Palaces;
The Dao student must observe the world with harmonious light, without affecting eccentricity;
The Dao student must protect the Three Treasures and the precepts of the scriptures, reciting them without seeking repayment;
The Dao student must preserve the feminine unity, recite the *Great Cavern Scripture*, and appear as though facing the divine;
The Dao student must ascend as an immortal to deliver the world, riding clouds and driving dragons;
The Dao student must yearn to see their teachers, friends, and fellow students;
The Dao student must yearn to see Perfected Ones and Daoists practicing the Dharma;
The Dao student must yearn to see sagely kings governing the world, with those beyond the seas bowing in submission and riding the wind to transform;
The Dao student must yearn to partake of the celestial kitchen’s natural repast, free from hunger or thirst.

The Dao student must yearn to commune with Heavenly Perfected Ones in serene non-action;
The Dao student must yearn to command jade lads and jade maidens;
The Dao student must yearn to journey eastward through the Azure Forest and the Tied Blossoms;
The Dao student must yearn to journey westward through the Land of Peace and Nourishment and the Western Blossoms;
The Dao student must yearn to journey northward through the Azure Net and the Northern Blossoms;
The Dao student must yearn to journey southward through the Great Cinnabar and the Southern Blossoms;
The Dao student must yearn to roam and linger in Qin, the Central Flower of Mount Sumeru and Kunlun;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through lecture halls and study chambers, where the sagely Dao is expounded and profound mysteries unfurled;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Golden Portals of Highest Clarity, paying homage to the Perfected Ones and the Great Elder;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Seven Jeweled Palaces of Jade Clarity, paying homage to the Three Heavenly Worthies;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Cinnabar Rosy Clouds Palace of Jade Clarity, paying homage to the Twenty-Four Lofty Sages of the Most High;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Seven Jeweled Flowing Terrace, shaded by the Jade Capital Grove of the Most High’s Jade Capital, paying homage to the Heavenly Worthy and the Ten Directions’ Great Sages, who endure through kalpas from end to beginning;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Purple Cloud Palace, paying homage to the Thirty-Nine Lofty Sages of Cavern Reality;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Thirty-Six Heavens’ Yellow Gold Palaces, paying homage to the Heavenly Emperors;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Nine Heavens’ Yellow Gold Radiance Palace, paying homage to the Heavenly Emperors;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the palaces of all heavens, discoursing on the Dao and debating scriptures with the Heavenly Emperors;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Six Heavens’ Seven Jeweled Palaces, beholding the Great Demon Kings as they inspect my register of deliverance, allowing entry into the immortal ranks and eternal departure from the ledgers of the Yellow Springs;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the palaces of the Sun and Moon, resplendent with radiant brilliance, paying homage to the Sun and Moon Kings and drinking the golden liquid of solar and lunar essence;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Flowing Light Palace of the Great Brahma Heaven, paying homage to the Heavenly Emperor and listening to the celestial hymns of the heavens, surpassing all earthly refinement;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Seven Jeweled Groves of all heavens, where reverse-born divine incense wafts fragrance against the wind, perceptible three thousand leagues away, where lions and flying dragons roar and cry amidst them;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the bathing pools of all heavens, seated upon lotus blossoms, naturally pure and fragrant, flowing through all heavens—hundreds and thousands of pools as one, each person joyous and content;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through all heavens, listening to the celestial musicians, free from worldly thoughts;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the outer heavens of the ten directions, paying homage to the Great Sage Assemblies and the Supreme Perfected Ones;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the Boundless Vajra Heavenly Palaces below, paying homage to the Nine Elder Perfected Ones;
The Dao student must yearn to wander through the renowned mountains and hidden grottoes of heaven and earth, paying homage to the sagely ones who first attained the Dao;
The Dao student must yearn to regard the heart as the Dao, forever free from heterodox views and stray thoughts, ever keeping the heart empty and the mind at ease, without thought or worry, tranquil and serene in emptiness;
The Dao student must yearn to conceal the secret names and taboos of the Heavenly Perfected Ones, never uttering them from my mouth.

Observe the precepts of the body from the fifth to the three hundredth, the Dao of the Most High’s Boundless, named the *Highest Jade Clarity Wisdom Upper Prime Precepts*.

**The Cavern Reality Wisdom Observing the Body Great Precepts Scripture**

The Heavenly King of Original Beginning said: The *Highest Cavern Reality Wisdom Scripture* is not proclaimed to worldly scholars; it is mostly transmitted to those who have already become Perfected Ones. What is seen is difficult to see; having seen it, it is difficult to exhaust. Thus, it is rarely seen in the world.

These precepts are revered and weighty; they cannot be proclaimed in words. By observing the myriad spirits within the human body, the three hundred joints’ true numina are not allowed to recklessly depart, and demonic trials cannot violate them. Those who receive and recite these precepts without transgressing their prohibitions may ascend as immortals without study. Azure clouds and jade chariots will naturally welcome you; at dawn, you will ascend to heaven, your body floating in the empty void, roaming freely through the ten directions. A halo will appear around your neck, radiant and luminous in the Great Emptiness. The hosts of heavenly sages will have no choice but to revere and look up to you.

At that time, the Great Demon Kings of the Six Heavens will immediately elevate those who uphold the precepts, reporting their names to the Eastern Flower Palace, which will report them to the Great Brahma Heaven Palace, and the Great Brahma Heaven Palace will report them to the Jade Capital Golden Portals, where they will be inscribed among the ranks of the highest immortals.

The Heavenly King of Original Beginning said: The *Great Cavern Reality Scripture* states that chanting it ten thousand times will summon cloud chariots to descend and welcome you. The *Numinous Treasure Cavern Mystery Scripture* contains passages on transcending kalpas, yet those who cultivate it may still fail to become immortals, and those who compound the golden elixir and numinous medicines may still fail to succeed. Why is this? It is because they have not received and upheld the *Wisdom Observing the Body Precepts*.

These precepts are the most wondrous of wonders, their majestic spirit supremely revered. Nine hundred Golden Flower Immortals stand in attendance, burning incense. This is the true secret Dao, not transmitted in writing but only through recitation and chanting.

Those who study the Dao but do not receive these precepts will never attain immortality. Some may create karmic obstacles and fall into sensual pleasures; some may begin diligently but grow lax in the end; some may enter mountains or dwell at home, only to be tested and defeated by demonic forces; some may harbor heterodox thoughts and doubt the true scriptures; some may return to worldly ways, losing all Daoist resolve; some may slight their teachers and friends, insulting their fellow students; some may suddenly become mad or foolish, their nature and qi inverted, growing greedy for wealth and enamored of beauty, even belittling the Three Treasures. Some may encounter misfortune in their family circumstances, with grievances and hardships converging; some may suffer from nightmares and chaotic thoughts, their spirits troubled and melancholy. All these afflictions arise from lacking the great precepts to govern their body and spirit, allowing the Three Poisons and floating corpses to disturb the five viscera.

The Demon Kings will not erase the names of the dead from the ledgers of the Yellow Springs; those who do not transcend the Three Realms will not enter the immortal ranks.

The Heavenly King of Original Beginning said: These precepts were revealed through numinous immortals, and now all heavenly beings, earthly immortals, and renowned mountain sages uphold and practice them. On every new and full moon, the eight seasonal nodes, one’s birthdays, and the celestial fast days, fellow students, teachers, and friends should enter the chamber to recite the precepts once through. First, pay homage to the ten directions, bowing once to each.

When the heavens hear the sound of the precepts being recited, all will bow in reverence. Disciples who wish to uphold them should offer five taels of superior gold as a token to the Five Emperors, and ten bolts of cinnabar brocade as a pledge to the ten directions.

The covenant of the hairpin’s fall must not leak the precepts’ rules; they are to be offered to a master who holds the precepts. Master and disciple should fast together for three days, contemplating the precepts’ essence. On that evening, light ten lamps to illuminate the ten directions, offering the light to the Great Sages of the ten directions to manifest my heart.

When the celestial qi is harmonious and serene, if at that time wind, rain, thunder, or lightning surge violently, one must not receive the precepts. Instead, fast anew and recompose oneself with reverence, for at such a moment the spirit scatters and the mind dissipates.

Upholding the precepts for nine years, the body becomes a candle illuminating itself; the radiance of sun and moon and the essence of cinnabar will naturally arrive. A golden countenance will emerge from within, the complexion of youth will fill the flesh, and divine penetration will extend in all four directions. Ascending to the heights of immortality, one’s virtue will equal that of the Perfected. Moving in and out without obstruction, one may bathe one’s cap tassels in the rushing waters of the pool, loosen one’s robe upon the Terrace of Seven Treasures, and wander beneath the shade of lotus blossoms, returning to the fragrant forest where light shines brilliantly and flourishes. From kalpa to kalpa, one will forever enjoy the truth of the Dao.

On the noon of one’s natal day or at midnight, facing north, recite the *Great Supreme’s Revolving Mystery, Great Chapter*, to penetrate the ten directions. The Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity declares: This precept is called the *Precept of Wisdom Observing the Body*; it is also named the *Scripture of Preserving the Immortal Spirit*, and the *Supreme Cavern-Real Scripture of Delivering Life*. Unless one possesses the accumulated merit of past lives, the blessings of successive karmic deeds, and the extension of felicitous destiny, one will never be permitted to behold this precious secret. Even the name inscribed on the Golden Tablet of the Eastern Flowery Pool will not allow one to encounter such a master. Those who uphold it are destined to become immortals.

To possess scriptures without precepts is like wishing to cross the sea without a boat, or having a mouth without a tongue—how could one ferry across the countless bodies? Students who seek scriptures but do not seek precepts fail to grasp the root of the true essentials, remaining in a long dream without awakening. This is truly a cause for grief! All should measure their capacity to uphold them; if one’s resources suffice for more than one person, to transmit the precepts to another is to leak them. The sin will extend to seven generations of ancestors, and parents will suffer confinement in the dark prisons of hell. The body will tread the Three Wretched Paths, enduring the Five Sufferings and Eight Calamities. From kalpa to kalpa, beginning anew without end, one will revolve through the evil destinies of the Wheel of Transmigration, drifting ever farther from immortality. Debtors and adversaries will meet in due time—each must guard their person well.

The Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity declares: Should anyone dare to eavesdrop on the recitation of the precepts, they will be struck by the evil demons of the world. The calamity that befalls them is certain, without the slightest doubt.

If a disciple upholding the precepts dwells alone in the mountains or a place of dread, strike the Heavenly Drum thirty-four times, and concentrate the mind on the deities of the precepts. The deities of the precepts will encircle and protect them in three layers. Demons, ghosts, and malevolent spirits will not dare approach; blessings and virtue will constantly follow them, and the good spirits of the various heavens will each surround and guard them. Even former debtors and adversaries will generate hearts of compassion.

The Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity declares: When I first began my studies, I only knew to request scriptures and did not know to seek the precepts. Thus, I passed through kalpas of birth and death. The Supreme One pitied my devotion to the Dao, and the Most High took mercy on my unrelenting efforts, revealing to me: “Your studies are ever diligent, yet you do not uphold the *Great Precept of Observing the Body*—how then could you attain immortality?” Thereupon, I prostrated myself beneath the Golden Gates for three thousand days. The Supreme One bestowed upon me the essential precepts, which I upheld and cultivated. Within nine years, cloud chariots came to welcome me, and the Perfected Ones of the Three Realms and the ten directions gathered in the Mysterious Void.

Thus, those who study the Dao must place precepts and regulations first; they are the honored foundation of the Daoist tradition. The method requires recitation until it flows from the mouth, for the ancient sages kept it secret and did not commit it to writing. Even now, it is the same: the true text must not be allowed to leak to the vulgar and common.

The Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity declares: If one studies the Dao without upholding the *Great Precept of Observing the Body*, reciting scriptures ten thousand times and dwelling in seclusion in the mountains, can one truly hope to ascend as an immortal? If one can perfect the precepts within and harmonize one’s light without, one may yet approach the precipice of the numinous standard. It is not that the study of the Dao is difficult—upholding the precepts is difficult! If you can fulfill the precepts completely, I and the ten directions, along with the Supreme One, will ensure your ascension as an immortal.

If one perfects the precepts and recites the precious scriptures, wearing the great talismans, and still does not attain immortality, then there is no path in the world that does not lead to death. What I have spoken is rare to find in the world! In this degenerate age, many cling to fame and superficial glory, seldom revealing the true heart of virtue and the Dao. Thus, the Three Treasures lie obscured, and the sages remain in seclusion. Is the Dao not vast? If one fully receives the precepts, the true sages of the ten directions will naturally appear to you—thus, without study, the Way of immortality is achieved.

These are not empty words—what purpose would empty words serve? I merely pity the aspiring scholars of the world. When the conditions and opportunities align, there may yet be those who can be taught. Strive on, exert yourselves! Once the Way of immortality is accomplished, what joy could compare? Roaming freely in the capital of the Supreme One, wandering at ease in the realm of spontaneity—this is the joy of the Supreme One. Even ten thousand kalpas past cannot begin to describe it, for it truly cannot be expressed in brush and ink.

The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate declares: I once heard the Dao from the Supreme One, who instructed: “To recite the *Three Treasures Cavern Scriptures* without upholding this great precept—how could the myriad wonders of the immortal Way be attained?” Thus, it was spoken only orally and not committed to writing, remaining secluded within the gardens of the Three Treasures. Even those without the auspicious marks of a supreme immortal will never be permitted to see it. Unless one’s seven generations of ancestors have accumulated blessings, their flourishing virtue casting shade, and the karmic conditions of past deeds extending through hidden merit across kalpas, how could one aspire to delight in the *Precept of Observing the Body* of the Supreme One? Those who uphold this precept become the honored masters of the Three Treasures and the foundation of the Supreme One’s great Dharma. The ten directions will revere you in the Cloud Han, and the assembly of immortals will lead you to the Eastern Flowery Pool. You will sit in audience before the heavenly demons, and the Demon King will present your talismanic mandate to the palaces of the Six Heavens of Desire and the Springs and Bends. The Master of Mount Tai and the officials of the Earth Bureau will no longer possess records of your death. Your immortal name will be fixed in the Azure Palace, and you will become a high immortal of the Jade Capital, a Perfected One of the Supreme One.

The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate declares: The essentials of the Dao lie in aligning one’s conduct with the hidden statutes, accumulating goodness within until it is sufficient, and only then can one ascend to the realm of the Great Dao. Those who cannot do this labor in vain amidst the dust and wind, gaining nothing for the length or brevity of their lives.

The Dao resides within me, not in others. Only with compassion, only with love, only with goodness, only with forbearance—practicing these four equalities, one draws near to the Dao.

Those who are diligent and faithful, who embrace stillness, who persevere to the end, who admonish with purity, and who renounce sensuality and wine—these are the six perfections of the Dao, and they place one among the company of the Perfected. Those who endure wrongs without self-justification, who yield virtue to others, who do not covet what others desire, who tolerate the unreasonable and impure, who distance themselves from the unprincipled, who conceal themselves in seclusion, who do not violate their conscience, who do not betray the scriptures and precepts, and who do not recite by rote—these eight capacities make one a companion of goodness.

The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate declares: The precepts as the essence of the Dao are majestic and spiritually wondrous, yet fearing that people may lack the resolve to uphold them, they are kept secret and unwritten. Thus, the chapters of the *Scripture of Wisdom* are never fully revealed to those of shallow learning. Passed down orally from mouth to mouth, how could they be leaked? When the precepts are expounded, devas and humans from the ten directions clasp their hands in reverent listening, while ghosts and spirits bow in homage to what they hear—how could this be taken lightly?

The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate declares: The ancients who cultivated the Dao abided in profound tranquility, their minds free of attachments, their mouths silent, their bodies unadorned. Serene and boundless, utterly still, they sat in forgetfulness of the true Dao, already perfected in effortless dignity, as cloud-borne chariots stood ready to receive them. Some rode the phoenix through the void, some mounted dragons through the heavens, their bodies treading the formless, ascending to the Great Ultimate, their forms moving through the empty expanse without reliance. Thus, their traces could not be seen, the world knew them not, and those who knew them were rare—such rarity was their true value. This is what is meant by "those who align in spirit and covenant become teachers and friends, their words mysterious yet steadfast." This is not the way of high antiquity but a fabrication of later learners.

If a scholar truly wishes to request the precious scriptures, one must carefully observe their character. Once their understanding is thoroughly awakened, they may present themselves before the Most High, make their petition, and receive the text, following its words as the supreme law of the Most High’s mysterious statutes. Without the capacity to uphold the great Dao, how could one presume to violate this, even with the witness of the seven ancestors and the ten directions? One must first reflect deeply: can your body truly uphold this? The three paths of hell, the ten sufferings, the eight calamities—how could these be taken lightly? Contemplating them chills the heart of all worthy and good; vigilance in the precepts brings blessings naturally. To turn against this resolve is to invite misfortune just as naturally. Agony will pierce the body, moment by moment, with no escape—how much worse through endless kalpas?

The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate declares: Though kalpas may end and begin anew, the precepts remain the unchanging Dao, received orally and practiced bodily by the ancients. When the Dao is perfected, one’s traces may be manifest or hidden, leaving later generations unable to fathom their cultivation. Thus, in high antiquity, some attained the Dao by donning robes and sitting in forgetfulness, while the Yellow Emperor cast his cauldrons and was received by a dragon. They could perceive the ten directions with clarity and transcend the three realms. Wang Qiao and Chi Songzi, who rode the purple mist to soar in the celestial courts, were of their kind. Such examples cannot all be recorded—are these not the worthies of whom it is said that they attained immortality without study?

*Concluding the Forty-Fifth Scroll of the Supreme Mysteries*
*Beginning the Forty-Sixth Scroll of the Supreme Mysteries*

The *Ascending Mystery Precepts*: The Five Precepts of Ascending Mystery

The Dao teaches: Sensual indulgence ruins affairs—it must not be practiced. Yet both the wise and foolish, the noble and base of the world share the same desires. Only the Daoist can uphold resolve, firmly adhere to the teachings and precepts, restrain conduct in movement and stillness, and keep the heart from inclining toward depravity. Amidst the snares of love and desire, they never once transgress.

When encountering beauty, profit, glory, or dazzling splendor, they cover their eyes with the precept.
When hearing flattery or slander, or the five tones of music, they seal their ears with the precept.
When presented with delicacies of the eight treasures or sweet and fragrant delicacies, they shut their mouths with the precept.
When coveting wealth, the seven precious gems, or indulging in extreme desires, they subdue their hearts with the precept.
When recalling lewdness, greed, or other vile matters, they break their thoughts with the precept.

Those who practice these five things will cause their seven generations of ancestors to ascend to heaven, where clothing and food arise naturally. Their bodies will attain divine transcendence, ascending at dawn in broad daylight. Even if they undergo liberation through simulated death, they will transform and become perfected. The worthy ones devote themselves to this with utmost sincerity.

If men or women cannot accept and uphold these precepts, refusing to receive and maintain them, nothing can be done for them!

I would rather give a man ten thousand gold than inscribe these words. Daoist Master of the Way’s Descendants must choose carefully to whom they transmit them, and never leak the true scriptures.

The Most High Dao Lord still chants and laments:

What is affliction?
It all arises from within the body.
The eye beholds radiant beauty,
the ear fills with the five tones,
the mouth savors the eight delicacies,
the mind covets wealth and glory,
the will craves lewd acts—
hands and feet carry them out.
Once the five evils do not cease,
judgment appears in the omen of form.
Forever cut off from the Way of life,
the dark soul perishes in the ghostly prison.
When the sentence is complete and one emerges,
there is a person, yet no feeling.
Those who uphold the precepts and do no evil
seal the five gates of the heart.
The eye does not gaze on ornate beauty,
the ear does not gather clamorous sounds,
the mouth does not feast on sweet delicacies,
the mind does not love money and wealth,
the will harbors no lewd imaginings,
hands and feet do not come and go.
When the five evils are stilled and cease,
how can judgment be pronounced?
Forever united with the true Dao,
no longer subject to the ghostly officials.
Merit accumulates from the precepts,
ascending at dawn to the Jade Morning.
The eye treats beauty as an enemy,
initially unwilling even to glance.
The ear treats sound as an enemy,
initially unwilling to desire hearing.
The mouth treats flavor as bitter,
initially unwilling to be tainted.
The mind treats treasure as stone,
initially unwilling to long for it.
The will treats lewdness as a thief,
initially unwilling to share its path.
The feet treat level ground as rugged,
initially unwilling to tread evenly.
These five follow the same road,
initially unwilling to incline toward the perverse.
Those who can be thus
are called rare among the wondrous.
Having penetrated what is rare,
no dregs or stagnation can remain.
The body pure, the spirit at peace,
the Sovereign Unity guards the cinnabar field.
Conduct perfected arises from within,
enabling ascent to the heavens.
The Dao says: Those who uphold the law and practice the Way
must diligently cultivate the body,
must firmly advance with vigor,
must long maintain the precepts,
must solidify focused mindfulness,
must hold fast to truthful contemplation.
Do not fail to preserve the Dao,
banish the perverse, banish delusion,
banish the demonic, banish the false,
banish lewdness, banish desire,
eliminate and discard all wrongs,
embrace the true as your wrapping.
This is to labor first and receive reward later,
to deliver the body and ascend as an immortal.
Focus on the future, not the present moment.

First, one must not be lewd and wanton,
letting the mind dwell on the perverse,
expending spirit and damaging essence,
so that the hun and po cannot be guarded,
the upright qi departs,
and the perverse comes to meet one.

Second, one must not let the temper flare in anger,
causing the heart to surge and rage,
the mouth to vent and raise the voice,
to curse and revile,
shaking heaven and earth.
The spirits do not protect such a person,
the true officials within the body report to the Three Heavens,
recording the name in the register of sins,
making immortality utterly unattainable.

Third, one must not harbor venomous thoughts,
envying others.
Heavenly scribes record it,
earthly officials report it,
the name is entered in the Black Book,
judgment extends to the point of execution.
This is most impermissible to violate,
as it harms even one’s descendants.

Fourth, one must not drink wine to the point of confusion,
defiling and polluting the body,
altering one’s usual nature,
disregarding the precepts,
defying official laws,
disrespecting father and lord,
failing to recognize one’s kin.
Drawn by desire,
the hun and po wail in sorrow,
filth stains the five spirits,
the mouth utters curses and complaints,
one acts perversely and disobediently.
Heaven sends down calamity,
the body suffers misfortune.

Fifth, one must not covet profit and wealth.
In the degenerate age, deception abounds,
human nature is fierce and corrupt.
Sometimes, for the sake of convenience,
one schemes and harms others.
Wealth is the body’s enemy—
what use is wealth?
If one has it but does not hoard it,
one should plant it in the field of blessings.
An empty hall, a pure chamber—
this is called the home of immortals.

These five must not be violated even once,
like treading on perilous ice,
like stepping into a dangerous chamber.
The sentence is certain to be pronounced,
yet one does not awaken to it.
The worthy, whether sitting, rising, lying, or resting,
must deeply use this to admonish themselves!

From the seventh scroll of the *Scripture of Ascending the Mysterious Inner Teachings*, "The Nine Precepts of Ascending the Mysterious."

The Most High addressed Dao Ling, saying: If one aspires to the Dao and seeks to cultivate the Great Vehicle’s teachings, one must delight in the emptiness of the mind, diligently practice and uphold the precepts, and faithfully observe them—thus may the Dao be established and attained. Simply receive and uphold these precepts, practice them with devotion, and I shall dispatch the Guardian Precept Generals and twenty-four mighty spirits to protect and defend you, severing the paths of evil and guiding you to the realm of goodness. In all your actions, you shall encounter auspiciousness, avoid misfortune and calamity, swiftly escape the way of death, and hasten to the attainment of immortality. Comprehending the secrets of emptiness and illuminating the meaning of non-being, you shall surely attain the supreme Dao.

The First Precept states: The body must not indulge in cruelty, recklessness, arrogance, extravagance, or dissipation; nor may it recklessly invite disaster, act with wanton abandon, delight in evil, or commit wrongdoing. Adornment and excess, indulgence in rich and delicate flavors, self-gratification without restraint—these lead one unawares into the eyes of sin. One fails to recognize the magnitude of the body’s transgressions, which cannot be reckoned. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the First Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Second Precept states: The mind must not harbor evil thoughts or intentions, nor entertain illusory or judgmental imaginings. One must not covet gain, blindly pursue profit, or scheme with malicious intent. One must not plot arrogantly, indulge in rich flavors without restraint, or remain unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin. One fails to recognize the boundless magnitude of the mind’s transgressions. One must not personally entertain such thoughts, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Second Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Third Precept states: The mouth must not recklessly speak of good or evil, utter curses or insults, deceive with falsehoods, sow discord with double-tongued words, engage in disputes or estrangement, criticize others’ faults, create strife, or incite harm. One must not spread groundless rumors, peddle the Dao and its teachings, or indulge in singing, chanting, whistling, or sighing. One must not crave fine flavors without restraint, remaining unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin. One fails to recognize the boundless magnitude of the mouth’s transgressions. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Third Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Fourth Precept states: The hands must not kill or harm living beings, including crawling, creeping, or blood-bearing creatures. One must not rob, plunder, steal, or seize what is not one’s own, nor wield weapons to commit unlawful acts. One remains unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin, failing to recognize the immeasurable magnitude of the hands’ transgressions. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Fourth Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Fifth Precept states: The eyes must not gaze upon what is contrary to the Dao, the Dharma, or righteousness—nor upon ostentatious adornments, seductive appearances, or alluring beauty. One must not indulge in lewd or depraved sights, nor covet extravagant treasures. The eyes serve as the mind’s scouts, gathering all manner of misfortune. They invite calamity and poison, drawing transgressions together—all of which originate from the eyes. The mind, eyes, mouth, and hands are the sources of misfortune and the roots of disaster. Every movement becomes the beginning of suffering, the origin of transgressions. The mind, eyes, mouth, and hands are the storehouses of sin—one must not be careless, nor lax, nor negligent, nor indulgent. One remains unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin, failing to recognize the immeasurable magnitude of the eyes’ transgressions. One must proclaim this precept for the eyes, exhorting all beings—how can one guard the eyes? When the mind’s thoughts are unified, illusions vanish; when illusions vanish, intentions cease; when intentions are empty, one enters non-being without attachment, thereby attaining the wisdom of the Dao. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it without fail throughout one’s life—this is the Fifth Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Sixth Precept states: The ears must not listen to the eight tones or the five musical modes, nor to lewd or seductive sounds that bewilder and corrupt the state. One must not indulge in deceptive or perverse music without restraint, remaining unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin. One fails to recognize the magnitude of the ears’ transgressions, which are likewise grave. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Sixth Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Seventh Precept states: The nose must not covet fragrant or foul scents, nor recklessly discern good from evil. One remains unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin, failing to recognize the magnitude of the nose’s transgressions, which are also considerable. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Seventh Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Eighth Precept states: The feet must not tread upon what is contrary to righteousness or the Dharma, nor walk paths of evil or enter depraved or lewd realms. One remains unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin, failing to recognize the magnitude of the feet’s transgressions, which are also considerable. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Eighth Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

The Ninth Precept states: One must not indulge the passions or act recklessly, nor forcibly employ spiritual instruments to attack those one cannot overcome. One must not dissipate essence, scatter spirit, or lose the three qi. One must not let the mind roam unchecked without restraint, remaining unaware of how such actions entangle one in the net of sin, leading to the ruin of one’s clan and lineage. One fails to recognize the immeasurable magnitude of such transgressions. One must not personally violate this precept, nor instruct others to do so. Restrain the mind and uphold the precept, observing it throughout one’s life—this is the Ninth Precept of the Most High, the Supreme, the Great One.

From the ninth scroll of the *Scripture of Ascending the Mysterious Inner Teachings*, "The Wondrous Precepts Chapter."

The Wondrous Ten Precepts Heavenly Worthy declared: Those who receive these ten precepts and cultivate them in accordance with the Dharma shall be protected and defended by the heavenly officials of the ten directions, and shall surely attain the Dao. If, due to the burdens of the world, one cannot fulfill all ten, then observe nine, eight, seven, six, or even five, selecting those one is capable of upholding. Yet even the blessings of the five precepts are beyond reckoning. You must widely exhort all beings—if some, upon hearing this, remain unmoved or disinterested, still, even a single thread of understanding, a partial awakening, may lead them to gradual enlightenment.

From the *Scripture of Mysterious Contemplation and Resolute Aspiration*, "The Ten Virtuous Precepts Chapter":

The First Precept: Do not kill; contemplate the lives of all beings.
The Second Precept: Do not commit adultery or violate the wives of others.
The Third Precept: Do not steal or take wealth that is not rightfully yours.
The Fourth Precept: Do not deceive, distorting right and wrong in debate.
The Fifth Precept: Do not become intoxicated; reflect upon pure conduct.
The Sixth Precept: Foster harmony among clan and kin, without partiality.
The Seventh Precept: Upon witnessing another’s good deeds, rejoice and lend support in spirit.
The Eighth Precept: When seeing another in distress, assist in performing meritorious acts.
The Ninth Precept: Regard others as yourself, with a mind set on non-retaliation.
The Tenth Precept: Toward all who have yet to attain the Dao, harbor no expectations.

From the *Scripture of Mysterious Contemplation*, "The Ten Good Precepts Chapter":

The First Precept: Do not envy those superior to yourself or suppress the worthy and wise.
The Second Precept: Do not drink to excess or indulge in dissipation, defiling the Three Palaces.
The Third Precept: Do not commit adultery with another’s wife or covet sensual pleasures.
The Fourth Precept: Do not abandon or despise the aged, infirm, impoverished, or lowly.
The Fifth Precept: Do not slander the virtuous or undermine fellow disciples.
The Sixth Precept: Do not hoard treasures and refuse to bestow or distribute them.
The Seventh Precept: Do not kill living beings in sacrifice to the demonic gods of the Six Heavens.
The Eighth Precept: Do not dismiss the scriptures as empty or absurd in private discourse.
The Ninth Precept: Do not betray the kindness of your teacher or deceive new disciples.
The Tenth Precept: Maintain equanimity and a single mind, practicing benevolence and filial piety toward all.

In all conduct, one must avoid the Ten Evils and distance oneself from the path of blindness.

From the *Scripture of Mysterious Wisdom*, "The Ten Wisdom Precepts Chapter":

The Ten Evil Precepts:
The First Precept: Do not indulge in wine and lust, giving free rein to insatiable desire.
The Second Precept: Do not secretly harm the world or slander Daoist practitioners.
The Third Precept: Do not disrespect your teacher, neglect the Dharma, or slight the Three Treasures.
The Fourth Precept: Do not steal scriptures or recklessly expound the essentials of the Dao.
The Fifth Precept: Do not borrow and fail to return, or deceive and mislead the people.
The Sixth Precept: Do not kill living beings for the sake of taste, or speak falsely while harboring deceit.
The Seventh Precept: Do not be unfilial, betray kindness, violate righteousness, or transgress the precepts.
The Eighth Precept: Do not recite scriptures carelessly, belittling them with arrogance.
The Ninth Precept: Do not demand compliance with your wishes or harbor resentment toward the four classes of beings.
The Tenth Precept: Do not alter the teachings of the scriptures, adding or omitting from the sacred texts; do not deny past lives, indulge in selfish desires, defile the Four Great Elements, or neglect the path of rebirth.

The Heavenly Worthy declared:
The First Precept: Let the heart harbor no malice or jealousy, give rise to no hidden harm, guard the mouth to avoid transgressions, and fix thoughts upon the Dharma.
The Second Precept: Uphold chastity and yield to life, show compassion to all beings, extend boundless mercy, and bestow blessings upon all.
The Third Precept: Uphold chastity and yield to righteousness, neither lust nor steal, ever practice compassionate thoughts, and sacrifice oneself to aid others.
The Fourth Precept: Neither indulge in sensuality nor desire, let the heart remain unscattered, preserve purity and caution, and ensure conduct is unstained.
The Fifth Precept: Let the mouth utter no evil words, speak no ornate or deceitful language, maintain integrity within and without, and commit no transgressions of speech.
The Sixth Precept: Reduce wine and moderate conduct, harmonize qi and temperament, prevent harm to the spirit, and avoid all evils.
The Seventh Precept: Do not envy those who surpass you, contend for fame and merit, yield in all matters, and withdraw to deliver others.
The Eighth Precept: Do not criticize or slander scriptures and sacred texts, but wholeheartedly uphold the Dharma, ever as though in the presence of the divine.
The Ninth Precept: Do not engage in quarrels or disputes, nor judge the four classes of beings; lest heaven and humanity resent you, and your spirit and qi be harmed.
The Tenth Precept: In all actions and deeds, maintain equanimity and single-mindedness, harmonizing people and pacifying spirits, ever thus in conduct.

The Twelve Permissible Precepts of *Dongxuan Wisdom*
The Heavenly Worthy said: Those who study, perform purification rites, and seek the Dao to deliver heaven and humanity, and to perform all virtuous deeds, should observe the Twelve Permissible Precepts.
The First: Upon encountering true scriptures that reveal the Dharma and deliver all beings, one should awaken the Dao-mind, aspiring to attain great sageliness in future lives.
The Second: Ever practice a compassionate heart, wishing all beings to encounter the Dharma, to be broadly delivered without hindrance or obscurity.
The Third: Delight in the scriptures and teachings, deeply comprehend and master them, with firm and luminous resolve, to enlighten the ignorant and benighted.
The Fourth: Reverently receive the master’s instructions, broadly exhort and transform others, guiding them into the Dharma-gate and far from blind paths.
The Fifth: Believe in and turn toward the profound and wondrous, reverently uphold the scriptures and their secrets, reciting them morning and evening without laziness or weariness.
The Sixth: Do not pursue glory and splendor, sever worldly entanglements, focus the mind and stabilize the will, directing all endeavors toward the Dharma.
The Seventh: Diligently recite the great scriptures, wishing all beings to be broadly delivered, building bridges for the future, and creating karmic conditions for rebirth.
The Eighth: Ever cultivate a good heart, neither deviant nor false, free from jealousy, harm, malice, or envy.
The Ninth: Wherever one is reborn, may one always encounter a sagely age, and never be parted from the teachings of the *Lingbao* scriptures.
The Tenth: Purify the body and uphold the precepts, perform purification rites and establish merit, broadly deliver all beings, that all may attain liberation.
The Eleventh: Study and master the teachings extensively, propagate and communicate them with fellow practitioners, preparing for the deliverance of heaven and humanity, universally enlightening all.
The Twelfth: May one always encounter enlightened masters in every lifetime, receive their teachings and propagate them, delivering countless beings, and may all good-hearted ones attain the true Dao.

The Six Superior Precepts for Closing the Passages of Wisdom and the Six Sensory Faculties
The First Precept: Let the eyes not wander, distracted by variegated colors, lest essence be lost, the pupils dimmed, and radiance fail to shine clearly.
The Second Precept: Let the ears not listen indiscriminately, lest they be confused by the five tones, harming the spirit and corrupting rectitude, drawn to evil sounds and lamentations.
The Third Precept: Let the nose not seek out strong fragrances or foul odors, lest it be easily tainted and turbid, and the form lose its clarity and uprightness.
The Fourth Precept: Let the mouth not crave rich flavors or pungent aromas, lest the five spirits be defiled, and the viscera and bowels become agitated.
The Fifth Precept: Let the hands not commit evil, steal others’ possessions, or covet profit for oneself, lest calamity arise unawares.
The Sixth Precept: Let the heart not cling to desire, lest the five spirits be disturbed, essence harmed, qi lost, and the body fall into confusion and delusion.

The Superior Great Precepts for the Wisdom That Delivers from Life and Death
The First: When seeing others in distress or peril, deliver them from mortal danger; in this life, one will be enlightened and capable, able to restrain misfortune and rebellion, enjoy long life, and receive boundless worldly blessings.
The Second: When seeing others in poverty and want, suffering from hunger and cold, sacrifice oneself to bestow alms, making them wealthy and noble; the karmic reward will be ten thousandfold, bringing joy in life after life.
The Third: When creatures of blood and breath in dire straits turn to humans for help, deliver them from mortal danger; in this life, one will be healthy and strong, free from unexpected misfortune.
The Fourth: Bestow kindness upon birds, beasts, and all living beings, offering food from one’s own mouth to the hungry and needy, sparing nothing; in life after life, one will be sated and content, ever dwelling in blessed realms.
The Fifth: Deliver all creatures, whether crawling or moving, ensuring their completion without premature death or injury; in this life, one will flourish and prosper, free from manifold misfortunes.
The Sixth: Ever practice a compassionate heart, showing mercy and delivering all beings, releasing life and rescuing from death; the merit is most weighty, enabling one in this life to turn danger into safety, sickness into health, poverty into wealth, and all wishes to be fulfilled.

The Superior Great Precepts of the Ten Good Deeds for Wisdom, Exhortation, and Assistance
The First: Exhort and assist in revering the Three Treasures, making offerings to Dharma-masters; in this life, one will become a noble person, virtuous and filial, of lofty talent, honored and exalted, revered by all, with a flourishing family and illustrious lineage.
The Second: Exhort and assist in transcribing scriptures; in life after life, one will be wise and intelligent, learned and profound, ever encountering sagely ages, able to recite the scriptures and their verses.
The Third: Exhort and assist in establishing purification rites and making offerings; in life after life, one’s family will be noble and exalted, ascending to the heavens, with clothing and food naturally provided, ever dwelling in non-action.
The Fourth: Exhort and assist in providing incense, oil, and other necessities; in life after life, one will be fragrant and resplendent, pure and radiant, with an extraordinary appearance and celestial bearing.
The Fifth: Exhort and assist in providing Dharma-masters with robes and vestments; in life after life, one will be refined and elegant, at ease within the central lands, not falling into border regions, with sons and daughters upright and handsome, adorned with crowns, jade, and pendants.
The Sixth: Exhort and serve the king, parents, and the people with loyalty and filial piety; in life after life, one will have many descendants, with sons and daughters who are virtuous and learned, free from all suffering.

The Seventh: Exhort and assist in maintaining quietude while reciting scriptures during fasts; in life after life, one will not fall into hell but ascend to heaven, paying homage to all sages, swiftly regaining one’s form, and transforming to be born into a royal household, with every desire fulfilled and all adornments and possessions in abundance. Seven generations of ancestors will rejoice together, all good affinities will converge, and from beginning to end, one will enjoy glory and bliss. The Dharma-wheel will turn in due course, and one will attain the Dao of immortality.

The Eighth: Exhort and assist Daoists and the multitude in the study of scriptures; in life after life, one’s talent and wisdom will be penetrating and thorough, and in movement and stillness, one’s bearing will serve as a constant model for others.

The Ninth: Exhort and assist in all acts of almsgiving and admonition; in life after life, one will enjoy longevity, wealth, and happiness, ever free from resentment and vexation.

The Tenth: Exhort and assist all people in eliminating jealousy and desire, and in practicing all virtues; in life after life, one will dwell in peace and joy, with no calamities or disorders arising. The sick will recover of themselves, officials will be promoted to high ranks, and one will be revered by all. None will fail to receive blessings, one’s household will be pure and noble, and both celestial beings and humans will cherish and nurture one. Spirits and demons will show deference, and one will forever dwell in lands of fortune.

—From *The Scripture of Cavernous Mystery: Upper Grade of Wisdom* (*Dongxuan Zhihui Shangpin Jing*), "Precepts of the Cavernous Spirit" (*Dongshen Jiepin*)

**Precepts of the Three Realms of Cavernous Spirit**

On the day of receiving the scriptures and precepts, Lord Lilu of the Di clan exhorted: each should exert utmost effort and hasten to practice diligently. Thus, these precepts are reiterated with earnest admonition for careful reception.

The First Precept: Discern causes and conditions with clarity; do not forget the root while chasing the branches.
The Second Precept: Strictly guard against self-interest; do not seek gain for oneself at the expense of others.
The Third Precept: Diligently practice and cultivate; do not indulge in negligence and lose authenticity.

These Three Supreme Precepts are revered by the Supreme Sovereign, upheld by the Celestial Thearch, and cultivated by superior practitioners. Those who practice and uphold them whole and unbroken shall have the Three Qi’s true spirits descend to merge as one with their inner gods. As the One is without duality, how can the Dao not abide eternally? Such a one is called *Tai Shang*. Those who fail to observe these precepts yet wear talismanic texts will labor in vain, bearing no verification—they are not disciples of the *Tai Shang*.

---

**Five Precepts of Cavernous Spirit**

The Yellow Thearch said: Those who do not uphold precepts will find that officials and soldiers do not attend their bodies, and their attainments will lack verification, their efforts wasted. If one does not trust the Supreme Dao and serve the master, yet desires to command officials and soldiers to guard the body and protect life, avert death and attain rebirth, dispel illness and prolong life, eliminate calamities for others, rescue them from distress, engage in meditative contemplation, and obtain verification within a set time, one must receive the Five Precepts:

The First Precept: Let the eyes not covet the five colors; vow to rectify teachings and study longevity.
The Second Precept: Let the ears not covet the five sounds; aspire to hear goodness and follow it without confusion.
The Third Precept: Let the nose not covet the five qi; use ritual incense to dispel foulness.
The Fourth Precept: Let the mouth not covet the five flavors; practice embryonic breathing and refrain from evil speech.
The Fifth Precept: Let the body not covet the five adornments; engage in diligent labor to accord with the Dao.

These are the Five Precepts. The Five Venerable Thearchs each dispatch fifteen spirits to guard and protect the bodies of those who receive and uphold them.

---

**Eight Precepts of Cavernous Spirit**

The Yellow Thearch said: Once, while dwelling in seclusion, the *Tai Shang* descended and inquired about the great and small, the beginning and end of scriptures and precepts. Though I have received and upheld them, much remains unclear, and I have not fathomed their order. I now present this fully to the *Tai Shang*.

The *Tai Shang* replied: All precepts and disciplines should be practiced universally. Among them, urgency and ease, complexity and simplicity, loftiness and humility each bear significance. They correspond to the transformations of the mysterious source, and their generation follows a gradual progression—three, five, eight, nine, ten, hundred, thousand, ten thousand. Though they adapt to what one can bear, they must not be skipped or neglected. Knowing causes and turning toward correctness, one cultivates the method of immortality and deathlessness. Combining three and five, one should receive the Eight Precepts:

First: Study and comprehend the Five Provisions and Five Virtues.
Second: Diligently practice the Five Affairs without wavering.
Third: Harmonize the Eight Correct Paths; act and withdraw in accord with the seasons.
Fourth: Clearly recognize the Five Cycles and abide with qi.
Fifth: Precisely examine the Supreme Polarity; harmonize above and below.
Sixth: Cultivate the Three Intentions to meet the Three Pure Ones.
Seventh: Resolve doubts and transform falsity into truth.
Eighth: Examine and verify, dispel misfortune and descend blessings, refine the mortal to ascend as a sage, and not betray the Three Honored Ones.

These are the Eight Precepts. For those who set their hearts on learning and seeking liberation from the world, first uphold precepts, understanding without stagnation. Precepts, whether many or few, all belong to the *Tai Wu*. The *Tai Wu* and *Tai Kong* are the root of precepts. Guarding the root and investigating the branches, external evils naturally dissipate, and internal afflictions do not arise.

Moreover, first cultivate purification, for only through refinement can one communicate with spirits. Summoning them yields swift efficacy. Long-accumulated dust and filth must be cleansed, but one must be vigilant not to interrupt or forcefully expel them. Though one may establish this intention, the dust will not depart, and demons will come to disturb, increasing calamities and faults. To prevent this flaw, use precepts as the gradual path. Uphold them according to one’s capacity; if transgressed, confess and repent, reform and renew. When in accord, advance further, and the attainment of the Dao will come in time.

---

**From *The Scripture of Cavernous Spirit*, "Five Precepts of the Orthodox Unity"**

In preserving the One and guarding the Five Spirits, the essential lies in rectifying the heart. The heart is rectified through stillness; still the body and settle the heart. When the heart is settled, perception becomes clear; when clear and bright, one meets the Dao. Meeting the Dao, the spirit and talisman unite—this is called a true sage.

When in motion, one forgets the One, and the Five Spirits are disturbed by perversity. The Five Spirits become chaotic, agitation and competition arise, vexation and restlessness follow, the Dao is lost, and one sinks into worldliness. The Three Karmas run rampant, goodness is violated, and evil is committed. The Six Penetrations are obstructed, the Seven Awakenings are obscured, and desires become innumerable.

With innumerable desires, thoughts of transgression arise incessantly, beyond description. In broad terms, there are five:

First: The eyes desire to behold the five colors; excess in color wearies the hun-soul.
Second: The ears desire to hear the five sounds; excess in sound afflicts the po-soul.
Third: The nose desires to smell the five fragrances; excess in fragrance scatters essence.
Fourth: The mouth desires the five flavors; excess in flavor clouds the spirit.
Fifth: The body desires indulgence in the five pleasures; excess in pleasure scatters the will, and scattered will injures the spleen.

When the spirit is clouded, the heart is disordered, and the mouth loses its clarity. When essence scatters, the kidneys are depleted, and madness ensues. When the po-soul is afflicted, the lungs are damaged, and deafness follows. When the hun-soul is wearied, the liver is distressed, and blindness results. When these five intermingle, the body perishes and life ends. When these five are pure and bright, the body remains whole and years are prolonged.

Prolonged years depend on upholding precepts. Upholding the Five Precepts can lead to longevity.

First: Practice benevolence—compassion and love, refraining from killing; release and deliver living beings. Inwardly contemplate the wondrous gate; with eyes gazing long, the liver and hun-soul are at peace.
Second: Practice righteousness—rewarding goodness and punishing evil, humility and yielding in public and private, refraining from theft. The ears hear the mysterious sound, and the lungs and po-soul are in harmony.
Third: Practice propriety—revering elders and deferring to the young, maintaining stillness and secrecy in yin and yang, purity and correctness without licentiousness. The mouth is filled with the dew of the Dao, and the heart and spirit are in accord.
Fourth: Practice wisdom—transforming the ignorant to learn from sages, moderating alcohol to avoid confusion. The kidneys and essence unite.
Fifth: Practice trust—upholding loyalty and embracing the One, manifesting efficacy in the hidden and visible, harboring no doubts. Without forgetfulness from beginning to end, the spleen and will are perfected.

Perfection leads to enrollment in the Orthodox Unity. Once united with the One, worries and anxieties no longer arise. The five desires are dispelled, the five evils naturally vanish, the five calamities are forever extinguished, the five sufferings are long departed, the Five Spirits are settled, and the five virtues spontaneously arise. The Three Fortunes flourish daily, and the Five Joys are ever renewed.

From the *Orthodox Unity Scriptures*

Here concludes Scroll Forty-Six of the *Supreme Secret Essentials*. Scroll Forty-Seven of the *Supreme Secret Essentials*: The Chapter on Fasting and Abstinence

The Perfected of the Great Ultimate said: In learning the Dao, fasting and abstinence are fundamental. Reciting scriptures requires fasting; collating scriptures requires fasting; copying scriptures requires fasting; inscribing talismans requires fasting; engraving registers requires fasting; compounding the Golden Elixir requires fasting; visiting a master to seek instruction requires fasting; performing rites of worship requires fasting; receiving scriptures requires fasting; healing illness and dispelling calamity require fasting; summoning Perfected Ones requires fasting.

Fasting is revered by the Most High, cherished by Lord Lao, and relied upon by all the Sages. There are many methods of fasting, which depend on what the practitioner has received and cultivates.

The Perfected of the Great Ultimate said: When a person fasts in purity and stillness for a long time, concentrating the spirit and immersing in the mysterious, reciting scriptures to repent of sins, burning incense and performing rites of worship, they will see flying immortals descending, and jade maidens and immortal youths appearing before them. Sometimes they may hear praise from the void, or see light and shadows illuminating their body, or hear the sounds of gold and jade, the music of the eight timbres—all signs that their Dao is about to be accomplished. Be diligent, be diligent! The Most High will not fail you. The only concern is that you may not persevere, not see it through to the end; this is why the path to immortality is difficult.

From the *Hidden Commentary on the Cavernous Mystery and Great Ultimate Scripture*

The Perfected of the Great Ultimate said: Always bear in mind fasting, chanting scriptures, and practicing great compassion. Put others before yourself, promote goodness and transform evil, sever all entanglements, extinguish thoughts and guard emptiness. Let the heart be like the Great Mystery, seeking only the Dao—only then can one be said to speak of the way of divine immortals.

From the *Cavernous Mystery Scripture on Pacifying the Will and Dispelling Demons*

Lord Lao the Most High said: Among the priorities of Daoists, none is closer than fasting. There are many methods of fasting, largely similar with minor differences. The most meritorious is the Fasting of the Most High Numinous Treasure, though it is rarely practiced in the world. Those who study it are all great beings, whose accumulated blessings from past lives bring them close to immortality. There is also the Fasting of the Three Heavens, which resembles the Numinous Treasure method.

The Immortal Duke said: The Fasting of the Three Heavens is the method received by the Masters of the Three Heavens, called the *Scripture of the Decreed Teachings*, and is somewhat secondary. Yet the celestial scriptures are vast and wondrous, beyond the contemplation of worldly worthies. Those who master them are all upper immortals and Perfected Ones, mystically one with the Most High. Thus, even middle immortals and heavenly beings cannot fathom their meaning—they merely glimpse the words without understanding, so what more can be said?

Lord Lao the Most High said: Fasting in purity, reciting scriptures, cultivating virtue, and establishing merit—these alone can accomplish the immortal Dao. Why must one retreat to mountains and marshes? The aim is simply to avoid desires and depart from filth and chaos; the mountains and forests do not exclusively harbor those who possess the Dao.

From the *Cavernous Mystery Scripture of Questions to the Highest*

The Immortal Duke ascended Mount Laosheng, fasting in stillness and contemplating the Dao. At midday, thirty-three earthbound immortals and Daoist adepts arrived at his seat. After burning incense and paying homage to the scriptures, each returned to their immortal abodes, dwelling in peace as before.

The Immortal Duke said: The Celestial Master has said that those who fast in a quiet chamber on the first and fifteenth days of the month, reading the scriptures they have received and the deeds of the immortals, will all become people of future sages, born to encounter this age—how joyful is that?

From the *Cavernous Mystery Scripture of the Difficulties of All Sages*

The Heavenly Worthy said: The Dao is revered, its methods wondrous, and the human body is also precious. Thus, the Dao has revealed scriptures, precepts, and teachings to deliver the human form. Once the human form is delivered, it ascends to become one with the Dao. One should practice purity, uphold fasting and precepts, calm the mind in stillness, keep the will and thoughts clear, focus the intent single-mindedly, and maintain unwavering concentration. Purify the six viscera, refrain from eating after midday, keep inner and outer purity, and align with spontaneity—this is the fasting where one kneads incense and voices aspirations, which ascend to the heavens. The patrols of the Four Heavens and the mighty spirits of the Ten Divisions descend to observe and listen. The sounds of the Dharma illuminate, and if your heart adheres to the precepts, your practice will be recorded as merit in the heavens. Fortune and misfortune will be immediately manifest, for the Dao does not fail people.

The Heavenly Worthy said: When establishing a fast and practicing the Dao, the Four Heavenly Emperor-Kings all ride flying clouds, green chariots, and eight-scene jade carriages. Perfected Ones and jade maidens attend them, holding flowered canopies. Phoenixes sing in the lead, celestial music follows, white cranes and lions roar and chant. Fragrant smoke wafts, flowers scatter in the air as they come to witness the rites, observe the practice, and listen to the sounds of the Dharma. The Heavenly Kings descend, and the myriad spirits pay homage.

From the *Cavernous Mystery Scripture of the Great Precepts of Wisdom and Intelligence*

At that time, the Dao Lord of the Most High was at the Cypress Mound Lodge in the Southern Vermilion Cavern of Yang. He bowed his head and paid homage to the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning, reflecting on the blessings of past lives that, through the connections of countless kalpas, had allowed him to encounter this sagely and luminous age. Formerly, he had been elevated by revelation, undeservedly honored, and favored by the Upper Perfected Ones, who instructed him in the Three Treasures and the divine scriptures, bestowed upon him the Great Precepts, and proclaimed the sounds of the Dharma. The joy of such excessive grace was boundless. Since receiving these teachings, he had fasted in empty mountains, upheld the precepts and commandments without negligence or weariness. His Daoist practice was accomplished, enabling him to deliver all heavenly and mortal beings, men and women, and universally reveal the gates of the Dharma.

From the *Cavernous Mystery Scripture of the Precepts on the Roots of Transgressions*

The Dao said: Once there was a Daoist who fasted and recited scriptures. A layman was hired to clean and prepare the fasting hall. The Daoist, seeing his diligence, at midday invited him to share the fast and eat together. After the meal, he expounded the Dharma to the laborer, telling him to join in fasting. The merit of this is vast—come again at midday tomorrow to eat, and do not break your fast, lest your efforts be in vain and without benefit. If you can do this, you may avoid poverty and hardship in this life.

The laborer bowed and received the precepts before leaving. That evening, he returned home, where his wife had prepared a meal, awaiting her husband’s return. He explained the Daoist’s precepts to her, but she did not understand and became angry. Unable to resist his wife’s wishes, the laborer broke his fast and ate with her. Later, when his life ended, the celestial officials made him the master of a thousand-year-old tree spirit in Mount Shu, forever providing for his sustenance.

The tree flourished in lush abundance. One sweltering summer day, three diligent and virtuous seekers passed by and rested beneath its shade. One of them sighed, saying, "Though this tree provides cool respite, the sun has already reached its zenith—how shall we find food?" From within the hollow of the tree, a voice replied, "I shall prepare a midday meal for you, noble ones. Have no concern." In an instant, food appeared, and the seekers ate together. After the meal, one said, "Where now shall we seek the Dao? Is this very spontaneity not the Dao itself?" They then asked the tree, "Might the great spirit deign to briefly descend and appear before us?" The voice from the hollow answered, "I am not one who can guide others to the Dao." It then revealed its name and origin, explaining, "I was once a laborer urged by a Daoist to keep the fast. My wife broke my resolve, leaving my merit incomplete. Thus, I am bound to guard this tree spirit, unable to depart. Heaven, recalling my past observance of the midday fast, now provides me with daily sustenance. Though my mouth and belly are sated, I remain trapped here without hope of advancement. I humbly ask, noble ones, to visit my home and explain my plight. If you could perform a three-day fast and purification on my behalf, I would ascend at once."

Moved by the spirit’s plea, the seekers sought out his family and relayed his words. His kin then arranged a fast, inviting Daoist priests to burn incense, recite scriptures, and offer three days of repentance. The spirit immediately took flight, ascending into the clouds, where it received a celestial writ and became a wandering immortal in the radiant heavens. Thus, the merit of fasting is profound and must not be neglected. This man, though he kept the fast for only half a day and died the following day, was freed from his bond and attained immortality within a year. Heaven’s reckoning of merit and transgression is precise and unerring. Those who pursue the Dao must diligently observe fasting and precepts, awaiting the hidden response; those who cultivate this practice will surely achieve ascension.

*—Excerpt from the* Wondrous Scripture of Fundamental Practices *(*Dongxuan Benxing Miaojing*)*

When the Left Immortal of the Grand Ultimate, Lord Taiyi, secluded himself in fasting and purification on Mount Tiantai to repent his sins, he burned incense, confessed his transgressions, and meditated upon the true Dao. For a hundred days, divine luminaries flickered in the void above—now present, now absent, now soaring, now gathering—casting shifting reflections upon the hall of fasting. The Immortal’s gaze pierced the depths, and his distant devotion moved the celestial perfected. Thereupon, he refined his thoughts upon the mysterious work, his resolve growing ever more steadfast. Before a year had passed, his devotion resonated with the exalted sages, who descended in subtle regard to his secluded chamber. On the night of the *gengyin* day in the first month of the new year, there suddenly appeared flying clouds from the cinnabar heavens, eight radiant scenes, jade chariots, jeweled canopies, streaming effulgence, celestial incense, and drifting blossoms—all floating in the void. A thousand chariots and ten thousand riders arrived, beyond all reckoning.

*—Excerpt from the* Wondrous Scripture of the Wheel of Exhortation and Precepts of the True One *(*Dongxuan Zhenyi Quanjie Falun Miaojing*)*

*The True Scripture of the Flying Steps on the Heavenly Net and the Treading of the Seven Primordials’ White Feathers and Black Pinions* (*Dongzhen Feibu Tiangang Nixing Qiyuan Baiyu Heihe Feixing Yujing*)

Master and disciple fast together for ninety days.
*The True Scripture of the Three Nines’ Plain Speech, the Jade Essence’s True Formula, the Eight Simplicities’ True Scripture, and the Ingestion of the Sun and Moon’s Yellow Splendor*—also named *The Eight Platforms and Four Gates’ Supreme Scripture* (*Dongzhen Sanjiu Suyu Yujing Zhenjue Basu Zhenjing Fu Riyue Huanghua, Yiming Ba Tan Simen Gaoshang Jing*)
Eight scrolls.
*The Jade Writ of the Great Empyrean’s Numinous Stanzas* (*Taixiao Langshu Qiongwen Dizhang*)
Three formulas, ten scrolls.

Master and disciple fast together for one hundred days, or thirty days.
*The True Scripture of the Cinnabar Radiance of the Dao’s Essence and the Eight Arts of Concealment in Earth* (*Dongzhen Danjing Daojing Yindi Bashu*)

Master and disciple fast together for eighty days.

*Highest Mystery Essential*, Scroll 47, concludes.
Scroll 48: *Numinous Treasure Fast and Retreat Rites*
*Highest Mystery Essential*, Scroll 48: *Numinous Treasure Fast and Retreat Rites*

The ranking officials enter the ritual chamber in order of seniority. Outside the chamber door, they knock their teeth three times and recite the incantation:

*"Four Superior Functionaries,
Dragon-Tiger Envoys,
Orthodox Unity’s Vital Qi,
Jade Maidens in Attendance—
Whatever is reported at night,
May the Luminous Youth and Supreme Mystery Maiden
accompany me into the Yellow Court’s interior,
conveying all petitions so they ascend on high."*

*(From the* Scripture of the Golden Register.*)*

Upon first entering the fast hall, the Dharma Master leads, followed by the officials in order. Each holds three pinches of incense, circumambulating the high seat once to the left. Facing east, they knock their teeth twenty-four times and recite the incantation:

*"Supreme Three Heavens’ True Primordial Three Qi,
Most High Lord Lao,
Summon forth from within us
the Three and Five Functionaries,
Left and Right Official Envoys,
Left and Right Incense-Bearing Dragon-Riding Couriers,
Incense-Attending Golden Youths,
