Message-Transmitting Flower-Scattering Jade Maidens,
Five Thearchs’ Direct Talismans,
and Day-Officer Incense Spirits—
thirty-six each—
to emerge in solemn array.
Notify the local earth deities and domain spirits:
we now burn incense and perform the Dao,
may the Most High’s Ten Directions’ Orthodox True Vital Qi
enter our bodies,
so our petitions swiftly ascend
before the Jade Thearch of the Supreme Ultimate Great Dao’s
Most True Imperial Presence."*

*(From the* Scripture of Illuminating the True.*)*

Next, the petition ritual.

**Petition of the Supreme Numinous Treasure’s Peerless Cavern-Mystery Disciples, Master [X] of [Y] Mountain, [Name] and Others:**

We, your disciples, humbly address the Supreme Ultimate Great Dao Most True, the Numinous Treasure’s Thirty-Six Divisions of Venerable Scriptures, the Three Supreme Ones, the Multitudes of Saints in the Ten Directions, the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious Realm, the Officials and Attendants of the Three Realms, and all divine spirits:

By fortunate karmic affinity, the blessings of our past lives and the nine heavens’ kalpas have extended to our present selves. We have encountered this luminous era, wherein the Great Dharma flourishes, allowing our defiled forms to partake in the sacred texts—the Golden Writings of the Upper Clarity and the Three Caverns’ Treasure Scriptures. We have reverently offered them devotion, observed precepts, and performed purification rites. The grace bestowed is profound, the favors weighty—far beyond our deserts.

Yet we, base and unrefined, have failed to ascend the numinous peaks or refine our hearts and spirits. Instead, we have indulged in worldly glory, lingering among mortals, drifting with the times, and sinking with the mundane tide. Our transgressions and faults have accumulated day by day, month by month. We constantly fear the reckoning to come, shamed before the hidden and obscure. Day and night, we tremble as if treading thin ice. Rightly should we remain silent in our inadequacy, yet on the day we received the Dharma, we swore oaths before the Three Officials: we vowed to devote even the slightest of our meager efforts to glorify the Great Transformation, making salvation our vocation.

Now, with reverence, we present our fellow Daoists—men and women of [X] prefecture, [Y] county, [Z] village, [Name], aged [X] years—who have composed their petitions and listed their vows, surrendering their lives to the Great Dao. They have prepared the rites of incense and lamps for offerings, seeking to undertake the purification rites of [X] office. How dare we not report this? We shall now perform the Peerless Great Dharma and the Numinous Treasure’s Natural Purification Rite, equivalent to a thousand days and nights. Beginning on the [X] day of this month, we shall gather together at [Location], purify ourselves according to the Dharma, and proceed with due solemnity.

We hereby announce this, adhering to the ancient protocols of ritual decorum, appointing officials and functionaries, proclaiming the precepts and prohibitions, that all officers and attendants may submit to the Dharma’s teachings.

We implore the Supreme Ones, the Three Treasures’ majestic spirits, the Dharma Masters overseeing the purification, and the attendant perfected beings: deign to look upon us with compassion, review our petition, and command the officials of the Three Realms and the local earth deities to guard and protect us, our households, and all within our dwellings. Cleanse our abodes, dispel malevolent impurities, and at dawn tomorrow, we shall perform the Dao according to the Dharma, continuing our supplications.

*(From the* Scripture of the Golden Register.*)*

The petition concluded, all face east and stand in alignment, reciting the Three Stanzas of Wisdom:

**First Stanza:**
Wisdom arises from the formless,
Radiant, transcending the Ten Directions.
It structures emptiness, towering in the Mysterious Empyrean,
While all heavens embrace its fragrant flow.
Its wonders defy thought,
Yet through emptiness, truth is realized.
Existence holds no true existence,
And non-existence contains all.

**Second Stanza:**
Wisdom ever observes the self,
The foremost study of those who cultivate the Dao.
Subtly it enters the Mysterious Workshop,
Naturally recording our spirits.
The Heavenly Worthy ever shields us,
While demon kings pledge their protection.
Resplendent is the Vajra body,
Transcendent, a Supreme Immortal.

**Third Stanza:**
Wisdom births the root of precepts,
For the true Dao, precepts are the foundation.
From them arise the Three Treasures,
Revered by lofty sages.
Aboard this deathless vessel,
Swiftly we cross the vast expanse.
At this moment of preaching precepts,
All heavens bow in homage.

*(From the* Jade Register of Pure Sincerity.*)*

**Next, Surrender to All Heavenly Worthies:**

With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Jade Dawn in the North.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of Ascended Immortals in the Northeast.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Jade Treasure in the East.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of Life-Nurturing Salvation in the Southeast.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of Mysterious Truth and Myriad Blessings in the South.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Fiery Numinous Empty Sovereign in the Southwest.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of Supreme Mystery in the West.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of Boundless Great Splendor in the Northwest.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Jade Clarity and Luminous Sovereign in the Above.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the True Sovereign and Cavern Spirits in the Below.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Highest Jade Emperor of the Past.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Primordial Origin of the Present.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Supreme Ultimate of the Future.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to the Heavenly Worthy of the Jade Capital, Mysterious Terrace, and Purple Tenuity.
With utmost sincerity, we surrender to all perfected immortals and accomplished saints.

**Next, the Dharma Master Faces East, Toward the West, and Proclaims the Precepts:**

The Heavenly Worthy addressed the Supreme Dao Lord, saying: “Now we shall universally proclaim the Dharma’s sound to awaken all beings. For all men and women, we shall dissolve calamities, avert misfortunes, invoke blessings, deliver lives, and eradicate the roots of suffering. May the living perceive the Dao, escape the eight difficulties, and may the dead rejoice, feasting in the heavens, soon reborn among men, ascending to the ranks of sagely kings. All who perform purification rites and seek the Dao must wholeheartedly receive and uphold the Ten Precepts. Listen attentively, without distraction, and contemplate their truth naturally. Do not allow stray thoughts to disturb body and spirit. Those who can do so shall now listen in silence:

**First Precept:** Let the heart harbor no malice or envy. Do not cultivate hidden harm. Guard your speech, be cautious of faults, and let your thoughts dwell in the Dharma.

**Second Precept:** Uphold benevolence, refrain from killing. Pity and aid all beings. Let compassion and love extend broadly to save all, bestowing blessings universally.

**Third Precept:** Uphold chastity and yield to righteousness. Do not indulge in lust or theft. Constantly cultivate good thoughts, sacrificing for others.

**Fourth Precept:** Do not indulge in sensuality or desire, nor act wantonly. Maintain purity and caution, ensuring your conduct remains unstained.

**Fifth Precept:** Let your speech be free of malice. Do not adorn your words with florid embellishments. Be upright in all matters, avoiding transgressions of speech.

**Sixth Precept:** Reduce alcohol and moderate conduct. Harmonize your qi and nature. Do not injure the spirit or commit manifold evils.

**Seventh Precept:** Do not envy others’ superiority or contend for fame. In all matters, yield and retreat, aiding others in their advancement.

**Eighth Precept:** Do not criticize the scriptures or slander sacred texts. Receive the Dharma with reverence, ever as if in the presence of the divine.

**Ninth Precept:** Do not incite strife or gossip, nor disparage the four classes. Heaven and humanity will resent you, harming your spirit and qi.

**Tenth Precept:** In all actions and deeds, maintain equanimity and single-mindedness. Let harmony prevail among people, and peace among spirits. Let this be your constant practice.”

The Heavenly Worthy said: Those who cultivate and uphold the pure precepts ever align with the heart of Heaven. Constantly practice great compassion, vowing to universally deliver all from calamity and distress. With reverence for the sacred teachings, never grow lax midway. Better to die upholding goodness than to live in evil. Thus unwavering, one may escape the Five Paths and avoid the Three Evils. Guarded by all heavens and revered by the myriad spirits, through long fasting and precept-keeping, one naturally attains deliverance from the world.

The Heavenly Worthy said: The Dao is exalted, the Dharma wondrous, and the human body likewise precious. Thus the Dao unfolds the Dharma, bequeathing precepts and scriptures to deliver the human form. Once the human form is delivered, it ascends to merge with the Dao. One should therefore practice with utmost sincerity, maintain fasting and precepts, calm the mind in stillness, and clarify intentions. With single-minded devotion and undivided focus, purify the Six Bowels. After midday, take no flavor. Within and without, remain pure and empty, ever in accord with nature. On fasting days, when incense is lit and vows are made, the invocation ascends to the Four Heavens. The ten divisions of mighty spirits then descend, observing conduct and listening to the Dharma. The sounds of the Dharma oversee and reflect. If your heart adheres to the precepts and you practice the Dao, your merits shall be recorded in the heavens. Fortune and misfortune manifest instantly. The Dao does not fail those who diligently practice and sincerely receive—beware the words of demons.

The Heavenly Worthy said: When establishing fasts and practicing the Dao, the Four Heavenly Emperor-Kings all ride jade chariots of eight luminous scenes drawn by flying clouds. Attended by perfected beings and jade maidens bearing floral banners, they are preceded by phoenix songs and followed by the celestial harmonies of the Grand Heaven. White cranes and lions roar and chant, while fragrant smoke wafts and flowers scatter through the air. They come to witness the practice of the Dao, to listen to the Dharma, and to pay homage. The Heavenly Kings descend, and the myriad spirits gather in attendance. How could one not fully uphold such a method?

First receive the Ten Precepts, then practice the Dao. Move with refined grace, quiet the heart, and still the mind. In sitting, rising, lying, or resting, never depart from proper form. The Heavenly Kings rejoice, and your name is inscribed in the Upper Clarity. This is what it means to attain the Dao within the square inch of the heart.

From the *Scripture of the Golden Register*.
Next, appoint the various officials.

Appoint the High Merit Grand Dharma Master, who must be of lofty virtue and profound understanding of the subtle and wondrous principles. Next, appoint the Chief Lecturer Dharma Master, who must be of keen intelligence and precision, well-versed in the regulations of the Dao. Then appoint the Supervisor of the Ritual Fast, who must oversee and correct all transgressions and errors. Next, appoint the Scripture Attendants, who must tend to the scriptures and arrange the ritual vestments. Then appoint the Incense Attendants, who must manage the censers and ensure the incense fire never ceases. Next, appoint the Lamp Attendants, who must face the Western Paradise and prepare the lamps. Then appoint the Seat Attendants, who must ensure the seating mats and ground are clean and orderly.

Thirty-six Articles of Penalties for Transgressions and Errors:
- If footwear is improper in the ritual hall.
- If the chanting of auspicious sounds is not in unison.
- If ritual robes, headscarves, or caps are improper.
- If hair hangs loose before the Dharma seat.
For each of these, the penalty is ten prostrations.

- If rising, sitting, bowing, or yielding lacks proper form.
- If the lamp fire extinguishes during the Lamp Attendant’s watch.
- If one fails to maintain pure and empty mindfulness, disturbing others.
- If one falls asleep before the Dharma seat.
For each of these, the penalty is twenty prostrations.

- If the bell’s sound ceases prematurely, disrupting the procession.
- If one fails to attend the morning audience with the master.
- If prostrations are uneven in ascent or descent.
- If the incense smoke ceases during the Incense Attendant’s watch.
For each of these, the penalty is thirty prostrations.

- If the Chief Lecturer fails to lead the chanting.
- If one enters or leaves without paying homage to the Three Treasures.
- If scripture recitation is careless, disrupting questions or corrupting verses.
- If rising or sitting lacks proper order.
For each of these, the penalty is forty prostrations.

- If the chanting of hymns is not in accord with the auspicious tone.
- If one leaves the ritual hall without reporting.
- If one listens to the scriptures while leaning or sitting improperly.
- If ritual robes are worn inside-out.
For each of these, the penalty is fifty prostrations.

- If one circulates without following the proper sequence.
- If the Chief Lecturer strikes the bell too early or late.
- If one ascends the altar out of turn.
- If the Supervisor of the Ritual Fast sees an error but fails to correct it, and is exposed by others.
For each of these, the penalty is sixty prostrations.

- If one wears coarse clothing or ritual headgear outside the hall.
- If one overturns an incense burner or lamp.
- If one burns incense without washing hands.
- If one speaks with outsiders during the ritual.
For each of these, the penalty is seventy prostrations.

- If one arrives after the chanting of "Silent Reflection" concludes.
- If the Seat Attendant fails to arrange the seating properly, causing damage or neglect.
- If one discusses the *Analects* or worldly affairs.
- If one leaves and does not return.
For each of these, the penalty is eighty prostrations.

- If one engages in frivolous laughter before the Dharma seat.
- If one indulges in frivolous speech before the Dharma seat.
- If one fails to rise at the appointed hour.
- If one raises their voice or displays harsh demeanor during the ritual fast.
For each of these, the penalty is ninety prostrations.

From the *Scripture of Ritual Fast Procedures*.
After the articles are proclaimed, each pays homage to the master with two bows. Then the master faces east, kneels, and formally requests the officials to assume their posts.

The Most High Numinous Treasure’s Supreme Three Caverns Disciples, Master So-and-So of Such-and-Such Mountain and So-and-So, humbly address the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Void and Spontaneous Origin, the Supreme Dao Lord of the Boundless Great Dao, the August Jade Sovereign, the Perfected and Great Sages who have attained the Dao, the Host of Most True Ones, the Lords and Elders, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors, the Jade Void Highest Emperor, the Great Emperor of the Jade Capital, the Eastern Florescence, the Southern Culmen, the Western Numinous, the Northern Perfected, the Golden Towers of the Jade Metropolis of the Dark Capital, the Seven-Treasured Mystic Terrace, the Supreme Palace of the Purple Tenuity, the Most True Ones of the Numinous Treasure, the Radiant Sovereign of the Dao, and all others:

By karmic affinity from past lives, we have been born to encounter the transformation of the Dao. Through the mysterious and true, we have been awakened and uplifted, entering the root of faith. Our former masters have transmitted to us the sacred scriptures of the Three Treasures through covenant. In reverent offering and homage, we prioritize the establishment of merit. Now, from such-and-such prefecture, county, village, and hamlet, the man or woman So-and-So has submitted a petition and come forth in person. With sincere and earnest hearts, we beseech your compassionate review and humbly present the petition for proclamation. We reverently recite the petition’s text.

Upon proclaiming the petition, we, in accordance with its words—its earnest and pressing matters, which evoke profound pity—find ourselves unable to bear witness without acting. Thus, we join together, purify ourselves through bathing, burn incense, light lamps, and circumambulate the Dao. Following the ritual, we invoke and supplicate the Heavenly Immortals, Flying Immortals, Earthbound Immortals, Perfected Ones, Divine Persons, Sages, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Overseers of the Ritual Fast, the Golden Lads Attending Incense, the Jade Maidens Scattering Flowers, the Thirty-Two Direct Talismans of the Five Emperors, the Messengers Transmitting Words and Memorials, the Flying Dragon Riders, and all others—requesting their united descent to oversee the ritual hall. As we hold incense and voice our vows, may our prayers ascend without obstruction. Upon the completion of the circumambulation, we petition for their return to the immortal palaces.

From the *Scripture of Radiant Perfection*.

Next, the Rite of Replenishing the Censer:
May the Incense Officials, the Lords of the Left and Right Dragon-Tiger, and the various spirit officials attending the incense ensure that within this hall of stillness, golden liquor, cinnabar, azure mushrooms, and numinous herbs spontaneously arise. May the host of perfected ones and the hundred spirits gather here before the incense fire. May we, the supplicants, receive blessings under heaven and be favored across the ten directions. May the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens attend the incense smoke, transmitting our words directly to the presence of the Supreme Boundless Dao.

From the *Scripture of Radiant Perfection*.

Next, the Offering of the Precepts and Hymn.

The Dao is the school of no-mind,
the field where all merit is sown.
To establish merit has no fixed master—
each follows their own original vow.
Empty the self to respond to all beings,
direct the mind so none is left unmet.
The Great Sage exalts the supreme teaching,
just as rain falls from heaven:
high and low alike receive it,
yet the lowly become deep pools.
The sea is king of the hundred rivers,
for it contains dragons and scaled creatures.
Through ten thousand kalpas, wisdom is preserved and used—
how could it be limited to one’s years?
Uphold the precepts without the slightest lapse,
and in life after life, good affinities will form.
With focused thought, contemplate the Great Vehicle,
and you shall embody the true Dao.

From the *Scripture of the Divine Duke’s Inquiry*.

Next, the Spell for Opening the Dao-Gate:
Darkest Supreme Yin, the eight windows open bright.
When there is something to report, the Maiden transmits the numinous.
Once the matter is complete, the ten thousand spirits return to their tranquil harbor.

From the *Scripture of the Golden Register*.

Here ends Scroll Forty-Eight of the *Supreme Secret Essentials*.

Scroll Forty-Nine of the *Supreme Secret Essentials*
The Three Sovereigns’ Fast

The numinous altar shall be twenty-four feet square, with four gates opened at the directions of chen, xu, chou, and wei. Within the altar, nine lamps shall be arranged in each of the four directions. Opposite the altar, set one tray and one cup for the offering. The cups used shall each hold one sheng. On the tray, place three jujubes and nine slices of dried meat. The total for one offering shall be nine sheng of wine and twenty-seven jujubes.

One censer of incense shall be burned.

Each of the Three Sovereigns’ seats shall have one table: the Heavenly Sovereign at zi, the Earthly Sovereign at shen, and the Human Sovereign at yin. Each shall have one tray, one cup, one offering mat, and one censer. Each cup shall hold three sheng of wine, and each tray nine jujubes. The three seats together shall use nine sheng of wine and twenty-seven jujubes.

Three azure banners shall be prepared, each five feet long. On each, write in vermilion the inner script of the Three Sovereigns, adjusting the size and spacing of the characters to fill the banner. Attach ribbons as above. Three green bamboo poles, each twelve feet long, shall be fitted with bases and placed behind each table at their respective positions.

At the center of the altar, place another incense table and censer, with the silk of the fast’s patron’s life-destiny spread upon the table.

One candle tray with a stand and three candles shall be provided for reading the scriptures and turning during the rite.

Spread mats to cover the altar. In total, eight censers, four tables, incense and lamps as prescribed, thirty-nine seven-inch trays, thirty-nine sheng cups, and two sets of seven libation vessels shall be used to hold the jujubes and dried meat prepared for the day.

For one day, use forty-five sheng of wine, one hundred thirty-five jujubes, and forty-five jin of dried meat. For three days, use one *dan* and thirty-five sheng of wine, four hundred five jujubes, and one hundred thirty-five jin of dried meat.

Prepare the incense according to the method for Upper Prime Fragrant Pearls, and refine cloud-fat for anointing. Bathe with cloud-water; if in a place of poverty, plain fragrant water will suffice. Five-fold incense and fresh clear oil are also acceptable.

Thirty-six lamp wicks shall be prepared, and lamps may also be lit at the kitchen stove and other places as available.

Offerings of faith.

The patron’s life-destiny silk shall be one *chi* in length, its color corresponding to the patron’s birth year. For the Heavenly Sovereign, nine *zhang* of black silk; for the Earthly Sovereign, seven *zhang* of white silk; for the Human Sovereign, seven *zhang* of azure silk. For the poor, these may be reduced to *chi* lengths, while wealthy households may provide more.

Also, spread one bolt of silk in each direction on the exposed mats to serve as seats for the deities: azure in the east, crimson in the south, white in the west, and black in the north—two in each direction, with additional ones placed at the gates.

According to the scripture, this fast should be observed with meals taken at the hours of *zi* and *wu*. However, most people today cannot adhere to this and follow the usual practice. Only at midnight, after the ritual circumambulation, shall the offering be presented at the seats, and all shall receive blessings. Any surplus may be distributed as desired.

For devout household members, though the rite is prescribed for three days, it may be completed in one day and night. In impoverished mountain regions, the offering may be omitted, and only lamps lit.

Here ends the list of items required for the fast.

The ritual implements, four banners, and mats shall be provided by the ritual master. Incense, oil, and offerings of faith shall be provided by the patron of the fast. After the rite, these shall be distributed as alms.

The preliminary rite on the eve of the fast:
If wind or rain drives one indoors, face north, knock the teeth twelve times, and say:

Fragrant smoke and jade maidens ascend to memorialize the Three August Sovereigns and the True Lords, reporting the establishment of the Three Augusts’ Daoist Fast of the Cavernous Divine for the thirty-six matters, with gratitude. Now, as we ascend the altar and enter the chamber to burn incense, may this eve’s preliminary rite be heard this very day, proceeding directly to the Purple Palace, and reaching upward to the presence of the Three August True Lords.

Thereupon, we offer incense and bow twice. Again, we present incense at the three thrones: to the Heavenly August at *zi*, the Earthly August at *shen*, and the Human August at *yin*. Thrice we bow and stand, saying:

We, your servants, now burn incense and perform this rite of reverence, wishing that by this merit we may offer it above for the king, the imperial lord, the dukes, ministers, and common folk, the prefects and magistrates of the commanderies, the assembled officials and all offices, and for our own living and deceased parents; below, may it extend to ourselves, the black-haired masses, the myriad people, the hidden souls of the earthly prisons, the spirits of mountains and waters, the essences of birds, beasts, fish, and insects, and all sentient beings. May each attain their Dao, have their accumulated transgressions pardoned, their trials and grievances resolved, their names inscribed on the cinnabar tablets, and their destinies fixed in the azure registers.

May we, your servants, together with the deities of the Three Palaces, ascend the Mystic Dawn, present ourselves at the Supreme Clarity, and behold the Sage Lord. May we be granted scriptures and receive our duties, forever becoming lofty perfected ones.

Still reciting, they say:

Vast, vast, the qi of the Three Heavens,
Nurturing and fostering the myriad transformations of things.
Worldly passions delight in their blossoms,
Yet the true Dao treasures their essence.
The foolish and vulgar play with fleeting glory,
While divine immortals cherish the fundamental substance.
Diligently cultivating the scriptures of the Three Sovereigns,
Jade spirits illumine the secluded chamber.
In lofty song, we aspire to the Supreme Microcosm,
Bowing our heads to pay homage to the August One.

Again they bow twice, each declaring their name and rank:

Disciples of the Supreme Perfected Three Sovereigns, your servants so-and-so, respectfully address the Supreme Dao Lord, the Supreme Lord Lao, the Supreme Elder, the Jade Lords of the Three Sovereigns, the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital, the Nine Qi Elders, the Immortal Officials of the Mystic Capital, the Supreme Mystic Perfected Spirits, the Divine Officials of the Thirty-Six Heavens above and below, the Spirits of the Great Clarity, the Celestial Emperors of the Five Directions, the Twenty-Eight Constellations, the Stellar Officials within and beyond, the Perfected Officials of the Five Marchmounts, the Assisting Spirits of all mountains, the Four Seas, the Four Rivers, the Eight Marshes, the Nine Springs, the renowned mountains and grotto-heavens, the water spirits, and all the myriad numinous beings within the cosmos.

We, your servants, have performed meritorious deeds in past lives, and in this present existence, our karma has inclined toward emptiness and distance, our understanding still pure and true. Thus, we have been able to transcend the mundane form and dwell beyond the forest of light, serving the Dao and contemplating the Mysterious. Years and months have passed in this manner. Though we have not yet attained wisdom to penetrate the profound origin or radiance to illumine the wondrous ultimate, we have fixed our thoughts upon the numinous spirits without fail.

From of old, we have received the inner scriptures of the Three Sovereigns, the celestial writings of jade graphs, which above can inscribe names among the myriad spirits and seal the palms of the host of numina, and below can rescue and resolve calamities, swiftly bestowing blessings and felicity.

There are the precious fasts and registers for supplication and thanksgiving, the inner formulas of the immortal capital revealing the rites of the jiao offering. The incense of the Upper Prime wafts through the vast heavens, the vermilion lamps of the Mysterious Numinous illumine the deep night. Truly, this is the secret transmission for attaining the sagely, the essential method for summoning the perfected. Its vast salvation extends to the four quarters, unbound by nobility or baseness; its vast moisture permeates the eight directions, undivided between Daoists and commoners.

Now, so-and-so of such-and-such commandery, district, village, and hamlet, having faith in the true canon and aspiring to merit and fortune, has journeyed afar to this mountain to present his plea. With sincere devotion, he seeks to establish the Three Sovereigns’ fast of thanksgiving, to repent misfortune and pray for blessings.

We respectfully recite the words to make them heard, aligning the petition with the proper forms and sincerity of intent. We, your servants, who assist the world and rescue the imperiled, are duty-bound to aid and deliver. So-and-so, overwhelmed by utmost sincerity, has humbly led us here. Having bathed in the numinous waters and purified ourselves, on such-and-such day of this month, we shall together ascend the numinous altar, enter the fast hall, and lodge our supplication. For three days and three nights, through the twelve hours, we shall perform the Dao, conduct rites, and present offerings, making our report to the Upper Palace.

We humbly pray that the Perfected Officials of the August One’s Three Perfected Grotto-Heavens deign to oversee and inspect. May they specially command the Perfected Officials and true spirits of the commandery, district, village, and hamlet, the various attending perfected officers, the soldiers, the incense and jade maidens, and the supervising altar spirits to jointly protect and defend the fast site, slay and sever demonic influences, so that the heavens may be clear and the qi bright, the winds may sweep and the clouds disperse. May our merit be accomplished and our affairs fulfilled, and may all be worthy of reward for their toil.

The rites and protocols shall be made clear at the dawn audience.

Thereupon, they bow twice more, turn, and proceed, reciting:

Those who cultivate the supreme Dao in the world
harbor myriad thoughts in their hearts and minds.
Their ears and eyes are distracted by gaudy hues,
and their emotions and wills remain ever unsteady.
Though petty wisdom may strive with its own strength,
how can it safeguard one’s life to the end?
The five spirits lose their master,
and true qi departs, never to return.
If one can practice with a suffering heart,
one may preserve life and secure its root.
Hold the precepts as your treasure,
and ever grasp the words of the Heavenly Elder.
All the Perfected will rejoice together,
and together they will welcome the August Lord.

Facing southeast, they turn west and kneel, saying:
We, your servants, humbly reflect upon ourselves.
Though we have fully heard the teachings of the Dao
and received the established rules in their entirety,
we have yet to still our minds and open our thoughts,
so that all leaks might instantly vanish.
We must redouble our efforts to perfect our true work.
Now we reverently unfold the scriptures, expound the prohibitions,
and instruct those of shared qi.
We explain and confer the duties to be undertaken,
so that each may follow the canonical offices.
We request that the fast officers prostrate themselves to receive the command.

We respectfully follow the words of the Supreme Minister, the Perfected One of the Western City, Lord Wang:
The August Scriptures of Heavenly Writ
are the great chapters of the cloud-seal of the Supreme Perfected One of the Three Sovereigns,
received in the time of the Three August Ones.
When the Three Sovereigns established their work,
heaven was harmonious and earth was uncarved.
They ordered yin and yang,
and regulated ghosts and spirits.
Thus could they nurture the body and secure life,
preserving and prolonging it.
These are the secret treasures of the Queen Mother of the West,
the objects of reverence for the immortals’ officials—
truly the precious texts of the Perfected.
Few in the world obtain these scriptures.
If one can possess them,
the Nine Elder Immortals of the Great Mystery’s Immortal Capital
will dispatch direct talismans to guard this true writ.
Simply by paying reverence morning and evening,
one may enjoy one’s full span of years,
and the five weapons, five poisons, and baleful influences will not assail one.
If one could summon by means of them, how could their power be described?
The calamity of careless disclosure and disrespect
is met with celestial statutes and punitive decrees.
The August One records transgressions in writing—
how can one not be cautious!

The Perfected One of the Western City further says:
The pursuit of fame is the name that destroys my virtue.
The pursuit of affairs is the affair that disorders my work.
The pursuit of desire is the desire that increases my confusion.
The pursuit of emotion is the emotion that destroys my self.
No sin is greater than lewdness,
no calamity greater than greed,
no fault greater than gluttony.
These are the vehicles that carry disaster:
in small measure, they endanger the body;
in great measure, they ruin the household.

The Perfected Lord Wang further admonishes:
Those who wish to study the Dao and seek life
must first be cautious of all prohibitions.
Only then can they commune with the divine luminaries
and thus forever preserve body and life.
If one repeatedly violates and offends,
one will be seized by the dark bureaus.
Even to remain human will be impossible—
how much more so to become an immortal?
Now I tell you these things—
you must uphold them.

The first prohibition: Do not indulge in lewdness or ejaculation,
lest your body and life perish prematurely.
The second prohibition: Do not secretly harm or cruelly oppress,
lest the Three Offices execute punishment.
The third prohibition: Do not kill or injure living beings,
lest the dead and living seize you in retribution.
The fourth prohibition: Do not slander, envy, or deceive,
lest humans and ghosts bring you harm.
The fifth prohibition: Do not steal or cheat,
lest your conduct be degraded and diminished.
The sixth prohibition: Do not grieve, sorrow, or brood,
lest your essence and spirit become confused.
The seventh prohibition: Do not rage or indulge in excess,
lest your spirit scatter and disperse.
The eighth prohibition: Do not become drunk or licentious,
lest the Three Palaces collapse in chaos.
The ninth prohibition: Do not eat the five pungents or bloody flesh,
lest your viscera become foul and putrid.
The tenth prohibition: Do not suffer hunger, satiety, cold, or heat,
lest the hundred diseases attack and congeal.
The eleventh prohibition: Do not speak or laugh excessively,
lest your spirit and qi be depleted.
The twelfth prohibition: Do not gaze or listen for too long,
lest your ears and eyes become dim and clouded.
The thirteenth prohibition: Do not be filthy, negligent, or indolent,
lest your form and spirit become ugly and perverse.

These thirteen prohibitions are the great perils of the human body.
Uphold them, and you will live;
violate them, and you will die.
As Laozi said: “Those who follow life are thirteen;
those who follow death are thirteen.”
Does this not refer to these?
What is light is called a precept;
what is weighty is called a prohibition.
Prohibitions and precepts are the excellent prescriptions for aiding the body.
For those who study immortality, prohibitions and precepts are their armor.
Though they enter the three armies, blades and arrows cannot harm them.
Though they dwell in the world, disasters and misfortunes cannot enter.
Truly, these words are clear—let each be exhorted by them!

Thereupon, they read the tablets and confer the duties.

Upon completion, they rise and turn toward the incense burner, saying:
"Fragrant smoke and jade maidens, attending officials of the present watch—let it now be known that upon this dew-altar and within this hall of purification, hidden zhi-fungus and jade essence abide before this incense lamp. May we, your servants, attain immortality, our bodies adorned with purple networks and feathered patterns; may our households enjoy blessings, and all under heaven rejoice as one. O jade maidens who attend the altar and hall, transmit our words to the Three August Sovereigns."

Following the ritual, they ascend the altar, make their procession, and stand facing north. They knock their teeth thirty-six times and recite the *Shejing Invocation*:

Vast and boundless,
I seal the celestial writ on high.
I receive the divine script,
opening my address to the Three August Ones.
To the west, I tread the Golden Gate;
to the east, I ascend Fusang.
To the north, I traverse the Dark Yin;
to the south, I ride the True Yang.
Advancing, I mount the Great Horn;
retreating, I tread upon Wen Chang.
I wander between Kui and Lou,
roam and feast in the chambers of Shen and Fang.
I enter to serve the jade maidens;
I depart, escorting the Immortal Kings.
With heaven I share longevity;
with the sun I merge radiance.
The twenty-five qi sweep away misfortune and calamity.

They then knock their teeth twelve times and recite the invocation:

Fragrant smoke and jade maidens,
ascend to memorialize the Three August Sovereigns, the thirty-six celestial immortals, and the divine officials. The humble male servant, so-and-so, respectfully establishes the Cavernous-Dao Three August Ones Retreat for such-and-such prefecture, county, and matter. We now request your proper ascent to the altar, entry into the chamber, the burning of incense, and the opening of the rite. May this day’s petition swiftly ascend to the Purple Palace and be reverently presented before the Three August Sovereigns.

Upon offering the incense, they bow twice and say:
Your servant, having purified himself in retreat and severed worldly dust, burns incense and offers gratitude. On behalf of my seven generations of ancestors and parents, extending to my entire household, I beseech forgiveness for accumulated transgressions and bound sins, the dissolution of trials and lawsuits, the inscription of names upon the cinnabar tablets, and the fixing of characters upon the azure scrolls. May your servant, together with the gods of the Three Palaces, ascend the Mystic Dawn, attend the court of Supreme Clarity, behold the Sacred Sovereign, receive sacred writ and office, and forever become a lofty perfected one.

First, they pour the Celestial Sovereign’s wine.
Having done so, they bow twice and say:
Your servant now reverently invokes the Primordial Three Mysteries of the Void, the Heavenly Stem Jia-Zi, and the Original Sovereign of the Celestial August One. May you deign to descend and partake.

They continue:
Your servant, having purified himself in retreat and severed worldly dust, establishes the Cavernous-Dao Three August Ones Retreat for so-and-so, offering gratitude. Through this rite of pacing the Dao, burning incense, and presenting offerings, we sincerely implore the descent of the Primordial Three Mysteries’ true qi of the Celestial August One. For so-and-so’s person, we beseech the dissolution of all transgressions from past lives down to the present—offenses against the suspended images of Heaven, the sun, moon, and stars; defilement and disrespect toward their radiance; wrathful winds and clouds; the destruction and abandonment of sacrifices; and all violations against the numinous spirits—amounting to one thousand two hundred categories of misdeeds, that they may all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s fate be bound to the Celestial Bureau, their name inscribed in the Celestial Records, their life fixed upon the Celestial Tablet, their merits engraved upon the Celestial Pavilion. May all the gods of Heaven deign to shield and protect them, so that their illnesses be cured, their body become light and strong, their calamities be transcended, and their well-being preserved forever.

Next, they pour the Terrestrial Sovereign’s wine and bow twice, saying:
Your servant now reverently invokes the Three Primordials of Pure Numinosity, the Jade Heaven of the Celestial Stem Geng-Shen, and the Original Sovereign of the Terrestrial August One. May you deign to descend and partake.

They continue:
Your servant, having purified himself in retreat and severed worldly dust, establishes the Cavernous-Dao Three August Ones Retreat for so-and-so, offering gratitude. Through this rite of pacing the Dao, burning incense, and presenting offerings, we sincerely implore the descent of the Three Primordials’ true qi of Pure Numinosity of the Terrestrial August One, to come and assist so-and-so’s person. We beseech the dissolution of all transgressions from past lives down to the present—offenses against the essence of the Nine Earths of the Dark Land, the spirits of all hills, mountains, and water sources, metals, stones, grasses, trees, birds, beasts, and insects, and all acts of killing—amounting to one thousand two hundred categories of misdeeds, that they may all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s form be freed from the Earthly Bureau, their name erased from the Earthly Register, their po soul released from the Earthly Prison, and their spirit transcend the Earthly Realm. May all the gods of the Earth unite to shield and protect them, so that their illnesses be cured, their body become light and strong, their calamities be transcended, and their well-being preserved without end.

Finally, they pour the Human Sovereign’s wine.
Having done so, they bow twice and say:

Now I humbly invoke the Sevenfold Subtle, Vast and Profound, Empty Heaven’s Jia-Yin Void-Formed Human Sovereign True Unity Lord, praying that You deign to descend and partake of the offering.

Again, I say:
Having purified myself through fasting and cut off all worldly dust, I establish this Cavernous-Divine Three Sovereigns Retreat for so-and-so, and make this prayer of repentance. May the present rites of Dao, the burning of incense, and the offering of thanks be accepted.

The libation is poured, and with utmost sincerity I look up to summon the Human Sovereign’s Sevenfold Subtle, Vast and Profound true qi, that it may come to assist so-and-so’s person, beseeching the dissolution of all transgressions—from past lives down to the present—against human ethics, rites, loyalty, and filial piety; all sins of lewdness, greed, impurity, and falsehood; all faults of cruelty, oppression, and harm; and all offenses against gods and spirits. Amounting to one thousand two hundred categories of misdeeds, may they all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s years surpass the human norm, their wisdom stand above others, their virtue uphold the human order, and their reputation fill the world’s gaze. May all the gods among humanity unite to aid and sustain them, so that their illnesses be cured, their body become light and strong, their calamities be transcended, and their well-being preserved without end.

Then, nine cups of wine are poured toward the east, and twice they bow, saying:
Now I humbly invoke the Divine Lords and Perfected Immortals of the Nine Heavens of the Eastern Realm, praying that You all deign to descend and partake of the offering.

Again, I say:
Having purified myself through fasting and cut off all worldly dust, I establish this Cavernous-Divine Three Sovereigns Retreat for so-and-so, and make this prayer of repentance. May the present rites of Dao, the burning of incense, and the offering of thanks be accepted.

The libation is poured, and with utmost sincerity I look up to summon the Nine Qi of the Eastern Nine Heavens’ Verdant Jade City, where the dawn’s rosy clouds descend, to assist so-and-so’s person, beseeching the dissolution of all offenses—from past lives down to the present—against the Lords of the Nine Heavens, the Year Star Wood Spirit, the Azure Dragon’s Seven Lodges, and all stellar officials within and beyond the heavens; and all violations against the Eastern Marchmount, mountains, hills, mounds, rivers, seas, streams, and valleys, and all spirits therein. For so-and-so, during the spring months of the year, on the days of Jia, Yi, Yin, Mao, and Chen, when their age and destiny clash with inauspicious stars, encountering harm from malevolent forces, calamities, illnesses, afflictions of noxious winds and poisonous influences, weakness, and all forms of ruin, downfall, and misfortune—may they all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s person unite with the true qi in virtue, that radiant blessings flow like light, all misfortunes be extinguished, and their years and life be long.

Then, nine cups of wine are poured toward the north, and twice they bow, saying:
Now I humbly invoke the Divine Lords and Perfected Immortals of the Nine Heavens of the Northern Realm, praying that You all deign to descend and partake of the offering.

Again, I say:
Having purified myself through fasting and cut off all worldly dust, I establish this Cavernous-Divine Three Sovereigns Retreat for so-and-so, and make this prayer of repentance. May the present rites of Dao, the burning of incense, and the offering of thanks be accepted.

The libation is poured, and with utmost sincerity I look up to summon the Five Qi of the Northern Nine Heavens’ Dark Yin, Vast and Mysterious Palace, where flying mists descend, to assist so-and-so’s person, beseeching the dissolution of all offenses—from past lives down to the present—against the Lords of the Nine Heavens, the Chronographic Star Water Spirit, the Dark Warrior’s Seven Lodges, and all stellar officials within and beyond the heavens; and all violations against the Northern Marchmount, mountains, hills, mounds, rivers, seas, streams, and valleys, and all spirits therein. For so-and-so, during the winter months of the year, on the days and hours of Ren, Gui, Hai, Zi, and Chou, when their age and destiny clash with inauspicious stars, encountering harm from malevolent forces, calamities, illnesses, water swelling, diarrhea, blockages, distension, all afflictions of wind, and dangers of drowning—may they all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s person unite with the true qi in virtue, that radiant blessings flow like light, all misfortunes be extinguished, and their years and life be long.

Then, nine cups of wine are poured toward the west, and twice they bow, saying:
Now I humbly invoke the Divine Lords and Perfected Immortals of the Nine Heavens of the Western Realm, praying that You all deign to descend and partake of the offering.

Again, I say:
Having purified myself through fasting and cut off all worldly dust, I establish this Cavernous-Divine Three Sovereigns Retreat for so-and-so, and make this prayer of repentance. May the present rites of Dao, the burning of incense, and the offering of thanks be accepted.

The libation is poured, and with utmost sincerity I look up to summon the Seven Qi of the Western Nine Heavens’ White Radiance, Vast and Resplendent Palace, where flowing light descends, to assist so-and-so’s person, beseeching the dissolution of all offenses—from past lives down to the present—against the Lords of the Nine Heavens, the Great White Metal Essence, the White Tiger’s Seven Lodges, and all stellar officials within and beyond the heavens; and all violations against the Western Marchmount, mountains, hills, mounds, rivers, seas, streams, and valleys, and all spirits therein. For so-and-so, during the autumn months of the year, on the days and hours of Geng, Xin, Jia, You, and Xu, when their age and destiny clash with inauspicious stars, encountering harm from malevolent forces, calamities, illnesses, and all dangers of blades, arrows, weapons, bandits, bloodshed, and bodily injury—may they all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s person unite with the true qi in virtue, that radiant blessings flow like light, all misfortunes be extinguished, and their years and life be long.

Next, nine cups of wine are poured toward the south, and twice they bow, saying:
Now I humbly invoke the Divine Lords and Perfected Immortals of the Nine Heavens of the Southern Realm, praying that You all deign to descend and partake of the offering.

Again, I say:
Having purified myself through fasting and cut off all worldly dust, I establish this Cavernous-Divine Three Sovereigns Retreat for so-and-so, and make this prayer of repentance. May the present rites of Dao, the burning of incense, and the offering of thanks be accepted.

The libation is poured, and with utmost sincerity I look up to summon the Three Qi of the Southern Nine Heavens’ Vermilion Radiance, Cinnabar Terrace, where suspended light descends, to assist so-and-so’s person, beseeching the dissolution of all offenses—from past lives down to the present—against the Lords of the Nine Heavens, the Sparkling Deluder Fire Spirit, the Vermilion Bird’s Seven Lodges, and all stellar officials within and beyond the heavens; and all violations against the Southern Marchmount, mountains, hills, mounds, rivers, seas, streams, and valleys, and all spirits therein. For so-and-so, during the summer months of the year, on the days and hours of Bing, Ding, Ji, Wu, and Wei, when their age and destiny clash with inauspicious stars, encountering harm from malevolent forces, calamities, illnesses, ulcers, sores, fevers, epidemics, and all afflictions of heat, poison, and stings—may they all be dispelled and released. We pray that so-and-so’s person unite with the true qi in virtue, that radiant blessings flow like light, all misfortunes be extinguished, and their years and life be long.

When the four directions are complete, they recite:
The vast qi of the Three Heavens nurtures the myriad transformations.
Worldly sentiments delight in their blossoms, but the true Dao treasures their essence.
The foolish cling to fleeting glory, while immortals cherish the root.
With focused heart, I cultivate the Sovereign’s scriptures, and jade spirits illuminate the secluded chamber.
I chant high, awaiting the Great Subtlety, and bow my head to the Primordial Unity.

Then, they bow twice more. Turning again to face the north, they kneel and bow nine times, saying:

The humble disciples of the *Neijing* of the Three Sovereigns of the Cavernous Divine, petty subjects so-and-so and others, respectfully address and petition the Most High Dao Lord, the Most High Lord Lao, the Most High Elder, the Jade Lords of the Three Sovereigns, the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital, the Nine Qi Elders, the Immortal Officials of the Dark Capital, the True Spirits of the Great Mystery, the divine administrators of the thirty-six heavens above and below, the Heavenly Emperors of the Five Directions, the various spirit officials of the Great Clarity, the stellar officials of the twenty-eight constellations within and beyond, the True Lords of the Five Peaks, the assisting deities of the eight mountains, the spirits of the four seas, the four rivers, the eight marshes, the nine springs, and the grotto-palaces of the famous mountains, the hidden officials of the water deities, and all the myriad spirits within the cosmos:

We humbly present these words to the Upper Palace, submitting our petition. We, so-and-so, by virtue of our humble and base nature, dwell in the ranks of the common, yet by the grace of our ancestors’ blessings, we have encountered the true teachings of the precious scriptures and authentic methods. We have diligently followed their guidance, heeding their instructions in movement and stillness, and entering into goodness in our daily lives. This is not merely a blessing for ourselves alone but also a benefit extending to seven generations. Yet we, bound by mediocrity and entangled in worldly pursuits, have overstepped our limits and invited fault and regret. Moreover, the karmic retributions of our ancestors remain unresolved, and litigation persists. The three disasters still drive us, and a hundred harms arise in competition. Our qi and life are frail and perilous, compounded by frequent illnesses and misfortunes. Day and night, we are filled with dread, our livers and hearts trembling in distress.

We have observed that within the precious registers of the Jade Emperor’s fasts, there are chapters for prayer and gratitude, and within the inner methods of the Immortal Capital, there are rites for offering and invocation. Though these methods are lofty and wondrous, they are not restricted by rank or status. They can rescue and dispel calamities, prolonging and bestowing blessings. We, leading Daoist disciples numbering so many, have bathed in the waters of the dark clouds, purifying our body-spirits; we have abstained from the flavors of meat and grains, cleansing our viscera. We have hung the celestial silks of the azure groves, unfurling the cloud-script banners of the imperial texts. The incense pearls of the Upper Prime ascend far into the nine heavens, while the true persons burn the dark liquid’s smoke, illuminating the jade court of the dark and yellow. We have arrayed the four nines of lamps, mirroring the thirty-six heavens. With sweet wine and meager offerings, we invite the descent of the divine and mysterious. For three days and three nights, we have performed the Dao, repenting and entreating.

Now, at this time, we humbly beseech the August Lords and Heavenly Thearchs, the Most Sagely Fire Spirit, the celestial true spirits, and the supervising immortal officials to deign to issue commands to all subordinate offices and governing authorities, that they may heed our petition. We pray for the deliverance of the seven generations of our ancestors—our fathers and mothers—and the remaining departed souls of our kin, releasing them from the bonds of suffering and confinement, absolving their penal labors, and ending their banishment and toil. May they each return to dwell in the halls of fortune, enjoying leisure and joy, bestowing protection and benefit upon their descendants, ceasing litigation, and when their allotted years are complete, may they be reborn into wealthy and noble families among humankind, forever preserving peace and prosperity.

We beseech the heavenly officials, soldiers, and local deities of the communities and hamlets, along with the spirits of the current day and talisman, to surround and guard our dwellings, halls, and chambers. May they each expel and eradicate malevolent spirits, dispel ghostly afflictions, cleanse and wash away demonic influences, and proclaim the true qi. If the lingering qi of our deceased ancestors or the burial sites violate taboos, or if the dead and mourning qi are registered, or if within our halls, lodgings, or dwellings lie buried dry bones, the ghosts of deceased servants, or those who died from injury, misfortune, or wandering calamities, or if curses and oaths have drawn them, or if the innocent have met their end—all such deep-seated afflictions that give rise to misfortune—we pray for their resolution and release from litigation, separating the living and the dead into distinct realms.

From this year, month, day, and hour onward, for all three punishments, six harms, clashes and breaks, oppressive killings, the entanglements of the celestial years and Jupiter’s net, as well as blades and warfare, water and fire, illnesses and epidemics, poisonous creatures, bandits and villains, official summons and slander—all inauspicious deaths—we pray that from month to month, day to day, and hour to hour, they may be transmitted and resolved according to the matter at hand, ensuring that they pass without causing harm. May we and our kin forever enjoy reverence in public and private, forming bonds near and far, our Daoist practices flourishing and exalted, our true hearts achieving completion as the seed people, eternally receiving boundless grace and enjoying blessings to the utmost.

We, your subjects so-and-so, with utmost reverence and fear, prostrate ourselves, bowing our heads repeatedly to make this known.

Having prostrated thirty times with my forehead to the ground, I rise and bow again, then recite:

With focused heart I establish the fast,
burn incense and bow to the imperial script,
bathe in the dark clouds’ water,
and send up smoke to reach the Supreme Origin.
The fast is arrayed in four nines,
the Eight Emperors command the divine chapters.
I knock my heart and utter vows,
ascending to be heard in the Three Heavens.
The debts of seven generations are dissolved,
and the burdens of the deceased are entirely absolved.
Passing through the Five Paths,
erasing sins to become an immortal of the highest rank.
One day’s practice of this method
becomes the cause for ten thousand kalpas.
When the true Dao is accomplished,
then shall I behold the Three Sovereign Lords.

Again, I address the censer, saying:
May the jade maidens attending the fragrant smoke and the assembled officials
cause the hidden zhi-plants and jade essences upon this sacred altar
to appear before this incense flame,
that we may attain immortality, our bodies adorned with purple networks and feathered patterns.
May our household enjoy blessings,
and the world rejoice as one.
May the jade maidens attending the altar transmit our words
and report them fully before the Three Sovereign Divine Lords.

Facing north and entering the altar, I knock my teeth twelve times and pray:
May the jade maidens of the fragrant smoke
present this petition before the Three Sovereign True Lords,
the thirty-six celestial immortals and divine officials.
I, your humble servant, the male adept so-and-so,
on behalf of such-and-such prefecture and county,
for such-and-such matter,
have established the Cavern-Divine Three Sovereigns’ Fast.
I request and give thanks.

When the rites are complete, I ascend the altar and enter the chamber to burn incense,
declaring that the merit of this day shall ascend directly,
proceeding to the Purple Palace,
and be respectfully presented before the Three Sovereign True Lords.
After offering incense again, I bow twice more and say:
I have purified myself in fast and cut off worldly dust,
burning incense to offer reverence and thanks.
On behalf of my seven ancestors and parents,
and for my entire household,
I beseech that accumulated transgressions and bound sins be pardoned,
that the trials of the deceased be resolved,
that our names be inscribed on the cinnabar tablets,
and our characters fixed in the azure registers.
May I, so-and-so,
together with the gods of the Three Palaces,
ascend to the Mystic Dawn,
and present myself at the court of the Supreme Clarity,
to behold the Sacred Lord,
receive the scriptures and assume office,
and forever become a perfected immortal.

Facing the Heavenly Sovereign, I bow twice;
then facing the Earthly Sovereign,
and then the Human Sovereign,
I bow twice each, saying:
I, so-and-so, have purified myself in fast and cut off worldly dust,
establishing the Cavern-Divine Three Sovereigns’ Fast on behalf of such-and-such.
I request and give thanks.
When the rites are complete, may the sincerity of this incense offering and reverence
absolve the thousand transgressions and ten thousand faults
accumulated from my ancestors down to my present self,
causing them all to dissolve.
May my illnesses be cured,
my calamities averted,
and may I attain long life and transcend the world,
becoming one of the seed people.

Next, facing the four directions:
To the east, the Nine Celestial Emperor Lords and divine officials of the host of immortals,
I visualize in my heart and bow nine times, then twice more.
To the south, the Nine Celestial Emperor Lords and divine officials of the host of immortals,
I visualize in my heart and bow nine times, then twice more.
To the west, the Nine Celestial Emperor Lords and divine officials of the host of immortals,
I visualize in my heart and bow nine times, then twice more.
To the north, the Nine Celestial Emperor Lords and divine officials of the host of immortals,
I visualize in my heart and bow nine times, then twice more.

I have now purified myself in fast and cut off worldly dust,
establishing the Cavern-Divine Three Sovereigns’ Fast on behalf of such-and-such.
I request and give thanks.
When the rites are complete, may the sincerity of this incense offering and reverence
absolve the thousand transgressions and ten thousand faults
accumulated from my ancestors down to my present self,
causing them all to dissolve.
May my illnesses be cured,
my calamities averted,
and may I attain long life and enduring vision,
forever preserved from misfortune.

Again, facing north, I bow nine times, then twice more, saying:
I, your humble disciple, a minor adept of the *Inner Radiance of the Cavern-Divine Three Sovereigns*,
respectfully address the Most High Dao Lord,
the Most High Lord Lao,
the Most High Elder,
the Three Sovereign Jade Lords,
the Nine Elder Lords of the Immortal Capital,
the Nine Venerable Ones,
the Immortal Officials of the Dark Capital,
the True Gods of the Great Mystery,
the divine officials of the thirty-six heavens above and below,
the Celestial Emperors of the Five Directions,
the various gods of the Great Clarity,
the stellar officials of the twenty-eight lunar lodges within and beyond,
the True Lords of the Five Marchmounts,
the assisting deities of the eight mountains,
the gods of the four seas, four rivers, eight marshes, and nine springs,
the water spirits of the hidden palaces in the named mountains and cavernous grottoes,
and all the myriad spirits throughout the cosmos:
I, together with my fellow Daoist disciples numbering a thousand,
have bathed in the water of the dark clouds,
arrayed the lamps of four nines,
and modeled the rites upon the thirty-six heavens.
On this day of such-and-such month,
we have gathered to commence the fast,
and on such-and-such an auspicious day,
we shall perform the Dao for three days and three nights, twelve hours in all.

When the rites are complete,
may the words we have spoken and the petitions we have presented
be heard and responded to,
and may all our prayers and requests be met with compassionate grace.
The Three Sovereigns’ petition has received the Most High’s decree,
granting our requests as they come.
May the suffering souls of my seven generations of ancestors
be immediately delivered and ascend,
and from this day forth,
may my household flourish in prosperity,
forever secure and blessed,
with both public and private affairs harmonious.
May the merit of the fast be accomplished,
and may the various divine officials and attendants,
the jade maidens of the fragrant smoke,
the overseers of the fast,
the local deities of the land, cities, communities, and villages,
and those who assist and proclaim the rites
all be diligent in their duties.
I respectfully report their merit for promotion and reward,
repaying their labor and virtue.
May the ranks and grades we receive
conform to the statutes of the Dark Capital.

When the rites are concluded,
may each return to their proper office and attend to their duties as before.
Now, I dismantle the altar and remove the mats,
restoring all things to their original state.

I, so-and-so, have personally presented this petition,
extolling the divine canon.
Yet the nether paths are distant and profound,
the principles truly subtle and remote,
the methods wondrous and difficult to fathom,
and many errors and omissions may have occurred.
Moreover, my reverence may have been insufficient,
my heart and form negligent,
the fragrant smoke uneven,
the wine and fruit offerings meager.
The roots of these transgressions may incur hidden reprimands,
and in my private heart, I am filled with dread at the prospect of punishment.
I humbly beseech the Emperor and host of perfected beings
to grant compassionate understanding,
indulgently applying the Three Pardons,
and to absolve me of guilt and punishment.

Again, I knock my head to the ground and bow twice, then address the censer, saying:
May the jade maidens attending the fragrant smoke and the assembled officials
cause the hidden zhi-plants and jade essences upon this sacred altar
to appear before this incense flame,
that we may attain immortality, our bodies adorned with purple networks and feathered patterns.
May our household enjoy blessings,
and the world rejoice as one.
May the jade maidens attending the altar,
upon the completion of our fast,
report our merit before the Three Sovereign Divine Lords.

From *The Established Rites of the Three Sovereigns’ Fast*,
*Highest Mystery*, Scroll Forty-Nine. End.

**Scroll Fifty of the *Highest Mystery*: The Chapter on the Cinder-and-Charcoal Fast**

Before dawn, first perform the customary morning audience rites, then proclaim your office and title. Addressing the censer, say:

We reverently invoke the Supreme and Boundless Great Dao, the Most High Lord of the Dao; the Most High Lord Lao; the Most High Elder; the Supreme and Mysterious Ancient of the Ten Directions; the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthies; the Perfected and Great Sages who have attained the Dao; the Lords and Elders; the Heavenly Master, Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center; the High Ministers and Prime Ministers; the Four Directors and Five Emperors; and all the divine officials and spirits of the Three Realms.

We, mere insects and foul filth, most base and lowly, by some past blessing have been born into this great transformation. The Three Caverns govern the turning of the ages, and the true scriptures have descended into the world. The Three Masters have opened the path to salvation, bestowing upon us wondrous methods—golden writings and jade characters, the secret formulas of immortals.

On the day we received this Dharma, we vowed to exhaust our foolish sincerity, offering our very sinews and bones, to uphold the scriptures’ intent, proclaim the compassionate grace, assist our masters and elders, and widely aid both the hidden and the manifest, delivering all beings and saving heaven and humanity. Whatever petitions are brought before us, we dare not ignore or obstruct.

Now, with reverence, we present our petition, stating: The words of so-and-so are earnest and moving, truly deserving of pity. Following the instructions of the Heavenly Master, we join together to perform the Rite of Cinder and Charcoal. We expose our bodies in the central altar, bind our limbs, let our hair hang loose to cover our foreheads, and suspend our heads by the hair beneath the railing. In accordance with the *Numinous Treasure Fast of Great Atonement for the Lower Prime*, we burn incense and knock our heads to the ground, beseeching grace.

We pray that on such-and-such a day of such-and-such a month, at the numinous altar in such-and-such a prefecture, county, village, and hall—or in such-and-such a household—we may perform the fast of purification and atonement. We will kindle lamps to continue the light, illuminating all heavens. For three days and three nights, in each of the six periods, we will circumambulate the Dao, repenting and atoning for the sins of our household’s countless ancestors—from the billions of generations past to our parents, uncles, brothers, and all the departed, down to our own selves—across innumerable kalpas and boundless lineages.

In accordance with the fast’s regulations, we have bathed and purified ourselves in this household. We now humbly report this, reflecting that the Three Supreme Worthies, the Perfected of the Ten Directions, and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center will deign to witness our words. We pray that the officials of the Numinous Treasure, the mighty spirits attending the scriptures, the divine officials of the Three Realms, and the local earth gods will unite in purpose and strength to protect us and this household, young and old alike.

May they sweep clean the fast’s site, the hall, and the dwelling inside and out; exterminate demonic thieves; subdue the Four Māras; and grant us peace of mind and stability of spirit. May our thoughts be clear, heaven serene, earth bright, and our prayers ascend unimpeded. May the fast’s merit be perfected without obstruction.

Though we presumptuously partake of the Great Dharma and wear the tokens of the Perfected, we dwell amid the Five Defilements of this dusty world. Our Three Barriers remain unregulated, our Six Passions unrestrained. We rely on the precepts to restrain and govern ourselves. Following the fast’s regulations, we now recite the precepts’ solemn protocols, that all officials and participants may submit to the Dharma’s discipline. At dawn tomorrow, we will proceed with the rites as prescribed and make further reports.

Next, the *Three Hymns of Wisdom*:

**First Hymn:**
Wisdom arises from non-being,
radiant, transcending the Ten Directions.
It structures emptiness, towering in the mysterious firmament,
naturally drawing in fragrant currents.
Its wonders are beyond thought,
through emptiness, true and real interpenetrate.
Being is ultimately non-being,
non-being is not non-being.

**Second Hymn:**
Wisdom but observes the body—
this is the first step in learning the Dao.
Subtly entering the mysterious workshop,
it naturally records my spirit.
The Heavenly Worthy ever protects,
the demon kings pledge their guardianship.
Resplendent is the vajra body,
transcending the Most High Immortals.

**Third Hymn:**
Wisdom sprouts from the root of precepts,
in the true Dao, precepts are the master.
From this arise the Three Treasures,
revered and received by lofty sages.
Riding this deathless boat,
swiftly we cross the great expanse.
At this moment of reciting precepts,
all heavens come to bow.

From the *Jade Purity Precepts*.

Next, the Dharma Master turns to face east, toward the west, and recites the precepts. All bow to receive them.

The Heavenly Worthy addressed the Most High Lord of the Dao, saying: Today, we shall universally proclaim the Dharma’s sound to awaken all beings. For all men and women, we dissolve disasters, avert misfortunes, pray for blessings, deliver lives, and uproot the roots of suffering. May the living behold the Dao, escape the Eight Difficulties, and shed their bodies; may the dead rejoice, feast, ascend to heaven, and swiftly be reborn among humans as Wheel-Turning Sage Kings.

Those who perform fasts and seek the Dao must concentrate their minds. Receive the Ten Precepts with sincerity, remember them without fail, focus your thoughts in silent contemplation, and penetrate the natural. Do not let scattered thoughts disturb your form and spirit. Those who can do this should now listen attentively:

**First Precept:** Let the heart not harbor malice or jealousy. Do not breed hidden harm. Guard your speech and be cautious of transgressions. Let your thoughts dwell in the Dharma.

**Second Precept:** Uphold benevolence and do not kill. Pity and aid all beings. With boundless compassion, save and moisten all.

**Third Precept:** Uphold chastity and yield to righteousness. Do not lust or steal. Constantly practice good thoughts, sacrificing yourself to aid others.

**Fourth Precept:** Be free from lust and desire. Let the heart not wander. Uphold purity and caution, acting without stain.

**Fifth Precept:** Let the mouth be free of evil speech. Words should not be ornate or deceitful. Be upright within and without, avoiding transgressions of speech.

**Sixth Precept:** Reduce alcohol and moderate conduct. Harmonize qi and nature. Do not harm the spirit or commit manifold evils.

**Seventh Precept:** Do not envy those superior to yourself or contend for fame and merit. In all matters, yield and withdraw, putting others first.

**Eighth Precept:** Do not criticize the scriptures and teachings or slander sacred texts. Personally uphold the Dharma, ever as if facing the gods.

**Ninth Precept:** Do not engage in quarrels or disputes, nor criticize the Four Assemblies. Heaven and humanity will resent you, harming your spirit and qi.

**Tenth Precept:** In all actions and deeds, be equal and single-minded. Let harmony prevail among people, and peace among spirits. Always act thus.

The Heavenly Worthy said: Those who cultivate and uphold pure precepts accord with the heart of heaven. Constantly practice great compassion, vowing to deliver all beings. Universally save those in distress, reverently following the teachings without ceasing. Better to die guarding goodness than to live doing evil.

Thus, without regression, you may be delivered from the Five Paths, avoid the Three Evils, be protected by all heavens, and revered by the myriad spirits. By maintaining long fasts and upholding precepts, you will naturally attain deliverance from the world.

The Heavenly Worthy said: The Dao is revered and its dharma wondrous; the human body is likewise precious. Thus, the Dao unfolds its dharma, bequeathing precepts and scriptures to deliver the human form. Once the human body is delivered, it ascends to become one with the Dao. One should cultivate refined conduct, uphold fasts and precepts, pacify the heart and still the mind, keep aspirations and thoughts clear, direct the will single-mindedly, and maintain unwavering focus. Purify the six viscera, refrain from indulgence beyond moderation, and keep inner and outer realms pure and empty, ever in accord with the natural. On fasting days, when incense is lit and vows are made, the invocation rises upward, piercing the heavens. The patrolling deities of the Four Heavens and the mighty spirits of the Ten Divisions descend to tread the Dao-path, observing and listening to the dharma-sounds, mirroring the radiance of your heart. Those who uphold precepts and practice the Dao have their merits recorded in the heavens; fortune and misfortune manifest instantly. The Dao does not fail those who strive—diligently receive its truth and do not heed demonic words.

The Heavenly Worthy said: When establishing fasts and practicing the Dao, the Four Heavenly Emperor-Kings all ride cloud-borne chariots drawn by eight jade carriages of luminous scenes. Realized beings and jade maidens attend them, bearing floral banners. Phoenix songs lead the way, celestial melodies follow, while white cranes and lions roar in harmonious chorus. Incense burns and flowers scatter as they float through the void, coming to witness the Dao-practice and listen to the dharma-sounds. The Heavenly Kings descend, and the myriad spirits pay homage. How could one not fully embrace this dharma?

First, one must receive the Ten Precepts, then practice the Dao. Proceed with measured steps, a composed heart, and a serene mind. Whether sitting, rising, lying, or resting, never depart from proper decorum. The Heavenly Kings rejoice, and your name is inscribed in the Upper Clarity. This is truly attaining the Dao within the space of a single thought.

*(From the* Great Precepts Scripture*. Next: the incense-burner method.)*

The Incense Officials, the Left and Right Dragon-Tiger Lords, and all the attendant incense spirits shall cause the chamber to naturally produce golden liquid, cinnabar, and azure mushroom blossoms. The host of perfected beings and the hundred spirits will gather before this incense flame. May we, in receiving blessings for the world below, be graced with the favor of the ten directions. May the Golden Lads and Jade Maidens attend the incense smoke, transmitting our words directly to the presence of the Supreme Peerless Dao of the Most High.

*(From the* Scripture of Illuminating the Perfected*. Next: the offering of precepts and hymns.)*

The Dao is the heartless source,
The field where all blessings are sown.
Merit has no fixed master—
Each person’s vow is their own.
Empty the self to respond to all beings,
Focus the mind without partiality.
The Great Sage expounds the supreme teaching,
Like rain descending from heaven.
High peaks are all encompassed,
Yet the lowly become profound.
The sea is king of a hundred rivers,
For it contains the dragon’s scales.
Through ten thousand kalpas, wisdom is preserved—
How could it be limited to one’s years?
Uphold the precepts without the slightest lapse,
And in life after life, good affinities will form.
With concentrated thought, contemplate the Great Vehicle,
And you shall embody the true Dao.

*(From the* Scripture of the Divine Duke’s Inquiry*.)*

At dawn, proceed together into the altar, reverently paying homage to the master and contemplating the spirits as prescribed.

**Next: The Guarding Spirit Incantations**

**East:**
Nine qi of the Eastern Heavens, the Radiant Star of the Azure Sky, shining brightly, illuminating the nine gates of the eastern quarter, turning the candle of yang light to sweep away filth and dispel miasma. The Luminous Youth attends my chariot, binding demons and restraining spirits, reporting directly to the Celestial Lord. Upholding the true Dao, the vermilion script and jade texts, the talismanic commands of the Nine Heavens swiftly transmit the dragon’s dispatch. May all under heaven be pacified, and may I ascend as a flying immortal.

**South:**
Cinnabar Heaven of the South, where three qi flow with light, the blazing star turns its candle to illuminate the Great Yang. Above dwells the Vermilion Essence, the Luminous Divine Youth, commanding the fire soldiers to guard the three palaces. Severing evil and binding spirits, cutting down demon kings, as decreed by the Northern Emperor, with wind and fire surging through the eight directions. The ringing bells interweave, and none dare disobey. As the true Dao flows, I receive supreme merit, preserving heaven’s eternal existence for countless kalpas without end.

**West:**
The Heaven of Seven Qi in the West, where the Great White Star emits its essence, its light illuminating the Golden Gate, brightening the Great Darkness. Within resides the White Sovereign, known as the Divine Lord, guarding and pacifying to protect my form. Severing the roots of evil, the kingly Dao shines clearly. Palaces and dwellings are ordered, the three luminaries aligned. In harmony with nature, I ascend to the Purple Court. The talismanic commands of the Numinous Treasure universally benefit all beings, extending merit to all, bringing peace to heaven and earth.

**North:**
The Mysterious Heaven of the North, where five qi linger, the Star of Dawn shines brilliantly, illuminating the Supreme Subtlety. The Black Numinous Lord, clad in flying dark feathers, guards the five gates, inspecting essences and capturing wrongs. Should any dare to test, they shall be shattered and destroyed. As the jade talisman proclaims, the eight mights of the divine spirits seal the gates of evil and open the radiance of the true Dao, illuminating my body so that the three lights shine together. I ride the void and soar, my form ascending as a flying immortal.

**Center:**
The Yellow Center governs qi and unifies the mysterious and true. The Star of Stability emits its radiance, flowing brilliantly through the Nine Heavens. Twelve Luminous Youths of primordial qi and yang essence blaze with crimson smoke, illuminating the entire dwelling and my body, crushing a hundred evils and slaying ten thousand ghosts. The Central Mountain incantation universally applies, the five spirits pacify and guard, and my body ascends as an immortal.

**Next:** Strike the celestial drum twenty-four times.

**Next: The Incense-Burning Rite**

The Supreme Three Heavens, the True Primordial Three Qi, the Most High Lord Lao, summon forth the Three and Five Merit Officials within our bodies, the Left and Right Attendant Envoys, the Left and Right Incense-Bearing Dragon Courier Officers, the Incense-Attending Golden Lads, the Jade Maidens who transmit words and scatter flowers, the Thirty-Six Direct Talisman Officials of the Five Thearchs, and the Thirty-Six Daily Incense Officials. Let them emerge, arrayed in solemn attire, opening the gates.
