Guo Jia, styled Fengxiao, strategist of Emperor Wu of Wei.
These four: Attendants of the Central Stables.
Liu Bei, styled Xuande, Emperor of Shu.
Han Sui, styled Wenyue, defeated by Wei.
This one: Marquis of the Northern River.
Xu Shu, styled Yuanzhi, recommender of Zhuge Kongming.
Pang De, styled Lingming, general of Emperor Wu of Wei.
Xia Yu, styled Shidu, Supervisor of the Secretariat in Jin.
Wang Jia, a man of Shu, who refused to serve Gongsun Shu.
He Yan, styled Pingshu, Minister of Works of Wei, adept in *Laozi* and *Yijing*.
Li Guang, renowned general of Emperor Wu of Han.
Xie Jie, styled Zhonglian, Minister of Works in Jin.
These eight: Attendants of the Northern Emperor’s Dawn Court.
Wen Taizhen, named Jiao, Earl of Haijian, General of the Cavalry in Eastern Jin.
Du Yu, Chief Clerk, General Pacifying the South in Jin.
Kong Wenju, named Rong, of Lu, General of the Central Guard in the Later Han.
Tang Gu, Chief Clerk, Minister of Works of Wu.
Zhang Xiu, Marshal, General of the Central Guard in the Later Han.
Guo Changxiang, of Wuchang, Chief Clerk.
Hua Xin, Minister of Works of Wei, Marshal and Minister of War.
Yu Liang, styled Yuan’gui, Right Prohibited Attendant of the Dawn Court, Grand Marshal of Jin.
Sima Fenghuai, styled Zu’en, Grand Master of Ceremonies in Jin.
Xie Qieyu, named Kun, Left Prohibited Attendant, Grand Master of Ceremonies in Jin.
Xi Jian, formerly Marquis of Lingguan of the Southern Gate of Zhuyang of the Northern Emperor, now Chief Inspector of Gaoming, Minister of Works in Jin.
Yan Huai, styled Siji, Attendant of the Central Prohibited Dawn.
Liu Xiu, Emperor Guangwu of Han, Attendant of the Grand Prohibited Dawn.
Duke Wen of Jin, surnamed Ji, named Chong’er, Director of the Water Office and Controller of Destiny.
Duke Huan of Qi, surnamed Jiang, named Xiaobai, Gentleman of the Three Offices.
King Wu of Zhou, son of King Wen, named Fa, Ghostly Officer, Lord of the Northern Dipper.
Wu Jizha, son of King Shoumeng of Wu, uncle of Helü, Duke of Northern Brightness.
Xun Yu, styled Wenruo, Minister of Works of Han, Chief of the Guest-Friends.
Shao Shi, Duke of Southern Brightness, also called Duke of Eastern Brightness.
Emperor Gaozu of Han, Liu Ji, Chief of the Guest-Friends.
Xia Qi, son of Yu, Duke of Eastern Brightness, Master of the Dipper Lords.
Sun Ce, styled Bofu, elder brother of Sun Quan, Chief of the Guest-Friends.
Xu Zhao, Right Master of the Dawn.
Zhou Boren, named Ji, Marshal and Protector of the Central Capital in Jin.
King Wen of Zhou, Ji Chang, Duke of Western Brightness, Master of the Northern Emperor.
Emperor Xuan of Jin, Sima Yi, Chief of the Guest-Friends.
Cao Cao, Grand Tutor of the Northern Emperor, Emperor Wu of Wei.
First Emperor of Qin, Prime Minister of the Northern Emperor.
Qing Jia, Flame Emperor, of the Great Ting Clan, Lord of the Great Northern Emperor of Fengdu.

The above seventy-eight persons all held offices among the ghostly ranks.

**Register of Those Who Attained the Dao of Earthly Transcendents**

Wang Yan, Fan Qiang, Fu Huang, Xu Wei—
these four attained the Dao through martial liberation.

Bao Jing, styled Taixuan, of Langye, Governor of Nanhai in the reign of Emperor Yuan of Jin, transmitted the liberation method by the Yin Lord and attained the Dao.
Li Dong, of Qu’e, Libationer in the reign of Emperor Yuan of Jin, diligent and pure, attained the Dao—
these two attained the Dao through civil liberation.

Feng Yi, of Huayin, said by the Southern Transcendent: "Feng Yi attained the Dao and roamed the great rivers."
Qin Gao, said by the Perfected of Great Clarity: "Qin Gao rode a vermilion carp in the abyssal depths."

These two attained the Dao as Cavern-Abyss Transcendents.

He Chong, styled Cidao, Minister of Works in the Jin dynasty, possessed hidden virtue. Having already attained the Dao in the Southern Palace’s Cheng Hua Terrace, he received scriptures and journeyed to the midst of Mount Heng.

Li Guangli, General Ershi of the Han, possessed hidden virtue and practiced loyalty and filial piety. He attained the Dao and received transformation in the Southern Palace.

Xin Xuan, styled Yanqi, of Dinggu in Longxi, was the son of Xin Yin and the seventh-generation ancestor of Xin Pi. Devoted to the Dao and its practices, he drowned in the Qin River. The Queen Mother of the West and the Northern Emperor of Fengdu took pity on him and commanded the Three Offices to retrieve his remains, restore his form, and initiate him in the Southern Palace. Now he serves as Commander of the Eastern Sea, overseeing the marshals of the *yuan*-realm and governing the ghostly and divine affairs of Wu and Yue.

Bi Gan, uncle of King Zhou, was disemboweled for remonstrating and died on Mount Rong.

Li Shan, a retainer of the Later Han who carried his young master to escape calamity, dwells in Mount Shaoshi.

Wu Guang, who refused King Tang’s abdication and drowned himself.

Song Jin, the drifting woman who begged food for Wu Zixu and drowned herself.

These seven underwent refinement and transformation in the Southern Palace.

Xie Zhijian.
Wang Boliao.

The Purple Yang Master, a Cavalry Commander of Yue during the Han. He Miao, styled Shuda, younger brother of He Jin. Feng Liang of Nanyang’s Guangjun, who began cultivating the Dao at sixty. Lang Zong, styled Zhongsui, a native of Anqiu in Beihai, served as Magistrate of Wu. Wang Shuming. Bao Yuanzhi. The wife of Yin Gai. These nine followed the deer tracks to Mount Hua and became masters of the abyssal grottoes.

Zhang Zuchang, a native of Pengcheng. Liu Pinghe, a man of Jiujiang at the end of the Han, who traveled far practicing medicine to save others. Lü Zihua, a native of Shanyang, disciple of the Yin Lord and student of the Eastern Minister. Cai Tiansheng, a native of Shanggu, who in youth became the Whistling Father and received the Dao from the River Earl. Long Bogao, a man of the Later Han, originally a recluse, studied under the Master of Fixed Records. These five became masters of the grottoes beneath Square Mountain.

Du Qi, styled Guangping, a native of Duling in Jingzhao, who during the Jian’an era crossed the river to receive the Practice of Mysterious Whiteness, mastered invisibility, and dwelled on the eastern slopes of Great Mount Mao. One female disciple, Sun Hanhua, daughter of Sun Ben. One male disciple, Chen Shijing, Attendant Gentleman to Sun Xiu. Xu Zongdu, a native of Jinling and Marshal to Lü Ti, skilled in qi restraints. Yan Xiansheng, nephew of the Recluse Bu. Zhao Xi, Inspector of Youzhou during the Han, father of Zhao Su. These six came and went beyond the mountains.

Dou Qiongying, younger sister of Dou Wu. Han Taihua, elder sister of Han Anguo and wife of Li Guangli. Liu Chunlong, daughter of Liu Fengxian, Director of Imperial Clan Affairs during the Han. Li Xizi, grandmother of Li Zhong, Governor of Dongping during the Jin. Wang Jinxian, daughter of Wang Yan, President of the Secretariat during the Jin, and consort to the Mourned Crown Prince. Guo Shuxiang, mother of Wang Xiu. Zhao Sutai, daughter of Zhao Xi, Inspector of Youzhou during the Han. Zheng Tiansheng, aunt of Deng Bo. Xu Kedou, wife of the Director of Records Xu and daughter of Tao Cheng. Li Huigu, wife of Xiahou Xuan of the Qi. Zhang Jiangzi, younger sister of Zhang Ji of Xizhou. Shi Shunü, daughter of Shi Xu of Shanyang. These twelve were of lofty attainment and surpassing talent.

Huang Jinghua, daughter of Huang Qiong, Minister of Works during the Han, who received the mandate to instruct women in the Daoist arts. This one studied under the Lady of Harmonious Dawn, Perfected of the Nine Palaces.

Zhang Weizi, daughter of Zhang Qing, Grand Architect during the reign of Emperor Zhao of Han. Fu Lihe, daughter of Fu Jian, Attendant Gentleman and nephew of Emperor Huan. These two were placed in the Hall of Containing Perfection within the Palace of Easy Transitions.

Wang Shaodao, son of Wang Sui, Governor of Shanyang during the Han. Fan Shusheng, a native of Beidi, Gentleman of the Yellow Gates during the reign of Emperor Wen of Wei. Li Boshan, father of Li Chong, Magistrate of Baima during the Han. These three studied in the Leisurely Hall of the Youthful Prime Bureau.

Fan Shusheng Chong, a native of Liaoxi, Gentleman of the Secretariat during the Han, versed in geomancy. Li Zheng of the Wei’s end, a native of Henan, disciple of the Duke of Constant Dao, who first resided in Luoyang and later came to Square Mountain to quarry stone brains. These two served as supervisors.

Summer Fu, styled Ziye, a native of Chenliu and disciple of Tongbai. Zhou Aiyou, a native of Ancheng in Runan and daughter of Zhou Chang, Prefect of Henan. Zhang Taozhi, a native of Pei and mother of Zhu Yu, Metropolitan Inspector. These three served as Attendants of the Bright Morning.

Zhao Weibo, a native of Dongjun. Yue Changzhi, a native of Xianyang. Zheng Zhizheng, disciple of Dai Meng. Tang Gongfang, a native of Xishan in Shu and disciple of Li Babai. These four served as Assistants.

Liu Kuan, styled Wenrao, a native of Hongnong, who in the Later Han served as Governor of Nanyang, Minister over the Masses, and Grand Commandant. Renowned for his benevolent governance, at seventy-three he entered Mount Taihua to ingest cinnabar and later became Preceptor of the Youthful Prime Bureau, enfeoffed as Marquis.

Zhang Xuanbin, a native of Dingxiang, nominated as Abundant Talent during the reign of Emperor Wu of Wei. Skilled in expounding emptiness and non-being, he entered Mount Tianzhu and came to serve as Minister of Regulations and Prohibitions.

Chunyu Zhen, styled Shuxian, a native of Shangyu in Kuaiji, appointed as county magistrate during the reign of Emperor Huan. Later, he entered the mountains to ingest cinnabar and came to serve as Keeper of the Authority, Enforcer of the Law.

Liu Yi, styled Zixiang—*The History of the Later Han* records that Zixiang, a native of Yingchuan, made it his family’s practice to aid the poor with their wealth. He served as Governor of Chenliu, then resigned his post to enter the mountains, where he was ordained as Donghua and appointed to the office of Right Supervisor of Central Governance.

Han Chong, styled Changji, a native of Piling in Wu Commandery, who served as Magistrate of Wanling and later as Governor of Runan during the reign of Emperor Ming of Han. At seventy-four, he retired and entered Mount Dahuo, later returning to serve as Left Supervisor of Central Governance.

Tao Jun, styled Gongzhong, a native of Qiantang, who in his youth served as an aide in his commandery and later as Governor of Jiaozhi. He abandoned the world to enter Mount Zengcheng and attain the Dao, coming to hold concurrent office as Marquis of the Northern River’s Fourfold Prohibitions, stationed at the Huayang Grotto Palace beneath Maoshan in Juqu.

Chilu, originally surnamed Huang and named Chuping, was the Red Lord of the Southern Marchmount. He entered Mount Jinhua in search of his younger brother and there changed his surname and name.

Pei Jun, a retainer of Liu An, served as Assistant Magistrate of Jizhou before resigning his post to follow him.

Shutian Gong first dwelled beneath the willows by the northern stream of Mount Leiping—now called Tiangong Spring and Thunder. In Zhou times, he kept dragons on the eastern side of Mount Leiping.

The two younger brothers of Lord Zhou both recited the *Plain Book* ten thousand times over seven scrolls. Before completing it, they rose to watch a white deer and, upon returning, found the book gone. They then received other methods and attained immortality.

Zhang Zhaoqi, having compounded an elixir with others, dared not ingest it. He left the mountains and later consumed *fuling* to become an earthbound immortal.

Liu Fenglin, a man of Zhou times, failed thrice in compounding the elixir and remained on Mount Weiyu.

Shi Cunyi, styled Hugong and also known as Wanwengzi, was among the three thousand disciples of Confucius. He attained the Dao and mastery of transformation, receiving the Fire Talisman of Cyclical Movement. He resided on Central Marchmount and Mount Shaoshi—he was the master of Fei Changfang.

Xie Yun, a native of Liyang and disciple of Dai Meng, attained the Dao during the reign of Emperor Cheng of Jin.

Dai Meng, originally surnamed Yan and named Ji, styled Zhongwei, entered Mount Huayin and Mount Wudang at the end of Emperor Ming’s reign. He received the Jade Pendant and Golden Cauldron Scripture from Pei Jun, as well as the Stone Essence and Golden Light Talisman. He also possessed the *Yellow Writ of the Grand Tenuity* and could traverse all the famous mountains. He claimed only to have attained deathlessness, not true immortality.

Jiang Bozi and Zheng Siyuan were disciples of Ge Xuan. In the first year of Yongkang of Jin, they entered Mount Kuocang and departed.

Ge Xuan, styled Xiaoxian, a native of Jurong in Danyang, first resided on Mount Chang and later entered Mount Gaizhu. Skilled in transformation and illusion, he could ride tigers and command ghosts, reaching everywhere. He nearly received an official appointment.

Xie Zhijian—one account places him as Grotto Master on Mount Luji. Another states he compounded an elixir with Mao Bodao but dared not ingest it. Yet another claims he often accompanied Ge Xuan.

Guo Shengzi and Huang Ziyang—one account says they were men of Wei who ate peach bark and served Sima Jizhu. Another claims they often followed Ge Xuan.

Weng Daoyuan and Jiang Bozhen—one account says they studied the Dao and gathered herbs on Mount Meng, where an immortal instructed them to face the sun and rectify their minds. Another states they took *shinao* from the northern side of Mount Fang. Yet another calls them disciples of Xu Yuanyou.

Xu Mai, styled Shuxuan and originally named Ying, later changed his name to Yuanyou. He was the third elder brother of the immortal Marquis Tongsheng. From youth, he loved the Dao, abandoning his home to wander the mountains of Lin’an’s western range. Later, he entered Red Mountain, where he passed three trials, then moved to Mount Gaizhu. Ordained as Donghua, he became an earthbound immortal.

Long Youjie and Li Kailin—these two were friends of Xu Yuanyou.

Zhao Daoxuan and Fu Taichu—these two crossed the river and entered Red Mountain in Linhai, later followed by Xu Yuanyou.

Wang Shilong, the master of Xu Yuanyou.

Chen Zhonglin, Xu Dao, Ju Linzi, and Zhao Shudao—these four entered Mount Zhuye at the end of the Han.

Liu Gang’s wife was skilled in qi restraints and summoning. Yan Qing was adept at summoning and restraints.

Jie Yan, disciple of the White Ram Lord, was killed by Sun Quan but underwent corpse liberation and departed to Mount Fang in Jian’an. He, too, was skilled in restraints and summoning.

The White Ram Lord was a disciple of the Western Marchmount Lord.

Jie Xiang, a man of Wu times, was skilled in qi restraints and consumed *gancao* pills.

Liu Gen was adept at summoning and restraints, having received and consumed *gancao* pills.

Cui Wenzi was skilled in using medicines to cure illnesses.

Shangqiuzi, a native of Gaoyi, herded swine and consumed *changpu* to avoid aging.

Jiqiuzi, during Emperor Wu’s reign, resided beneath Mount Tai.

Xiu Yanggong, during Emperor Jing’s reign, transformed into white stone on a terrace.

Liang Boluan, named Hong, a man of the Han’s end, vanished into the seacoast.

Liu Shaoweng entered Mount Taihua, where he attained the Dao through reverence and ritual.

Fan Qiulin, wife of Wei Xingdao, General of the Tower Ships during the Han, was protected by Zhao Cheng, Assistant for Longevity, and received instruction from the Master of the Six *Jia*.

Tang Gongcheng of Mount Heming.

Zhang Jilian, Zhao Shuda, and Guo Zihua.

These three men sought to study under the Lord of Destiny on Mount Huo.

Diao Daolin, master of Long Bohao of Fangshan.

Zhou Zhengshi, master of Liu Ping’a of Fangshan.

Deng Yunshan, Tang Lan of Xihe, Lord Ji, who was likely Zixun, and also master to Zhang Li of the prohibitions.

Zheng Zizhen, grandson of Kangcheng, resided on Mount Yangzhuo.

Dongguo Youping, a man of the Qin era, long concealed on Mount Cheng where he attained the Dao, and became master to Taobei of the He.

Huichezi, master to Chunyu Dianbing.

Master of Qinggu, master to Master Liu Shang.

Shi Changsheng, master to Zhou Mingchen.

Master Redbeard, master to Xia Mingchen.

Lord Shantu, master to Zhang Jin, Grand Master of the time of King Ai of Zhou.

Immortal of the Grotto of Linwu, Wang Zhang, attendant to King Zhuang of Chu, who received arts from Lord Wang Han, master to Zuo Jian.

Elder Dragon Might, envoy of King Helü of Wu, who entered the cavern of Mount Bao and obtained the Five Talismans.

Lu Sheng, Hou Gong, and Shi Sheng—these three were sent into the sea by the First Emperor of Qin.

Zhi Ziyuan, master to the young Daoist Pei Jun.

Master Jiang, master to Zhi Ziyuan.

Crown Prince Zhao, who received and consumed wooden pellets.

Bian Que, who treated Crown Prince Zhao.

Zirong, Ziming, Ziyi, Zixi, and Ziyou—these five were disciples.

Master Li of Mount Song, master to Yue Cheng.

Immortal Song Laizi of Mount Song, formerly Market Chief of Chu, who encountered Feng Yanshou.

The above one hundred thirty-nine persons, all earthbound immortals of known names, had cultivated inner yin virtue and practiced loyalty and filial piety outwardly. Yet as their worldly merits remained incomplete, they could not ascend to the Three Realms but were instead appointed as earthbound immortals, with further promotion contingent upon separate time limits.

**Names and Ranks of Earthbound Perfected Daoists**

Perfected Fan Ziming, master to Zhang Li of the prohibitions.

Zhu Jiaofu of the Whitewater Immortal Capital.

Lady Zhu of Duling and Lady Song of Yi’an—these two both received the Azure Essence Formula from the Perfected of Western Liang but were not recorded with official titles. It is unknown what rank of immortal they attained, so they are provisionally listed among the earthbound perfected.

Luo Yu, Female Perfected of Mount Jiuyi, who descended in the reign of Shengping. Yang Quan called herself E Lühua and now resides on Mount Xiangdong, having lived for nine hundred years.

Zuǒ Yuanfang, named Ci, a man of the Han and Wei eras, disciple of Li Zhongfu. Having consumed the Ninefold Splendor Elixir of the furnace and fire, he came to the Huayang Cavern in the early Jin and, after many years, emerged. He has now received appointment as Jade Perfected of Shangdang.

Meng Junjing of Jingzhao and Lu Nüsheng of Mount Song—these three, along with the Jade Perfected, practiced the Way of the Five Pecks of the True One.

Xu Huya, named Cong, styled Yuanhui, second son of the Immortal Marquis. Having settled his faith and devotion, he served as Magistrate of Yongkang County, then as Assistant to the Chamberlain for the Palace Garrison and Marshal for State Aid. He received the Way of Guarding the One from Master Yang.

Fu Daoliu, a man of Beidi, General of the Palace Hall during the reign of Emperor Ling of Han. Yan Chengsheng of Wu and Liu Xuan of the Gengshi era were born as Prefect of Wudang.

Li Shusheng, a man of Zhuo Commandery, born in the reign of Emperor Yuan of Han.

Jia Xuandao, a man of Hedong, born in the reign of King Wei of Zhou.

These four all attained earthbound perfection and, on Mount Xiaoyang of Mount Tai, received the command of the Eastern Minister of Destiny to examine and instruct those studying the Dao.

Fan Anyuan.

Xun Zhonghou, whose name is not recorded.

Wang Fuzi, Guardian of the Three Offices’ Great Judiciary, equivalent to the present-day Supervisor of the Court of Judicial Review.

Li Feng, Chief of the Three Offices’ Great Judiciary, formerly Secretariat Director of Wei, who served Sima. These four oversee the prisons of the Three Offices, equivalent to the present-day Chamberlain for Law Enforcement.

Bao Yuanjie, a man of Donghai, Marquis of Mount Tai, who oversees the Right Prohibitions Bureau of Mount Feng and commands the spirits and gods, supervising the Two Offices and examining and instructing those studying the true Way.

Mao Zhong, styled Sihe, youngest brother of the Lord of Destiny. Though his practice was the same as that of the Middle Lord, he received the scriptures as Controller of the Three Offices’ Lifespan Protection Bureau. He governs the northern cavern entrance of Mount Liangchang, guards the gate of the Dark Palace, oversees Mount Tai, records life and death, exhorts and guides the young, and governs the laws of the hundred ghosts.

The Lord of Fixed Records has already ascended to the Grand Clarity.

Mao Zhong and the other two oversee the supervision of the Three Offices and instruct male and female students.

**Names and Ranks of Daoists of the Nine Palaces**

Xu Zhao, styled A, seven-times-great-grandfather of the Immortal Marquis, formerly in Fengdu as Right Master of the Dawn of the Eastern Brightness.

Xu Fu, styled Zhongxian, father of the Immortal Marquis, formerly in Fengdu as Marquis of Danfang.

These two, after the Immortal Marquis cultivated the Great Cavern, have both ascended to fill vacancies among the immortals of the Nine Palaces.

You, Duke of Shao, Grand Protector to King Cheng of Zhou, younger brother of the Duke of Zhou, enfeoffed in Yan. Formerly in Fengdu as Lord of the Southern Brightness, he had not yet fulfilled his time limit but had accumulated much yin virtue, so he was first promoted to fill this position.

Sun Deng and Mi Changsheng—these two were disciples of Zhou Taibin.

Lord of the Western Marchmount, Huang Luzi, surnamed Ge, named Yue, a man of the prohibitions. Skilled in qi prohibitions, he could summon dragons and command tigers. Later, he rode a dragon to ascend to heaven and transmitted his talismanic arts to his disciples.

Lord Red Sheep, Zhu Ruzi, who in the final years of Wu entered Mount Chishui and consumed chrysanthemum flowers and wooden essences. Having received the method of internal visualization of the Mud Pill from Master Xigui, he was summoned by the Queen Mother of the West to reside on the Terrace of Accumulated Stones.

Yu Wengsheng, a man of Kuaiji, who in the time of Wu entered Langwu Mountain in the sea. Having received from Master Jie the method of consuming solar essence and the Way of Cloud Qi and Returning Form, he was summoned by the Great Emperor to reside on Mount Yanggu.

Zhao Guangxin, a man of Yangcheng, who in the final years of Wei came to Mount Xiaobai. Having received the method of consuming qi and guarded the Way of the Mysterious Center for seventy or eighty years, he later compounded the Ninefold Splendor Elixir. After consuming it once, he was summoned by the Lord of the Great One to reside in the Eastern Florescence.

Ping Zhongjie, a man of Hedong, who came to Mount Kuocang. Having practiced the Mysterious Heart and possessed the hundred spirits, he cultivated the Cavern Chamber for forty-five years. The Yellow Elder of the Center summoned him to reside in the Numinous Terrace of Canglang.

Zheng Jingshi and Zhang Chonghua, both men of the early Jin, together entered Mount Qian where they received and practiced the method of guarding the Five Viscera and consuming solar essence, consuming sesame and Mysterious Elixir. The Northern Mystery Elder and the Great One dispatched messengers to welcome them to the Dark Continent.

Zhang Lizheng, a man of the late Later Han, and Zhi Mingqi, a man of the late Wei—these two together entered Mount Heng where they received the Rainbow Radiance Elixir of Perfected Wang. After forty-three years of accumulation and thirty years of guarding the One, the Eastern Florescence dispatched messengers to welcome them to the Recitation Chamber of Fangzhu as Upper Transcendents.

Yin Qianzi, Zhang Shisheng, and Li Fanghui—these three were all men of the reign of Emperor Wu of Jin. Together they entered Mount Hua where they received the method of steaming and consuming elixirs, practicing the Way of Vermilion Radiance for fifty years. The Great One dispatched messengers to welcome them to the Dark Continent as Lofty Transcendents, with Shisheng becoming the Lord of the Source.

Deng Boyuan and Wu Wangxuanfu of Pei—these two together entered Mount Huo where they consumed Azure Essence Stone Meal, swallowed solar radiance, and contemplated the Cavern Chamber for twenty-four years. The Great Emperor dispatched messengers to welcome them to the Northern Mystery Garden Terrace, where they received scriptures and became Middle Perfected.

Guan Chengzi, Master of Sumen, and Zhou Shouling—these three were the masters of Qianzi and his companions.

Meng Deran was the master of Jingshi and his companions.

Song Junping was the master of Zhongjie.

Li Facheng was the master of Guangxin.

These six, though masters of those who came after, may have ascended to the Grand Clarity or remained as Earthly Transcendents or Earthly Perfected—none can be definitively ranked. Though they were teachers to later practitioners, their cultivation and attainment of the Dao were not necessarily superior.

Zhuling Pin, Ding Shuying, and Madame Du Zong—these three were devoted to practicing hidden virtue.

Lady Xie Chen and Huang Jinghua—these two dwelled in the midst of change.

Wende, Right Transcendent Overseer Zhang Shuyin, who received the Azure Essence method.

Transcendent Lord Xin Yanyun of the Hu clan, named An, disciple of Perfected Tan Chi.

Stone Transcendent Duke Wang Yao, of the Hu clan and surnamed Zhu, named Shi, disciple of Perfected Bin Chi.

Left Transcendent Duke Guo Sichao of Yan, whose four brothers all attained the Dao. Sichao, the eldest, first governed Juqu, oversaw the Three Bureaus, and led the Six Hundred Morning Lords of Luofeng for six hundred years. Upon completion of his term, he ascended to fill a vacancy in the Nine Palaces, becoming Left Transcendent Duke and overseer of the Jade Terrace, wielding the canopy as Attendant Gentleman.

Perfected Yu Yin Zhang of Shangluo, who received the Azure Essence method.

Right Perfected Duke Guo Shaojin, compiler of the Licorice Pill.

Right Guardian Duke Zhan Shanggong, a man of the Gaoxin era, who planted plums in the Hidden Dragon land.

One Minister of State, ascended to the Grand Ultimate.

Two Upper Ministers of the Nine Palaces, ascended to the Upper Clarity.

The aforementioned forty-one individuals attained the ranks of Middle Perfected and Transcendents of the Nine Palaces. Some may have advanced to the Grand Clarity or Grand Ultimate, while others may yet remain as Earthly Perfected. Thus concludes the eighty-third scroll of *The Supreme Secret Essentials*.

Thus concludes the eighty-fourth scroll of *The Supreme Secret Essentials*.

The Register of Names of Daoists of the Grand Clarity

**Celestial Beings:**
Flying Celestial Elder, Supreme One of the Central August, Jade Youth of the Mysterious Upper, Fierce Beast Master—these four govern the mountains, rivers, ghosts, spirits, birds, and beasts of the world. They are spontaneous deities, not attainable through mortal study.

**Regional Deities:**
Elder of the Western Marchmount, Jade Youth of the Three Heavens, Divine Maiden of the Luo River—this last is likely Fufei. These three may be attained through mortal study.

**Five Marchmount Lords:** This office rotates every five hundred years.
**River Lords:** The River Earl, the River Earl’s Young Maiden—neither are necessarily born of wombs but manifest through transformation. These three are filled by those who have attained the Dao.

**Five Emperors of the Grand Clarity:**
- **Eastern:** Lingweiyang, Spirit of Awesome Might
- **Western:** Yaopobao, Treasure of Radiant Soul
- **Southern:** Chifiaonu, Crimson Whirlwind Archer
- **Northern:** Yinhouju, Hidden Marquis of the Curved Bow
- **Central:** Hanzhushu, Pivot of the Containing Axis

Each commands the Five Directions’ Celestial Ministers, Jade Maidens, and hosts of spirit officials. These Five Emperors of the Grand Clarity are spontaneous deities, not subject to the control of the Grand Clerk.

**Five Directional Celestial Emperor Lords:** Twenty-four Palace Lords, with twenty-five generals and officials to correspond to the twenty-five spirits within the body, and one thousand two hundred Palace Lords with their generals and officials. These are all formed through the coagulation of qi, not attainable through mortal study.

**Messengers:**
- Soaring Flight Messenger
- Nine Dragons Messenger
- Nine Heavens Perfected King Messenger
- High Transcendent Celestial Summoner Messenger
- Wandering Celestial Messenger
- Grand Clarity Messenger
- Six Yi Messengers
- Six Bing Messengers
- Six Ding Messengers
- Six Ren Messengers
- Six Gui Messengers

These eleven messengers are largely spontaneous deities, not all products of worldly study.

**Generals and Commanders:**
- Four Highest Generals, leading one hundred thousand troops of the Celestial Emperor
- Mountain-Penetrating Messenger, commanding one hundred thousand troops of the Celestial Emperor
- Celestial Valiants
- Heavenly Ding Valiants

These four generals command the celestial armies.

**Jade Maidens:**
- Four Jade Maidens of the Register of Ascending Heaven
- Four Jade Maidens of the Upper Heavens
- One Hundred Jade Maidens of the Three Heavens
- One Hundred Grades of Jade Maidens
- Jade Maidens of the Northern Palace
- Jade Maidens of the Five Emperors
- Jade Maidens of the Grand Simplicity
- Ten Jade Maidens of the Azure Waist Office
- Jade Maiden of the Azure Heaven’s Life-Bestowing
- Heavenly Advent Jade Maiden
- Level Heaven Jade Maiden
- Ten White Simplicity Jade Maidens
- Six Wu Jade Maidens
- Divine Elixir Jade Maiden
- Jade Maidens Attending the Five Streams

These fifteen are titles of Jade Maidens and spirit maidens.

**Ladies:**
- Five Transcendent Ladies
- Lady of the Inner Guo Clan

These two are titles of ladies.

**Elders:**
- Elder of the Hundred Spirits’ Qi
- Great Man of the Hundred Thousand Spirits’ Qi
- Great Man of Eternal Peace
- Elder of the Nine Paths
- Flying Perfected Elder
- Life-Bestowing Elder
- Great Qi Elder
- Southern Upper Elder
- Northern Upper Elder

**Grand Clarity Deities:**

These three hold the most venerable positions of the Grand Clarity but do not govern the myriad people.

The aforementioned ninety-nine entries are but a brief register of positions within the Grand Clarity. Some lack names or records of virtue and deeds; some may be attained through worldly study, while others are spontaneous deities.

Ge Hong compounded the Grand Clarity’s Golden Liquid on Mount Luofu and, consuming it, vanished in transcendence.

Le Ba, Grand Administrator of Yuzhang and Guiyang during the Later Han, cultivated the Way of the Sword and Liberation through Disintegration, entering Mount Heming.

Bao Cha, a native of Shangdang and a fifth-generation descendant of Bao Xuan, received the Dao from Perfected Lord Wang.

Hua Ziji, a native of Jiujiang, received the Divine Treasure Red Goblet method from Master Jiaoli.

Bo He, styled Zhongli, disciple of Wang Xicheng, received the Three August Celestial Writings and the Grand Clarity Elixir method.

Xu Fu, a man of the Qin dynasty.

Yin Gui, styled Gongdu, a man of the Jin dynasty, skilled in boiling stones.

Zhang Jujun, who transmitted the *Yi* method to Xu Jishan.

Hei Yu, likely Mo Di.

Xu Fu and these four others all appeared as two stars.

Wang Lu, Gate Captain of Wei Mingdi, husband of Fan Wang Bogang’s daughter.

Zhao Aier, a former aide to Governor Liu Yu and sister of Zhao Gai of Yuyang.

Guo Shaoyao, General of Wave-Crossing in the Han dynasty and daughter of Guo Qian of Dongping.

These three all practiced the Way of the Numinous Flight and the Six Jia Spirits.

Qiu Jizi swallowed golden liquor, its fragrance wafting a hundred li.

Master Deerhide swallowed Jade Blossom, and insects flowed from his body.

These two both achieved liberation through disintegration by ingesting the elixir.

Xu Jidao received the Five Spirit Affairs from an immortal.

Zhao Shuqi sought a diviner and received the *Record of the Essence of the Womb*.

Master Zhou received the seven-scroll *Plain Writings* of Lord Lao and attained the Dao after reading them ten thousand times.

Guo Shengzi, a diviner in the Luoyang market.

Guo Chongzi, disciple of Master Peng, who censured evil men.

Liu Weidao of Zhongshan, who ingested the golden elixir.

Zhuang Bowei, who concocted and ingested the golden distillate.

Li Ming, who compounded the elixir beneath Mount Juqu and ascended to the Dark Pearl Continent.

Liu Daogong and Mao Boda, who together compounded the elixir, feigned death, and became immortals.

King Zhao of Yan, Ning Zhongjun, Zhang Zifang, Zang Yanfu, Liu Zixian, and Zhao Boxuan—these six all ingested the elixir, achieved liberation through transformation, and became immortals.

Chi Jiangzi, a man of the Yellow Emperor’s time, received the Mountain-Restraining Talisman from the Duke of the Western Marchmount and also practiced the Fire Method.

Master Green Crow, who dwelled on Mount Huang—these two were disciples of Master Peng.

Dongfang Shuo, who ingested the Primary Spirit Pellet and served Emperor Wu of Han.

Fang Ming, Li Mu, and Chang Yu—these three were ministers of the Yellow Emperor.

Ning Feng ingested stone brain and entered fire, achieving liberation through fire.

The Eight Lords of Huainan were the Eight Elder Masters.

Dongyuangong, Qiliji, Xia Huanggong, and Jiaoli Xiansheng—these four were the Four Hoary Ones of Mount Shang.

Yue Zichang of Qi, who in the time of King Qiang of Wu received the Five Numinous Talismans of Han Jun, then disseminated the Celestial Writings and concealed them in Mount Laoshen in the Eastern Sea, where they were obtained by the King of Wu.

Han Zhong, a man of the Qin dynasty, became an immortal of Mount Huolin.

Feng Gang, who could prepare medicine to revive the dead.

Peng Jian, a man of the Yin dynasty, skilled in the Way of the Bedchamber, who transmitted the Way to Perfected Lord Peng.

Yin Changsheng of Nanyang, who studied under Master Ma and received the Great Clarity Elixir Method.

Ma Mingsheng of Linzi, who encountered the Grand Perfected Lady and received the Spirit Pellet, then studied under Anqi Sheng, ingested the Great Clarity Elixir, lived for five hundred years, and departed.

Mo Di of Song, skilled in mechanical arts, who swallowed rainbow cinnabar and entered water, seemingly achieving liberation through water.

Qin Shuyin of Fengyi—these two were the Immortal Elders of Mount Hua.

Liu Qianshou of Pei, the Immortal Elder of Shaoshi and Gentleman of the Northern Terrace.

Zhao Zuyang of Zhuo Commandery, the Perfected Elder of Mount Qian.

Zhang Shanggui of Chu, the Immortal Marquis of Mount Jiuyi.

Master White Stone, who prepared the Stone-Boiling Formula, was the Left Immortal Minister of the Eastern Flower.

Zhou Dabin and Jiang Shumao—these two men of Qin were the Left Ministers of Penglai.

Jia Bao of Anzheng, the Right Duke of Penglai.

Song Chensheng and Zhang Li, who together discussed emptiness, were the Left Duke of Penglai.

Li Baozu of Mount Min, who received the Azure Essence □ Meal, was the Right Duke of Great Clarity.

Wang Daoning of Changshan, who oversaw the recording of good deeds in the West.

Ji Baoju, who studied the Way under the Perfected Man of the Bo Family, was the Left Prohibition Gentleman.

Mao Jiwei, who practiced the *Upper Clarity and Lower Perfection* scriptures, ingested the Ninefold Cyclical Elixir of the Supreme Ultimate, received the writings, and became an Upper Perfected of the Earthly Realms, the Perfected Man of Juqu, and the Right Prohibition Gentleman of the Registers.

Shan Shiyuan of Jin, who transmitted prophecies and apocrypha, was the Perfected Man of Great Harmony.

Wei Xianren, the Perfected Man of Daliang.

Yin Youzong, the Perfected Man of Mount Min.

Han Weiyuan, who received the Numinous Flight of the Six Jia Spirits from Song Dexuan, was the Perfected Man of Mount Jiuyi.

Master Hongya, the Perfected Man of Mount Qingcheng.

Master Fu, the Perfected Man of the Southern Marchmount.

Feng Yanshou, the Perfected Man of the Western Marchmount.

Meng Zizhuo, the Perfected Man of the Central Marchmount.

Song Dexuan, a man of the Zhou dynasty, who practiced the Way of the Numinous Flight, was the Perfected Man of the Central Marchmount.

Gaoqiuzi, the Perfected Man of the Central Marchmount.

Yanmenzi, the Immortal Minister of the Middle Prime.

Shudu Hu, surnamed Kang, named Xian, who studied under the Red Lord, was the Western Gatekeeper of the Five Marchmounts.

Deng Lizhi, who studied under the Red Lord, was the Immortal King of Lesser You.

Li Yuanrong, who studied under the Red Lord, was the Immortal King of Great Clarity.

Zhao Chezi, the Immortal King of Great Clarity.

Mao Chucheng, also named Benchu, the High Merit Lord of the Controller of Destinies, who studied under Master Guigu, entered Mount Hua to cultivate the Way, then rode clouds and drove dragons to ascend to heaven in broad daylight.

Master Guigu, a man of the Zhou dynasty, who dwelled in Ghost Valley on Mount Chengyang.

The Perfected Man of Orthodox Unity, the Master of the Three Heavens’ Methods, Zhang Daoling, who cultivated the Way and, in the first year of the Han’an era (renwu year), on the first day of the fifth month, had immortals descend from the immortal palace on Mount Heming to bestow upon him the teachings of the Orthodox Unity and the Covenant of Might, along with the methods for transforming and guiding the people. These teachings have spread to the present day and are known as the Celestial Masters. His wife also attained the Dao and became a female master. Their grandson Lu inherited and transmitted the Way, and Emperor Wu of Wei honored him as General Who Pacifies the South. On the night when the true transmission was received, the cloud-borne Zhang, the Pacifier of the South, achieved liberation—this is what is meant by "lineage master."

He had twenty-four disciples, among whom Wang Chang and Zhao Sheng were the foremost; the others are not well known.

The above eighty-five individuals are those whose names, deeds, and traces as middle-grade immortals of Great Clarity are roughly evident—today, they too should ascend to the Supreme Ultimate.

**Attained the Supreme Ultimate Perfected and Immortal Ranks**

Wei Bianlang Zhuang Zhou, who received the esoteric teachings of Chang Sang, composed the Inner and Outer Chapters, concealed himself on Mount Baodu, ingested the Fire Elixir, and ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Chang Sang the Noble, teacher of Zhuang Zhou, who transmitted the formula for reviving the dead to Bian Que.

Zizhou,

Liu Jing, disciple of Lord Zhang.

These twenty-seven individuals,²¹ all practiced the Dao of flying steps, though not all attained the Great Ultimate; many still resided in the Grand Clarity. Su Lin, styled Zixuan, a native of Qushui in Puyang, studied the Dao under Master Juan, receiving the Three Origins and True Unity. He wandered the human realm for several hundred years,²² until the Cloud Chariot with Feathered Canopy from the Dark Continent summoned him.²³ Drawn by dragons and tigers, he was enfeoffed as Upper Minister of the Dark Continent and appointed Grand Master of the Central Warden of the Great Ultimate. Master Juan, whose given name remains obscure, was a disciple of the Azure Lad and the teacher of Master Su. From youth, he consumed the essence of trees and received the Dao of the Mysterious Elixir and Guarding Unity. He served as Grand Master of the Four Central Yellow Offices and Lord of the Northern Sea. Guo Youdu, the True Man of Luhun, was Inspector of the Great Ultimate.²⁴ Fan Bohua, a native of Bin, was the Right Immortal Duke of Mount Rong. Chunyu Taixuan, a native of Stone City, was the True Man of Yangluo, overseeing the *Western Return Transmission*. Li Yi, styled Zhongfu,²⁵ a native of the Capital District, studied alongside Mao, Master of Destiny, under Lord Wang. Zuo Yuanfang, who studied under the Minister of the Western Marchmount, succeeded as Master of Destiny and separately oversaw the records of the Western Realm. Wang Zhong was Jade Gentleman of the Supreme Unity. The officials of the Great Ultimate Palace of Baoqiu included the Jade Maiden of Nanling. Sima Jizhu, a man of the Han, received the sword-liberation Dao from Xiling Zidu. Assuming the form of a pillow, he resided in the Great Abundance Palace of Mount Weiyu. Ingesting the blossoms of luminous cinnabar and drawing forth the radiance of dawn’s embrace, he was truly instructed: if one performs the sword-liberation method, one may not remain in the Great Ultimate. He had four disciples: one, Bao Yang, a native of Guangyu, practiced sword-liberation and perished in a mountain stream; another, Wang Yangbo, a native of Taiyuan, gathered herbs with Zhang Liang and never returned; another, Liu Weihui, a native of Yingchuan, was Liu Feng, the Palace Attendant of Emperor Jing of Han, who underwent corpse-liberation, leaving his staff and sandals beneath a mulberry tree; the last, Duan Jizheng, a native of Daijun, originally a recluse, underwent corpse-liberation but drowned while crossing the Qin River of Nanzheng. The Immortal Maiden of the Grand Clarity, Xilingzi, was the teacher of Jizhu. The Eight Elder Masters, whose names remain obscure, were likely the Eight Lords of Huainan; among them, some also resided in the Grand Clarity. The Seven True Men of Pure Emptiness of the Terrace of Liquids, whose names remain obscure, all dwelled in the palace of Mount Wangwu; among them, some also resided in the Upper Clarity. Jiang Wenqi, who descended the Perfected of the Southern Continent upon Mount Yangluo. Master Gai, the High Immortal Earl of the Great Ultimate. Zhang Feng, styled Gongxian, a native of Henei, formerly served as Master of Destiny of the Northern River of Shuhua and was enfeoffed as Marquis of Prohibitions. Ji Zijiu, already appointed by the Great Ultimate in the Shuhua Palace, also served as President of the Nine Palaces and Immortal Marquis of the Great Ultimate. Huang Guanzi, who studied the Dao, ingested golden cinnabar, and attained the Dao through reciting cavernous scriptures, became Left Minister of the Great Ultimate. Fan Mingqi, who received the *Western Liang* □ meal, was the Right Perfected of Purple Yang. Since Purple Yang had left and right Perfected Ones, Zhou Jun served as the Left Perfected, whose rank was higher and who had already ascended to the Upper Clarity as the Azure Essence Master. The two who received the *Western Liang* □ meal and attained the Dao were the Master of the Northern Valley of Dawan. Gong Zhongyang of the Cinnabar Mound Palace of Zhu Huo, and Gong Youyang, these two brothers received the true records of the Immortal Taboos from the Azure Lad and attained the Dao. The Eastern Extremity Elder, Master Fuyang; the Western Extremity Elder, Master Tuzhan Lingziqi; the Southern Extremity Elder, the Upper Perfected of Cinnabar Mound; the Northern Extremity Elder, the Dark Upper Immortal Sovereign; and the Central Origin Elder, the Central Supreme Master—these five cultivated the Five Celestial Bodies and became the Elders of the Five Directions. The True Man of the Eastern Extremity, Master Lingyang Ziming, and the True Man of the Northern Extremity, An Qisheng—these two, along with the Red Lord and Lord Wang, were known as the Four Extremity True Men. The Venerable Master of the Literary Beginning, and the Master of the Western Return.

The Half-Chariot Lad—these three were mutually accomplished as master and friend. Baicheng Zigao cultivated the Way of Step-Net, truly receiving the transmission of Cloud Mutual-Completion to absorb qi, whereby his intestines and stomach underwent threefold dissolution, resembling the traces of alchemical transformation.

Feng Hou was the Yellow Emperor’s master. King Mu of Zhou, surnamed Ji, was the great-grandson of King Cheng. He traveled throughout the world, feasted at Jasper Pool, and met the Queen Mother of the West.

Yu of Xia, surnamed Si, named Wenming, inherited the throne from King Shun and ruled the world. He received the Nine Practices of the Perfected from the True Lord of Bell Mountain, and by practicing the Mysterious Perfected Method, attained the Dao.

Emperor Shun, surnamed Yao, named Chonghua, consumed the Thousand-Turned Purple Frost presented by the Northern Rong’s Long-Bearded Chieftain and attained the Dao.

The Prince of the Royal House, a great-grandson of the Yellow Emperor, received the Five Talismans of the Numinous Treasure. He also journeyed to Bell Mountain to receive the Scripture of Nine Transformations and Ten Changes, thereby concealing himself from the sun and moon, roaming among the stars, and cultivating the Way of Sword Liberation.

The Dark Emperor Zhuanxu, grandson of the Yellow Emperor, traveled the Four Seas, buried the treasure tripod at Cavern Mountain, and received the Five Talismans of the Numinous Treasure to attain the Dao.

The Yellow Emperor Xuanyuan, surnamed Gongsun, practiced the Way of Step-Net and employed the method of Sword Liberation. He concealed himself at Bridge Mound, rode a dragon to the Dark Garden, and ascended upon clouds to the Tower of Langfeng to attain the Dao.

The Supreme Left Duke of the Great Ultimate, the Eight Perfected Limits of the Northern Luo Master.

The Five Elders and Upper Perfected of the Left Duke of the Immortal Capital, compilers of the Purple Texts of the Numinous Writ.

The Dark Harmony and Yin Mound Supreme Emperor, the Emperor of the Great Ultimate Central Heaven.

The Heavenly Emperor Lord of the Pure Harmony Palace, the Emperor of the Great Ultimate Central Heaven.

First, the Central Yellow Elder Lord, most revered on the left, who has already ascended to the Highest Clarity.

Second, the Purple Yang Left Immortal Duke, the Central Flower Prince, and the Stone Path of Empty Completion.

Third, Xi Liang Ziwen, who transmitted the Azure Essence to Wang Qingxu, feeding him cloud kernels and jade grains.

Fourth, An Duming, who first descended the Southern Perfected in the midst of Xiuwu County—these four are the Four Emperor Lords of the Golden Watchtower of the Great Ultimate. The Later Sage Li Lord, most revered on the left, has already ascended to the Highest Clarity, while the remaining three Emperors are the Heavenly Emperors of the Great Ultimate.

The aforementioned ninety-three individuals are the True Immortals of the Great Ultimate, some of whom have also advanced to the Highest Clarity.

*End of the Eighty-Fourth Scroll of the Supreme Secret Essentials*

Here begins the Eighty-Seventh Scroll of the *Supreme Secret Essentials*: "The Chapter on Liberation Through Corpse Transformation"

The Overseer of Destinies, Eastern Minister Lord, said: "As for *shijie* (corpse liberation), it is the transformation of form, the refinement and shedding of original truth, the escape and change of bodily substance, the concealment and departure of the five constituents. Though it ranks as the lowest grade among immortal attainments, the endowment and reception it entails are by no means slight.

Some do not yet wish to ascend to heaven but prefer to dwell in renowned mountains; some seek to exalt the teachings of the world, severing the Way of life and death; some wish to cut off the close attachments of descendants, deeming the pursuit of divine transcendence rare and difficult; some desire to observe the transformations of the world for long ages, yet dread the toils of immortal office.

Once the wondrous Dao is fully attained, one may freely follow high or low paths as one pleases. It is not that one is incapable, but rather that one clarifies life and death to establish a fixed pattern—what is called ‘concealing the three luminaries’ and ‘the sun sinking into the land.’ Those who ‘fly the blossoms of langgan jade’ while tending to their graves include Master Gaoqiu, Master Yanmen, and Master Hongya.

Yet none knew that Master Gaoqiu, at that time, entered the Six Radiance Mountains through *shijie*, later ingested the water of golden liquid, and received the blossoms of langgan jade from the Central Mountain Master. Feigning death once more, he entered the Dark Continent, received scriptures, and became the Perfected of the Central Marchmount. Master Yanmen now resides in the Golden Court of the Great Cavern of Mount Meng, having received scriptures to become the Immortal Minister of the Middle Prime. Master Hongya is now the Perfected of Green City.

Those who ‘rinsed the dragon embryo in death’s resolve’ and ‘drank jade essence while knocking on coffins’ include my late master Wang Xicheng, as well as Zhao Boxuan and Liu Zixian. Those who ‘ingested golden elixir and announced their end’ include Zang Yanfu, Zhang Zifang, and Master Mo Di. Those who ‘clasped the ninefold cyclical elixir yet reeked of corpse stench’ and ‘swallowed the knife-point elixir only to have insects stream forth’ include Sima Jizhu, Lord Ning Zhong, King Yan Zhao, and Prince Wang Zijin.

King Mu of Zhou journeyed north to the slopes of Kunlun, personally drank the crimson marrow of Mount Jiang, and ate the fruit of the jade tree, yet was buried in Jiyin. Yu the Great visited Mount Zhong, tasted purple [elixir] and became drunk on golden wine, and practiced the Nine Perfected of the Numinous Treasure, yet still concealed himself in Kuaiji. The Great King of the Northern Rong, Changhu, presented Emperor Shun with ten transformations of white langgan frost and purple blossoms, which upon ingestion grant long life and flight as an immortal, rivaling heaven and earth. Shun ingested them yet feigned death and was buried in the wilds of Cangwu.

All these lords had already ‘ascended to the numinous river with dragon suites’ and ‘drummed the cloud pools with phoenixes,’ yet still employed *shijie* and feigned death. Their true intent was to sever the emotions of life and death, demonstrating to the people the limits of beginning and end. How could they be like those who rot in the dark yin of the earth, their flesh fed to ants and mole crickets?

Their aim was to obstruct those who defy the world and block the aspirations of the vulgar. As for Master Qingjing, Peng Keng, Feng Gang, the Four Hoary Ones of Mount Shang, and the Eight Lords of Huainan, all had ingested the supreme elixir. Yet without taking even a single dose, they chose to withdraw in silence, secluding themselves in mountains and forests, delighting in roaming transformations and grieving over ascending the void. It was not that they could not ascend to heaven, but that they chose not to.

Thus, these lords wandered among the Five Marchmounts, changing their names and altering their appearances, no longer resorting to *shijie*. The Way of *shijie*, though somewhat wondrous, is rare and obstructed by emotions. Those who hear of it cannot attain it, and death is used to seal its path, showing there is no more to discuss. Even if Peng Keng roamed the mountains, Feng Gang frequented markets and courts, the Four Hoary Ones feigned old age, or the Eight Lords of Huainan transformed their forms myriad times, such things are not what I desire.

There are those who, by virtue of their names being inscribed on the Fangzhu register, are destined to become *shijie* immortals. Some are made so by their endowment, others by the decline of their aspirations and conduct, or by shallow and narrow learning, their inclinations stagnant and fixed. These are matters of rare attainment and individual allotment, not what was previously discussed. Lords like Master Yanmen and his peers, having already partaken of the supreme elixir, deliberately employed *shijie*.

In the past, I received from my late master the supreme methods of *shijie* and the arts of transformation by commission. Though I did not attain their use, I have always cherished them. Now, as the world’s dust and grime converge, armies clash fiercely, the Three Offices drive out the worthy and harm the Dao, those who speak of divine transcendence seek illness and pursue profit, and those who aspire to wealth and honor seek life through the Dao—why should one hasten amidst wind and fire, donning robes to enter the markets of Yan?

Now I secretly reveal the methods of *shijie*. Each may transmit them to disciples who are destined to become Perfected Ones. Employing them in concealment and flight can distance one from misfortune; applying them in departure can sever the close attachments of descendants; hiding and roaming can lead one to ascend renowned mountains.

If one’s Dao and arts are fully complete, myriad techniques perfectly clear, able to command a hundred ghosts, summon all spirits, sit and vanish, or disperse one’s form with a breath—though amidst armies, blades cannot harm; though traversing peril, calamities cannot touch; though entering markets and courts, no harm can arise—then one need not resort to the transformations of *shijie*.

Those who practice this liberation are mostly those not eager for the dragon chariot, content to dwell peacefully in mountains and forests. Take the *Lingwan* elixir, mix it with saliva, and apply it to the staff you hold. Sleep with it for three days, and the staff will transform into your likeness beneath the covers. Then depart quietly, and no one nearby will notice.

Apply the elixir to burning charcoal, and others will see your form burned to death—this is called *fire liberation*. Take one pill with water and drink it, then embrace grass and lie down. Others will see you wounded to death in an empty chamber—this is called *martial liberation*. In all cases, one may freely return to one’s hometown, but must change one’s name and alter one’s appearance."

In ancient times, one practitioner did this and entered Linlü Mountain, dwelling there for thirteen years before returning home. The supreme method of liberation is called *Matching the Purple Slip*, whereby the Three Offices no longer record one’s transgressions, sealing all gaps and falsely attributing death to the practitioner.

The *Lingwan* elixir may also be used to achieve *shijie* for others, provided one instructs them clearly on the timing and procedures of departure. If one wishes to bring a favored disciple along on their journey, this should be arranged accordingly. Those who achieve *shijie* through other elixirs, not by the transformation of the *Lingwan* pill, may not return to their hometown—for if they do, the Three Offices will seize them.

The methods of *shijie* vary: some die and then revive, some are decapitated yet emerge alive from elsewhere, some perish before burial and vanish without a trace, some retain their form but lose their bones, some leave their clothes behind while their form departs, and some shed their hair before their form disappears. Those who depart by daylight are called *upper shijie*; those who depart at midnight are called *lower shijie*; those who depart at dawn or dusk are called *Earthly Overseers*—though they achieve concealment, their traces remain, arousing suspicion. In this age, those whose aspirations are unfulfilled may not yet wander their hometowns, drifting without fixed abode, deeply entangled in doubt, their intentions lingering here.

If one’s ancestors have accrued merit in the Three Offices, its blessings may extend to descendants, allowing some to refine their transformations across generations, changing their surnames and rebirthing. This is the transmission of seven generations of hidden virtue, where roots and branches intertwine. Upon death, they must leave behind one bone to return to the Three Offices, while the rest of their bones ascend with their form. Men leave their left bone, women their right, and all receive scriptures to become Earthly Overseers. After two hundred and eighty years, they may advance to receive the Dao of Earthly Immortality.

On the day of their passing, if their form appears as flesh of the living, and at death their body remains fragrant and pure, their toes unblackened, their hands unwrinkled, this is called *naturally achieving shijie through prior virtue*.

—Excerpted from *The Scripture of Concealed Radiance and the Record of Form and Spirit* from the *Dongzhen* canon

The *Four Epochs* states: The *Central Scripture of the Nine Perfected* (also called *The Flying Feather Scripture*)—those who possess it may achieve *shijie* by daylight.

The *Six Epochs* states: The *Numinous Book of Purple Texts* (also called *The Treasure Scripture of the Five Elders*)—those who possess it may achieve *shijie*.

—Excerpted from *The Jade Chapters of the Emperor* from the *Dongzhen* canon

For all Earthly Overseers who achieve *shijie*, according to the *True Regulations of the Four Poles*, after one hundred and forty years they may be appointed as Immortal Officials, and after another one thousand three hundred years, they may be appointed as Perfected Officials. Only then may they ascend on flying blossoms, ride a host of dragons, and roam the Nine Palaces of the Great Ultimate.

—Excerpted from *The Hidden Scripture of the Supreme* from the *Dongzhen* canon

Those who possess these scriptures yet fail to diligently cultivate, contemplate the true, and revere the numinous—indistinguishable from the common folk—may still preserve their hidden existence as Lesser Immortals and achieve *shijie* by daylight.

—Excerpted from *The Eight Simplicities of the True* from the *Dongzhen* canon

The Perfected of the Great Ultimate bequeathed a belt scattered with white powder. Consuming one *daogui* of it induces sudden heart pain as if pierced, and after three days of thirst, drinking a *hu* of liquid will sever the breath, leading to death. After burial, the corpse vanishes, leaving only clothes behind—this is the *Belt Liberation Immortal* of daylight. If one knows the name of the elixir, the heart pain ceases, but drinking a *hu* of liquid will still sever the breath. Upon severance, one awakens to find their discarded corpse on the earth. At that moment, jade maidens and jade lads arrive in a blue carriage to welcome them. Those who wish to pause must endure three days of heart pain, regulated by their drinking.

This method may be compounded and used by an entire household.

—Excerpted from *The Scripture of True Traces*

The Grand Ultimate Golden Flower Perfected One inscribed this scripture upon the eastern wall of the Mystic Jade Hall within the Purple Tenuity Palace of the Heavenly Emperor of the Great Tenuity. Its text reads:

The five qi arise from different directions,
Essence-light unites with form.
Some end in death,
Some begin in life.
The myriad kinds return to their root,
A thousand threads merge into darkness.
Qi drifts like floating mist,
Blood rushes as flowing clarity.
In a single dawn, the body takes shape—
Without the true, it cannot be complete.

Why not refine it with *yuncao* of dark purity,
Infuse it with *huili* of blossoming herbs,
Conjoin it with the five luminous, seven white numinous greens,
And harmonize it with the white essence of soaring dragons?

Bathe at dawn’s first light,
Compose the mind and face the east.
Concentrate the essence, rouse the soul—
Before the Five Lords of the Supreme Emperor,
Bow twice and pay homage to the numinous.
Secure the five directions,
Prolong life between heaven and earth,
Enter and circulate freely,
Each resting in its proper place,
Flourishing the five viscera.

This text is the Great Script of Intertwining Dragons from the Eight Assemblies of the Highest Clarity—
Not something worldly scholars can comprehend.

The Grand Simplicity Perfected One, having distinguished and transcribed its characters,
Received and ingested it,
Seeking its explication from the Grand Ultimate Heavenly Lord.

*Yuncao of dark waves* is *heiju* vine, also called *xuanqing*.
*Huili of blossoming herbs* is honey.
*The five luminous, seven white numinous greens* are *xie* greens.
*The white essence of soaring dragons* is quartz.

The method requires cultivating *xie* greens,
Leaving them unharvested on the fifth day of the fifth month,
Only tending and nurturing them with the hoe.
After five years,
They may be gathered as medicine,
Called *the five luminous, seven white numinous greens*.
Select ten pounds of the finest, deep-blue, plump *xie* greens,
Five *dou* of *heiju* vine,
Five *dou* of honey as congealed snow,
Thirty-six *hu* of pristine water from the stone cavities of lofty mountains and dark cliffs,
And five pieces of pure white quartz, free of grit and flaws.
First, grind them well on a whetstone,
Shaping them into perfect spheres like small sparrow’s eggs,
Polishing them to a pearl-like luster,
Ensuring no trace of grit remains.

Begin a purification fast of one hundred and sixty days,
Completing it on the ninth day of the first month.
Then, construct a foundation of earth two *chi* high,
Build a furnace-house,
And within it, a proper furnace,
With the cauldron’s mouth facing west—
The house should also have a western door.
Obtain a new iron cauldron and place it upon the furnace.
On the ninth day of the ninth month, at the *shen* and *you* hours,
Kneel facing the cauldron’s mouth, toward the east,
And place the five stone pellets into the cauldron.
First, cast one pellet into the cauldron and invoke:

Stone of the Azure Emperor,
Three Pristine Primordial Lords,
Great One Who Oversees Destiny,
Dark Mother Who Governs the Soul,
Fortify the bones, replenish the liver,
Guard and nourish the liver spirit,
Let the liver flourish above,
That the liver may endure forever.

Next, cast another pellet into the cauldron and recite:

Stone of the White Emperor,
Where the Great One rests,
Primordial Father Who Governs essence,
Dark Mother Who Replenishes the lungs,
Guard and nourish the lung spirit,
Let it know no decay,
Let the lungs flourish above,
For ten thousand myriad ages.

Next, cast another pellet into the cauldron and invoke:

Stone of the Vermilion Emperor,
In harmony with the Heavenly Lord’s voice,
Dark Mother Who Governs the blood,
Peach Vitality Who Replenishes the heart,
Guard and nourish the heart spirit,
Let it know no ashen sinking,
Let the heart flourish above,
Becoming a forest of jade.

Next, cast another pellet into the cauldron and recite:

Stone of the Black Emperor,
In accord with the Great One’s calculations,
Dark Mother and Primordial Father,
Who govern the transformation of fluids,
Guard and nourish the kidney spirit,
Let it know no ruin or chaos,
Let the kidneys flourish above,
Ever attaining the highest aspiration.

Next, cast the final pellet into the cauldron and invoke:

Stone of the Yellow Emperor,
In shared majesty with the Venerable Lord,
Great One and Heavenly Lord Who Governs the po and secures the spleen,
Guard and nourish the spleen spirit,
Let it know no collapse,
Let the spleen flourish above,
Ascending at dawn’s light.

When casting the stones, hold the breath for five cycles before each placement.
Once all are cast, rise and face the furnace,
Bowing twice five times.
Then take five pounds of *xie* whites,
Carefully layering them over the five stones.
Afterward, pour honey to cover the *xie*.
Then, add five *dou* of *jujiao* to cover the honey.
Next, measure the depth to which the *jujiao* fills the cauldron.
Gradually add clear water, leaving the cauldron slightly unfilled,
Covering it loosely with a wooden lid.
At dawn on the tenth day of the ninth month, kindle the fire,
Using straight-grained, well-dried firewood,
Avoiding worm-eaten or bark-stripped, impure fuel.
Let the fire simmer gently,
Preventing violent boiling or overflow.
Frequently tend the fire,
Adjusting its intensity below.
First, observe the level of the rich decoction;
When the water reduces, replenish it as needed,
Using all thirty-six *hu* of water.
After the water is spent,
Continue simmering until the decoction reduces by two *cun* from its original level,
Judging by sight.
When complete, let it cool in the cauldron,
Remove the fire and ashes,
Seal the cauldron tightly,
And after five days, gently retrieve the five stones.
At dawn, face the five directions and bow twice each.
Then, kneeling, take this rich decoction,
Mixing it with east-flowing water,
And consume it in sequence.
When drinking the water and decoction,
Let the stone pellets follow into the mouth and down the throat.
While ingesting, recite the invocations as when first casting the stones into the cauldron.
Afterward, bow twice five times again.

If, upon completion of the decoction, no stones remain,
There is no cause for alarm—
The five essences have dissolved and concealed their numinous forms,
Merging into the cloud-like richness,
Leaving no trace.
Simply consume five *ge* daily,
Washing it down with clear wine.
The spirit transforms, the body reverts,
Each securing and nourishing the five viscera.
Within the five viscera,
The five stones are regenerated anew.

Beware of fierce fire—
If the fire is too strong, the stone essence will flee,
The dregs will spoil and rot,
The cloud-like richness will scorch and reek,
Rendering it unfit for consumption.
Moreover, the flavor of this cloud-like richness is
Fragrant, sweet, and surpassingly fine,
Strengthening the blood, replenishing the essence,
Filling and generating the five viscera,
Securing the qi, congealing the fluids,
Prolonging and nourishing the hun and po—
A true supreme medicine.

Store it in a fine vessel, sealing it tightly. Begin by consuming two *ge* daily, maintaining this regimen without fail. If the cloud-like richness or honeyed decoction proves too potent, it may be extracted first, with the stone medicine taken afterward, then recombined and simmered until it congeals like sliced fat. Some choose to form it into pills, taking thirty daily, though the richness is far superior to pill form. The method may be adapted to personal preference, for what suits the body brings ease, and what brings ease is without flaw.

Those who regularly consume this richness will find it most excellent. Once the initial supply is exhausted, prepare another batch as before: place five *liang* of white quartz at the bottom of the cauldron, adding one *liang* at a time while reciting the prescribed incantations. Unlike before, the stones need not be ground but should be rounded for easier ingestion. Once the medicine is complete, remove the stones and cast them into an eastward-flowing stream, avoiding stagnant or parched pools. If one chooses not to prepare another batch, the previous five stones remain undiminished.

This richness is called *Mysterious Water Jade Liquid*, also known as *Flying Dragon Cloud-Richness* or *Refined Essence of the Five Stones*. After fifteen years of consumption, the body will radiate a jade-like luminosity, becoming inwardly and outwardly translucent. One will attain longevity matching heaven and earth, command ghosts and spirits, and after three years, gain the ability to read by night. The True One says: "This formula surpasses the refinement of eight stones or the ingestion of gold, and far excels the jade nectar of cassia water and mica."

Upon consuming these five stones, they descend into the throat and directly fill the five viscera. The viscera perpetually generate their essence, each housing one stone to guard its apertures. Above these apertures bloom five-colored flowers. Should one temporarily die and pass through the Great Yin, enduring the trials of the Three Bureaus—where flesh turns to ash, blood sinks, and pulses scatter—the five viscera will yet regenerate. The white bones will gleam like jade, the seven *po* will tend the remains, the three *hun* will guard the dwelling, the Three Primes will rejoice in rest, the Great Spirit will seal within, the Great One will record the spirit, and the Controller of Destinies will hold the tally. The Five Elders will uphold their splendor, and the Imperial Lord will treasure the essence. After thirty, twenty, ten, or five years—emerging at will—the time of rebirth arrives: blood is recollected, flesh nurtured, fluids generated, and the form reconstituted, its refined appearance surpassing even its pre-death state. This is what the True One means by "refining the body in the Great Yin and transforming the countenance before the Three Bureaus."

The Celestial Emperor of the Great Tenuity intoned:
*"Refining the body in the Great Yin,
Outshines the nine-fold cinnabar elixir.
A radiant visage, dignified and stern,
A countenance suffused with numinous light.
The five stones unite with celestial perfection,
The Great One treasures the spirit’s gate.
Ascending the Terrace of the Great Ultimate,
One receives the scriptures and becomes an immortal."*

The True Man of the Southern Marchmount, Red Pine Master, said: "Long ago, there was a man named Zhao Chengzi, a student of immortality. He first received my *Upper Scripture on Filling and Nurturing the Five Viscera* and followed its instructions. Later, Chengzi deliberately sought to enter the Great Yin to transform his appearance and alter his form. At that time, he feigned death in a stone chamber beneath the Dark Mound Mountain in Shanggu of Youzhou, becoming a corpse of white bones. Five or six years later, a traveler passing through the mountains discovered his remains in the stone chamber—flesh decayed, bones intact. Yet within, the five viscera remained self-generated, fragrant and uncorrupted as before, wrapped in fluids and blood, with five-colored flowers gleaming within and a purple placenta entwining without.

The traveler sighed, saying: 'I have heard that the viscera can be nurtured to endure without decay—now I see such a man! This one must have possessed the Dao but failed to complete it.' He pried open the corpse and found within each viscus a white stone. 'What preserves your viscera must be these five stones,' he said. 'You have lost the Dao; I shall take them for myself.' He extracted the stones and swallowed them whole. The stones descended into his throat.

Ten years later, as Chengzi’s corpse was about to revive, the traveler—having already consumed the stones—found them flying from his mouth like cicadas, returning to the corpse’s viscera. Thereupon, Chengzi transformed and rose. Witnessing the stones take flight, the traveler trembled in awe. Days later, he returned to the mountain to seek the corpse’s resting place. Arriving at the stone chamber, he saw Chengzi, hair unbound and reclining, whistling through the numinous valley, his face radiating jade-like light, his hair lustrous and flowing. Overcome, the traveler prostrated himself among the rocks and bamboo.

Chengzi asked: 'Who are you?' Suddenly, five elderly immortals appeared before Chengzi, clad in embroidered robes and talismanic sashes, holding feathered tablets, crowned in purple, treading upon the void. Gnashing their teeth, they addressed Chengzi: 'The one who stole and swallowed your viscera’s precious stones is this leprous-faced man before you.' At their words, the traveler’s face erupted in foul sores, his speech failed, and he fled in disarray. Upon reaching home, his entire household was afflicted with leprosy, and all perished together, their clan extinguished.

When a perfected one temporarily journeys through the Great Yin, the Great One guards the corpse, the three *hun* tend the bones, the seven *po* protect the flesh, and the embryonic spirit records the qi. It is not that they wish to conceal evil intentions or blind the eyes and ears of the wicked and foolish, but rather to manifest numinous proofs across the eight directions and display true majesty in resplendent glory. How much more so when one harbors the divine stones of the Five Emperors and the essence of the Numinous Lords? To steal and consume them in hopes of prolonging life or secretly seeking immortality is beyond hope—how could it be otherwise?

Thus, the True Man of the Southern Marchmount recorded this tale to dispel the reckless greed of thieves."

—Excerpted from *The Upper Scripture of the Supreme Emperor of the Great Ultimate on Filling and Nurturing the Five Viscera*
*Concluding the Eighty-Seventh Scroll of the* Supreme Essentials of the Unsurpassed
*Beginning the Eighty-Eighth Scroll of the* Supreme Essentials of the Unsurpassed

**On the Transformation of Form**

Laozi said: When a serpent obtains the Numinous Treasure, it transforms into a divine dragon; when a crow obtains it, it becomes a phoenix; when a common beast obtains it, it turns into a qilin; when an ordinary person obtains it, they are called a sage.

What is a sage? One who possesses the scripture of the Perfected Communion with the Sacred, and who constantly ingests it, may wander and sport upon the Five Marchmounts, roam freely through the void, alter the five viscera, and transform their form and appearance. In one year, their qi is renewed; in two years, their blood; in three years, their flesh; in four years, their sinews; in five years, their bones; in six years, their marrow; in seven years, their hair; in eight years, their locks; in nine years, their very form—body and substance entirely transformed. Thus is the Great Dao perfected.

—Excerpted from *The Scripture of the Five Natural Designations from the Cavern of Mystery*

The Divine Lord of the Great One gives birth to the five viscera, fills the six stomachs, nourishes the nine orifices, harmonizes the nine passes, refines the three hun-souls, illumines the two youths, preserves the body, and grants longevity of ten thousand years. Here follows the formula for the Four-Filling Pellets.

**Four-Filling Pellets Formula**

*Taiyi Yu Yu Root*, four liang: stabilizes the six palaces and fills the five viscera.
*True Tangkuei*, one liang: harmonizes with the Yu Yu Root to halt the onset of the hundred diseases.
*Frankincense*, one liang: blends with Tangkuei to fumigate the five viscera within.
*Ginseng*, one liang: supplements the fluids of the six palaces and aids the potency of the Yu Yu Root.
*Clove*, one liang: dispels guest heat in the stomach and arrests phlegm congestion.

The above five ingredients take the Yu Yu Root as their chief, with the other four following it. First, place the chief ingredient in the mortar and pound it a hundred times, then add the remaining four and grind them into powder.

*Cinnabar*, four liang: gathers the hun and po souls, fills the three spirits, and regulates harmonious qi.
*Licorice*, one liang: harmonizes with cinnabar, benefits the flesh, and removes white hair.
*Costus Root*, one liang: assists licorice in expelling the three worms and hidden corpses.
*Dried Rehmannia*, one liang: harmonizes the hundred marrows and fills the brain with blood.
*Rosewood*, one liang: brightens the pupils of the eyes and fumigates the lower passes.

The above five ingredients take cinnabar as their chief, with the other four following it. First, place the chief ingredient in the mortar and pound it a hundred times, then add the remaining four and grind them all into powder.

*Poria*, four liang: fills the seven orifices, supplements the nine deficiencies, and harmonizes the numinous passes.
*Wood* [ingredient unclear], one liang: harmonizes with poria, enhances spirit and qi, and brightens the pupils of the eyes.
*Dried Ginger*, one liang: supplements the potency of the wood, dispels phlegm-heat, opens the three passes, and removes cold.
*Ledebouriella*, one liang: supplements numbness and impediment, dispels foul fluids, and arrests hunger and thirst.
*Mica Powder*, one liang: moistens the form and body, generates luster in the face, and supplements bone and blood.

The above five ingredients take poria as their chief, with the other four following it. First, place the chief ingredient in the mortar and pound it a hundred times, then add the remaining four and grind them all into powder.

*Ophiopogon*, four liang (remove the heart): fills the spirit-essence, nourishes the numinous fluids, and secures the bones.
*Dried Jujube Paste*, one liang: assists ophiopogon, congeals the blood vessels, and removes heart impurities.
*Aconite*, one liang (stir-fried): benefits the qi of the brain, fills cold within the viscera, and dispels phlegm.
*Sesame*, one liang (stir-fried): harmonizes the fluids of the throat and mouth, fills leakage in the lower passes, and moistens the three spirits.
*Dragon Bone*, one liang: benefits the six fluids, nourishes the orifices and intestines, blackens the hair, and halts whitening.

The above five ingredients take ophiopogon as their chief, with the other four following it. First, place the chief ingredient in the mortar and pound it a hundred times, then add the remaining four and grind them all into powder.

In total, the Four-Filling Spirit Pellets comprise twenty ingredients, divided into five groups, each ground into powder. First, place the Yu Yu Root group in the mortar and pound it three thousand times; next, add the cinnabar group and pound it four thousand times; then add the poria group and pound it five thousand times; next, add the ophiopogon group and pound it six thousand times. Then add four sheng of white honey and pound it seven thousand times; next, add twelve liang of white wax and pound it eight thousand times. Add more honey until the mixture can be formed into pills—if the mixture is too firm, add honey; if it is soft, no further addition is needed. Add more honey and continue pounding up to thirty thousand times. When the medicine is complete, form it into pills the size of a chicken’s egg yolk, or calculate the yolk’s size to make smaller pills for ingestion.

Take the first day of the first and ninth months, when the stellar configurations are aligned, to compound the medicine. Begin ingestion on the full moon and continue for a hundred days. At the middle hour, measure and take five pills. On the preceding day, fast; on the following day at dawn, ingest the pills. Afterward, resume eating and drinking as usual. After a thousand days, take seven pills within two hundred days. After two thousand days, take twenty-nine pills within three hundred days. After three thousand days, take thirty-nine pills within four hundred days. This is the established measure. The spirit fills and guards the center, and one’s destiny becomes coextensive with Heaven and Earth. This medicine does not decay for ten thousand years. If one constantly ingests this medicine, one need never again consume any other miscellaneous food or elixirs.

Before compounding the medicine, observe abstinence for seven days, forever renouncing the bedchamber. Do not allow chickens, dogs, children, or women to see it. When compounding the medicine, burn incense and set a divine seat facing east for the Divine Lord of the Great One, the Lord of the Great One, and the Supreme Primordial Lord of the Great One. Constantly maintain reverent visualization and invocation. When ingesting the medicine, likewise visualize and face the Moon King. This is what is called the Four Great Ones, which fill the four spirits and cure the hundred diseases. It enables one to perceive without turning one’s gaze ten thousand *li* away, restores blackness to white hair, regrows fallen teeth, and makes the face and eyes radiant while the skin and texture generate luster. After one year of ingestion, all long-standing illnesses are dispelled; in two years, the hair turns black; in three years, the qi is renewed; in four years, the vessels are renewed; in five years, the [text unclear] is renewed; in six years, the sinews are renewed; in seven years, the bones are renewed; in eight years, the teeth are renewed; in nine years, the form and body are renewed. In ten years, one commands ghosts and spirits and wields authority over tigers and wolves.
